id=\"p-tb\" class=\"vector-menu mw-portlet mw-portlet-tb\">\n\t<div class=\"vector-menu-heading\">\n\t\tGeneral\n\t</div>\n\t<div class=\"vector-menu-content\">\n\t\t\n\t\t<ul class=\"vector-column-end no-font-mode-scale\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<div class=\"vector-sticky-pinned-container\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<nav class=\"vector-page-tools-landmark\" aria-label=\"Page tools\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<div id=\"vector-page-tools-pinned-container\" class=\"vector-pinned-container\">\n\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t</nav>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<nav class=\"vector-appearance-landmark\" aria-label=\"Appearance\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<div id=\"vector-appearance-pinned-container\" class=\"vector-pinned-container\">\n\t\t\t\t<div id=\"vector-appearance\" class=\"vector-appearance vector-pinnable-element\">\n\t<div class=\"vector-pinnable-header vector-appearance-pinnable-header vector-pinnable-header-pinned\" data-feature-name=\"appearance-pinned\" class=\"vector-body\" aria-labelledby=\"firstHeading\" data-mw-ve-target-container=\"\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<div class=\"vector-body-before-content\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<div class=\"mw-indicators\">\n\t\t<div id=\"mw-indicator-pp-default\" class=\"mw-indicator\"><div class=\"mw-parser-output\"><span typeof=\"mw:File\"><a href=\"/wiki/Wikipedia:Protection_policy#semi\" title=\"This article is semi-protected.\"><img alt=\"Page semi-protected\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/1/1b/Semi-protection-shackle.svg/20px-Semi-protection-shackle.svg.png\" decoding=\"async\" encyclopedia</div>\n\t\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t\t<div id=\"contentSub\"><div id=\"mw-content-subtitle\"></div></div>\n\t\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t\t\t<div id=\"mw-content-text\" class=\"mw-body-content\"><div class=\"mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output\" lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\"><div class=\"shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux\" style=\"display:none\">Japanese media franchise</div>\n<style data-mw-deduplicate=\"TemplateStyles:r1320445320\">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}@media print{body.ns-0 .mw-parser-output .hatnote{display:none!important}}</style><div role=\"note\" class=\"hatnote navigation-not-searchable\">This article is about the media franchise as a whole. For the video game series, see <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_(video_game_series)\" title=\"Pokémon (video game series)\"><i>Pokémon</i> (video game series)</a>. For the animated series, see <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_(TV_series)\" title=\"Pokémon (TV series)\"><i>Pokémon</i> (TV series)</a>. For a list of creatures known as \"Pokémon\", see <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_Pok%C3%A9mon\" title=\"List of Pokémon\">List of Pokémon</a>. For other uses, see <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_(disambiguation)\" class=\"mw-disambig\" title=\"Pokémon (disambiguation)\">Pokémon (disambiguation)</a>.</div>\n<p class=\"mw-empty-elt\">\n\n</p>\n<style data-mw-deduplicate=\"TemplateStyles:r1316064257\">.mw-parser-output .infobox-subbox{padding:0;border:none;margin:-3px;width:auto;min-width:100%;font-size:100%;clear:none;float:none;background-color:transparent;color:inherit}.mw-parser-output color:inherit;\">Pokémon</th></tr><tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"infobox-image\"><span class=\"mw-default-size\" typeof=\"mw:File/Frameless\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:International_Pok%C3%A9mon_logo.svg\" ul{line-height:inherit;list-style:none;margin:0;padding:0}.mw-parser-output .plainlist ol li,.mw-parser-output .plainlist ul li{margin-bottom:0}</style><div class=\"plainlist\">\n<ul><li><a href=\"/wiki/Game_Freak\" title=\"Game Freak\">Game Freak</a><sup id=\"cite_ref-Legal_2-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Legal-2\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>2<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup></li></ul>\n</div></td></tr><tr><th scope=\"row\" class=\"infobox-label\">Years</th><td class=\"infobox-data\">1996–present</td></tr><tr><th colspan=\"2\" color:inherit;\">Films and television</th></tr><tr><th scope=\"row\" class=\"infobox-label\">Film(s)</th><td class=\"infobox-data\">See <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_Pok%C3%A9mon_films\" title=\"List of Pokémon films\">list of <i>Pokémon</i> films</a></td></tr><tr><th scope=\"row\" class=\"infobox-label\">Animated series</th><td class=\"infobox-data\"><a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_(TV_series)\" Game</a></i></td></tr><tr><th scope=\"row\" class=\"infobox-label\">Video game(s)</th><td class=\"infobox-data\"><a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_(video_game_series)\" title=\"Pokémon (video game series)\"><i>Pokémon</i> video game series</a></td></tr><tr><th colspan=\"2\" class=\"infobox-header\" style=\"background: #EBEBEB; color:inherit;\">Official website</th></tr><tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"infobox-full-data\"><span class=\"official-website\"><span class=\"url\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"https://www.portal-pokemon.com/\">Official hub</a></span></span></td></tr></tbody></table>\n<p><i><b>Pokémon</b></i><sup id=\"cite_ref-3\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-3\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>a<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-4\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-4\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>b<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> is a Japanese <a href=\"/wiki/Media_franchise\" title=\"Media franchise\">media franchise</a> consisting of <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_Pok%C3%A9mon_video_games\" title=\"List of Pokémon video games\">video games</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_(TV_series)\" title=\"Pokémon (TV series)\">animated series</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_Pok%C3%A9mon_films\" title=\"List of Pokémon films\">films</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Trading_Card_Game\" title=\"Pokémon Trading Card Game\">a trading card game</a>, and other related media. The franchise takes place in a <a href=\"/wiki/Shared_universe\" title=\"Shared universe\">shared universe</a> in which humans co-exist with creatures known as <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_Pok%C3%A9mon\" title=\"List of Pokémon\">Pokémon</a>, a large variety of species endowed with special powers. The franchise's primary <a href=\"/wiki/Target_audience\" title=\"Target audience\">target audience</a> is children aged 5 to 12,<sup id=\"cite_ref-5\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-5\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>3<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> but it is known to attract people of all ages.<sup id=\"cite_ref-14\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-14\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>I<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <i>Pokémon</i> is estimated to be the world's <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_highest-grossing_media_franchises\" title=\"List of highest-grossing media franchises\">highest-grossing media franchise</a> and is one of the <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_best-selling_video_game_franchises\" title=\"List of best-selling video game franchises\">best-selling video game franchises</a>.\n</p><p>The franchise originated as <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Red,_Blue,_and_Yellow\" title=\"Pokémon Red, Blue, and Yellow\">a pair of role-playing games</a> developed by <a href=\"/wiki/Game_Freak\" title=\"Game Freak\">Game Freak</a>, from an original concept by its founder, <a href=\"/wiki/Satoshi_Tajiri\" title=\"Satoshi Tajiri\">Satoshi Tajiri</a>. Released on the <a href=\"/wiki/Game_Boy\" title=\"Game Boy\">Game Boy</a> on 27 February 1996, the games became <a href=\"/wiki/Sleeper_hit\" title=\"Sleeper hit\">sleeper hits</a> and were followed by manga series, a trading card game, and anime series and films. From 1998 to 2000, <i>Pokémon</i> was exported to the rest of the world, creating an unprecedented global phenomenon dubbed \"Pokémania\". By 2002, the craze had ended, after which <i>Pokémon</i> became a fixture in popular culture, with new products releasing to this day. In the summer of 2016, the franchise spawned a second craze with the release of <i><a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Go\" title=\"Pokémon Go\">Pokémon Go</a></i>, an <a href=\"/wiki/Augmented_reality_game\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Augmented reality game\">augmented reality game</a> developed by <a href=\"/wiki/Niantic,_Inc.\" title=\"Niantic, Inc.\">Niantic</a>.\n</p><p>Unlike most <a href=\"/wiki/Intellectual_property\" title=\"Intellectual property\">IPs</a>, which are owned by one company,<sup id=\"cite_ref-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p474-475_15-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p474-475-15\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>12<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <i>Pokémon</i> is jointly owned by three: <a href=\"/wiki/Nintendo\" title=\"Nintendo\">Nintendo</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Game_Freak\" title=\"Game Freak\">Game Freak</a>, and <a href=\"/wiki/Creatures_(company)\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Creatures (company)\">Creatures</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Legal_2-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Legal-2\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>2<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Game Freak develops the core series <a href=\"/wiki/Role-playing_video_game\" title=\"Role-playing video game\">RPGs</a>, which are published by Nintendo exclusively for their consoles, while Creatures manages the trading card game and related merchandise, occasionally developing spin-off titles. The three companies established <a href=\"/wiki/The_Pok%C3%A9mon_Company\" title=\"The Pokémon Company\">The Pokémon Company</a> (TPC) in 1998 to manage the <i>Pokémon</i> property within Asia. The <i>Pokémon</i> anime series and films are co-owned by <a href=\"/wiki/Shogakukan\" title=\"Shogakukan\">Shogakukan</a>. Since 2009, The Pokémon Company International (TPCi), a subsidiary of TPC, has managed the franchise in all regions outside Asia.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Daswani_(2009)_16-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Daswani_(2009)-16\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>13<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-TPCi_About_Us_17-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-TPCi_About_Us-17\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>14<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<meta property=\"mw:PageProp/toc\">\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading2\"><h2 id=\"Name\">Name</h2></div>\n<p>The original full name of the franchise is <i><b>Pocket Monsters</b></i><span style=\"font-weight: normal\"> (<span title=\"Japanese-language text\"><span lang=\"ja\">ポケットモンスター</span></span>, <span title=\"Hepburn transliteration\"><i lang=\"ja-Latn\"><i>Poketto Monsutā</i></i></span>)</span>, which has been <a href=\"/wiki/Japanese_abbreviated_and_contracted_words\" title=\"Japanese abbreviated and contracted words\">commonly abbreviated</a> to <i>Pokemon</i><span style=\"font-weight: normal\"> (<span title=\"Japanese-language text\"><span lang=\"ja\">ポケモン</span></span>)</span> since its launch. When the franchise was released internationally, the short form of the title was used, with an <a href=\"/wiki/Acute_accent\" title=\"Acute accent\">acute accent</a> (´) over the <i>e</i> to aid in pronunciation.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Tsukayama_(2016)_18-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Tsukayama_(2016)-18\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>15<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> As a Japanese word composed of English loanwords, the word <i>Pokémon</i> is an example of a <i><a href=\"/wiki/Wasei-eigo\" title=\"Wasei-eigo\">wasei-eigo</a></i>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-TIME_19-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-TIME-19\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>16<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup class=\"reference nowrap\"><span title=\"Page / location: 30\">: 30 </span></sup>\n</p><p><i>Pokémon</i> refers to both the franchise itself and the creatures within its fictional universe. As a noun, it is <a href=\"/wiki/English_plurals#Nouns_with_identical_singular_and_plural\" title=\"English plurals\">identical in both the singular and plural</a>, as is every individual species name;<sup id=\"cite_ref-Baylis_(1999)_20-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Baylis_(1999)-20\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>17<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> it is grammatically correct to say \"one Pokémon\" and \"many Pokémon\", as well as \"one <a href=\"/wiki/Pikachu\" title=\"Pikachu\">Pikachu</a>\" and \"many Pikachu\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-21\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-21\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>18<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading2\"><h2 id=\"General_concept\">General concept</h2></div>\n<link rel=\"mw-deduplicated-inline-style\" href=\"mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320\"><div role=\"note\" class=\"hatnote navigation-not-searchable\">See also: <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_(video_game_series)#Gameplay\" title=\"Pokémon (video game series)\">Pokémon (video game series) §&nbsp;Gameplay</a></div>\n<p>The <i>Pokémon</i> franchise takes place in a <a href=\"/wiki/Shared_universe\" title=\"Shared universe\">shared universe</a> in which humans co-exist with creatures known as Pokémon. <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Red_and_Green\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Pokémon Red and Green\">The original pair of games</a> contain 151 Pokémon species, with new ones being added in subsequent games; as of January 2024, <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_Pok%C3%A9mon\" title=\"List of Pokémon\">1,025 Pokémon species</a> have been introduced.<sup id=\"cite_ref-22\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-22\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>c<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Most Pokémon are based on real-life animals or mythical creatures from folklore.<sup id=\"cite_ref-23\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-23\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>19<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> For example, <a href=\"/wiki/Pikachu\" title=\"Pikachu\">Pikachu</a> are a yellow, mouse-like species with tails shaped as lightning bolts, able to blast powerful electric jolts through the air.<sup id=\"cite_ref-24\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-24\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>20<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-25\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-25\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>21<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-26\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-26\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>22<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a href=\"/wiki/Player_character\" title=\"Player character\">player character</a> takes the role of a Pokémon Trainer. The Trainer has three primary goals: travel and explore the Pokémon world; discover and catch a specimen of each Pokémon species in order to complete their <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9dex\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Pokédex\">Pokédex</a>; and train a team of Pokémon and have them engage in battles. Most Pokémon can be caught with spherical devices known as <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9_Ball\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Poké Ball\">Poké Balls</a>. Once the opposing Pokémon is sufficiently weakened, the Trainer throws the Poké Ball against the Pokémon, which is then transformed into a form of energy and transported into the device. If the catch is successful, the Pokémon is tamed and under the Trainer's command from then on. If the Poké Ball is thrown again, the Pokémon re-materializes into its original state. The Trainer's Pokémon can engage in battles against opposing Pokémon, including those in the wild or owned by other Trainers. Because the franchise is aimed at children, these battles are never presented as overtly violent and contain no blood or gore.<sup id=\"cite_ref-31\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-31\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>II<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Pokémon never die in battle – they <a href=\"/wiki/Syncope_(medicine)\" title=\"Syncope (medicine)\">faint</a> upon being defeated, and can then be rejuvenated at a Pokémon Center.<sup id=\"cite_ref-36\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-36\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>III<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>When a Pokémon wins a battle, it gains <a href=\"/wiki/Experience_point\" title=\"Experience point\">experience points</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-37\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-37\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>31<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> After gaining a certain amount of them, the Pokémon levels up, and its statistics rise. As its level increases, the Pokémon learns new offensive and defensive moves to use in battle.<sup id=\"cite_ref-38\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-38\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>32<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-39\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-39\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>33<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Furthermore, many species can undergo a form of spontaneous metamorphosis called <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_evolution\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Pokémon evolution\">Pokémon evolution</a>, and transform into stronger forms.<sup id=\"cite_ref-40\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-40\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>34<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Most Pokémon will evolve at a certain level, while others evolve through different means, such as exposure to a certain item or trading with another trainer.<sup id=\"cite_ref-41\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-41\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>35<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading2\"><h2 id=\"History\">History</h2></div>\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading3\"><h3 id=\"Origins\">Origins</h3></div>\n<p>The main idea behind <i>Pokémon</i> was conceived by <a href=\"/wiki/Satoshi_Tajiri\" title=\"Satoshi Tajiri\">Satoshi Tajiri</a>. Tajiri was born on 28 August 1965,<sup id=\"cite_ref-42\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-42\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>36<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> and grew up in <a href=\"/wiki/Machida,_Tokyo\" title=\"Machida, Tokyo\">Machida</a>, a suburb of Tokyo.<sup id=\"cite_ref-43\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-43\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>37<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> As a child, he enjoyed discovering and catching insects and other small creatures in the various ponds and fields that surrounded his town.<sup id=\"cite_ref-44\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-44\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>38<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-45\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-45\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>39<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> During <a href=\"/wiki/Japanese_economic_miracle\" title=\"Japanese economic miracle\">Japan's economic miracle</a>, many cities, including Machida, were significantly expanded. <a href=\"/wiki/Human_impact_on_the_environment\" title=\"Human impact on the environment\">As a consequence</a>, Machida's nature was largely destroyed. In his second year of <a href=\"/wiki/Secondary_education_in_Japan#Junior_high_school\" title=\"Secondary education in Japan\">junior high school</a>,<sup id=\"cite_ref-46\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-46\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>40<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-47\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-47\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>41<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> an <a href=\"/wiki/Amusement_arcade\" title=\"Amusement arcade\">arcade hall</a> opened in Tajiri's neighborhood, introducing him to video games. While studying electrical engineering at <a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Tokyo_College_of_Technology&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1\" class=\"new\" title=\"Tokyo College of Technology (page does not exist)\">Tokyo College of Technology</a><span class=\"noprint\" style=\"font-size:85%; font-style: normal;\">&nbsp;[<a href=\"https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E6%9D%B1%E4%BA%AC%E5%B7%A5%E6%A5%AD%E9%AB%98%E7%AD%89%E5%B0%82%E9%96%80%E5%AD%A6%E6%A0%A1\" class=\"extiw\" title=\"ja:東京工業高等専門学校\">ja</a>]</span>, Tajiri began publishing a <i><a href=\"/wiki/Doujinshi\" title=\"Doujinshi\">doujinshi</a></i> magazine titled <i>Game Freak</i>. The title was inspired by the 1932 film <i><a href=\"/wiki/Freaks_(1932_film)\" title=\"Freaks (1932 film)\">Freaks</a></i>, which Tajiri was fascinated with at the time.<sup id=\"cite_ref-48\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-48\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>42<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> He self-published the first issue of the magazine in March 1983, at the age of 17.<sup id=\"cite_ref-AMWC_p55-57_49-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-AMWC_p55-57-49\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>43<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-50\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-50\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>44<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> At the time, magazines specializing in video games did not yet exist in Japan, allowing <i>Game Freak</i> to fill a <a href=\"/wiki/Gap_in_the_market\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Gap in the market\">gap in the market</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-51\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-51\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>45<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-52\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-52\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>46<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Sometime later, Tajiri was contacted by aspiring <a href=\"/wiki/Manga\" title=\"Manga\">manga</a> artist <a href=\"/wiki/Ken_Sugimori\" title=\"Ken Sugimori\">Ken Sugimori</a>, who became <i>Game Freak'</i>s illustrator.<sup id=\"cite_ref-53\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-53\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>47<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <i>Game Freak</i> folded in the late 1980s,<sup id=\"cite_ref-AMWC_p55-57_49-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-AMWC_p55-57-49\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>43<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> by which point Tajiri had become a respected <a href=\"/wiki/Video_game_journalism\" title=\"Video game journalism\">game journalist</a> in Japan's fledgling video game industry.<sup id=\"cite_ref-54\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-54\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>48<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Tajiri's knowledge of video games brought him into contact with <a href=\"/wiki/Tsunekazu_Ishihara\" title=\"Tsunekazu Ishihara\">Tsunekazu Ishihara</a>. Ishihara had studied Arts and Science at <a href=\"/wiki/Tsukuba_University\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Tsukuba University\">Tsukuba University</a>, and was trained in <a href=\"/wiki/Computer-generated_imagery\" title=\"Computer-generated imagery\">CGI</a>. After working in advertising for two years, Ishihara joined a company named Sedic in 1983, which created video graphics and software,<sup id=\"cite_ref-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p82_55-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p82-55\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>49<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> including one video game, <i><a href=\"/wiki/Otocky\" title=\"Otocky\">Otocky</a></i> (1987).<sup id=\"cite_ref-56\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-56\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>50<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-57\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-57\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>51<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> As video games grew in popularity, Sedic also produced a number of game-related television shows for <a href=\"/wiki/Fuji_Television\" title=\"Fuji Television\">Fuji Television</a>'s late-night slot.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p82_55-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p82-55\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>49<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> In his job as a TV producer, Ishihara befriended Tajiri, as well as <a href=\"/wiki/Shigesato_Itoi\" title=\"Shigesato Itoi\">Shigesato Itoi</a>, who would later become CEO of Ape, Inc.<sup id=\"cite_ref-58\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-58\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>52<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Tomisawa_(2000)_p30_59-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Tomisawa_(2000)_p30-59\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>53<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Ishihara was also the general director of the world's first gaming encyclopedia: <i>TV Games: Encyclopedia of Video Games</i><span style=\"font-weight: normal\"> (<span title=\"Japanese-language text\"><span lang=\"ja\">テレビゲーム—電視遊戯大全</span></span>, <span title=\"Hepburn transliteration\"><i lang=\"ja-Latn\">Terebigēmu — Denshi Yūgi Taizen</i></span>)</span>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-60\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-60\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>54<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-61\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-61\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>55<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Journalist Kenji Hatakeyama wrote that, at the time, Ishihara was probably the most well-connected man in the industry.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p97-98_62-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p97-98-62\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>56<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Masakazu_Kubo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1\" class=\"new\" title=\"Masakazu Kubo (page does not exist)\">Masakazu Kubo</a><span class=\"noprint\" style=\"font-size:85%; font-style: normal;\">&nbsp;[<a href=\"https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E4%B9%85%E4%BF%9D%E9%9B%85%E4%B8%80\" class=\"extiw\" title=\"ja:久保雅一\">ja</a>]</span>, who would later play a vital role in <i>Pokemon</i>, wrote that Ishihara possessed a knowledge of games that was \"beyond comparison\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-63\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-63\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>57<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Ishihara was also interested in <a href=\"/wiki/Playing_card\" title=\"Playing card\">playing cards</a>,<sup id=\"cite_ref-Kawaguchi_interview_64-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Kawaguchi_interview-64\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>58<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Masuda_2019_interview_65-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Masuda_2019_interview-65\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>59<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> and contributed to the development of at least three simple <a href=\"/wiki/Card_game\" title=\"Card game\">card games</a> designed by Itoi and published by Ape.<sup id=\"cite_ref-cardgames_72-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-cardgames-72\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>d<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>In 1986, Tajiri, Sugimori, and a few other enthusiasts started an informal development team called Game Freak, named after the magazine it grew out of. Over the next few years, they <a href=\"/wiki/Indie_game\" title=\"Indie game\">independently developed</a> the puzzle game <i><a href=\"/wiki/Mendel_Palace\" title=\"Mendel Palace\">Quinty</a></i>, working on it alongside school or their regular jobs.<sup id=\"cite_ref-73\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-73\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>66<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> However, no one within the group knew how to make the <a href=\"/wiki/Video_game_music\" title=\"Video game music\">game's music</a>. After consulting all his contacts, Tajiri got in touch with <a href=\"/wiki/Junichi_Masuda\" title=\"Junichi Masuda\">Junichi Masuda</a>, who became the group's composer.<sup id=\"cite_ref-74\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-74\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>67<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <i>Quinty</i> was finished in 1989, and published by <a href=\"/wiki/Namco\" title=\"Namco\">Namco</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-75\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-75\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>68<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Tajiri officially incorporated <a href=\"/wiki/Game_Freak\" title=\"Game Freak\">Game Freak Co., Ltd.</a> on 26 April 1989.<sup id=\"cite_ref-76\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-76\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>69<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading3\"><h3 id=\"1989–1995:_Development_of_Red_and_Green\"><span id=\"1989.E2.80.931995:_Development_of_Red_and_Green\"></span>1989–1995: Development of <i>Red</i> and <i>Green</i></h3></div>\n<link rel=\"mw-deduplicated-inline-style\" href=\"mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320\"><div role=\"note\" class=\"hatnote navigation-not-searchable\">Further information: <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Red_and_Blue#Development\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Pokémon Red and Blue\">Pokémon Red and Blue §&nbsp;Development</a></div>\n<figure class=\"mw-default-size\" typeof=\"mw:File/Thumb\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Duo_gameboy.JPG\" class=\"mw-file-description\"><img src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Duo_gameboy.JPG/250px-Duo_gameboy.JPG\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"250\" height=\"166\" class=\"mw-file-element\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Duo_gameboy.JPG/500px-Duo_gameboy.JPG 1.5x\" data-file-width=\"3008\" data-file-height=\"2000\"></a><figcaption>Two original <a href=\"/wiki/Game_Boy\" title=\"Game Boy\">Game Boys</a> connected with a <a href=\"/wiki/Game_Link_Cable\" title=\"Game Link Cable\">Game Link Cable</a></figcaption></figure>\n<p>Tajiri started to think of what was to become <i>Pokémon</i> while completing <i>Quinty</i>, and before he officially founded Game Freak. Around this time, <a href=\"/wiki/Nintendo\" title=\"Nintendo\">Nintendo</a> announced the upcoming release of the <a href=\"/wiki/Game_Boy\" title=\"Game Boy\">Game Boy</a>, a handheld console that would revolutionize the gaming industry. Tajiri learned that the device would have a <a href=\"/wiki/Computer_port_(hardware)\" title=\"Computer port (hardware)\">link port</a>, and with the corresponding <a href=\"/wiki/Game_Link_Cable\" title=\"Game Link Cable\">Game Link Cable</a>, two Game Boys could be linked together.<sup id=\"cite_ref-77\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-77\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>70<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Sometime later, Tajiri remembered an incident while playing <i><a href=\"/wiki/Dragon_Quest_II\" title=\"Dragon Quest II\">Dragon Quest II</a></i> (1987), a <a href=\"/wiki/Role-playing_game\" title=\"Role-playing game\">role-playing game</a> (RPG) for the Famicom (<a href=\"/wiki/NES\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"NES\">NES</a>). The game features randomly appearing items of varying rarity, including an extremely rare item called Mysterious Hat.<sup id=\"cite_ref-78\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-78\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>e<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Tajiri did not encounter any, while Ken Sugimori, who was also playing the game, encountered two. Upon recalling this experience, Tajiri realized that the cable now made it possible to transfer things from one cartridge to another.<sup id=\"cite_ref-83\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-83\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>IV<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> He noted that, until then, the Game Link Cable was only used for competing, but not for something else.<sup id=\"cite_ref-84\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-84\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>75<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Combining this inspiration with his memories of catching insects and other small species, Tajiri's idea would eventually evolve into a virtual recreation of his boyhood experiences,<sup id=\"cite_ref-85\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-85\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>76<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> and an attempt to \"regain the world that he had lost\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-86\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-86\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>77<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> He would later state that the game represents \"the story of a boy's summer day\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-87\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-87\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>78<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<figure class=\"mw-default-size\" typeof=\"mw:File/Thumb\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Gachapon.jpg\" class=\"mw-file-description\"><img src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Gachapon.jpg/250px-Gachapon.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"250\" height=\"167\" class=\"mw-file-element\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Gachapon.jpg/500px-Gachapon.jpg 1.5x\" data-file-width=\"3872\" data-file-height=\"2592\"></a><figcaption><i><a href=\"/wiki/Gashapon\" title=\"Gashapon\">Gashapon</a></i> capsules have been cited as an inspiration for <i>Pokemon</i>.</figcaption></figure>\n<p>Tajiri and his Game Freak staff began pondering over a game centered on capturing creatures of differing rarity. Since the Game Boy is a portable device, these creatures could then be exchanged with other players in real life using the link cable. Once the player has caught a creature in-game, it was to be stored in miniaturized form in a special capsule. This facet of the game was inspired by <i><a href=\"/wiki/Ultraseven\" title=\"Ultraseven\">Ultraseven</a></i>, a <i><a href=\"/wiki/Tokusatsu\" title=\"Tokusatsu\">tokusatsu</a></i> show that Tajiri had enjoyed as a child.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Tajiri_Time_interview_88-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Tajiri_Time_interview-88\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>79<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/Ultraseven_(character)\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Ultraseven (character)\">The series' titular character</a> owns a number of capsules containing miniaturized <i><a href=\"/wiki/Kaiju\" title=\"Kaiju\">kaiju</a></i> (monsters), which come out and return to their original sizes when the capsule is thrown into mid-air. <i>Kaiju</i> media in general were an important influence on <i>Pokemon</i>, as many Game Freak staff members had grown up with them.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Encylo_p140_80-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Encylo_p140-80\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>72<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-89\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-89\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>80<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Other influences that have been cited by Tajiri include: <i><a href=\"/wiki/Gashapon\" title=\"Gashapon\">gashapon</a></i>, capsules with toy figures in them that can be drawn from vending machines;<sup id=\"cite_ref-90\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-90\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>81<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-91\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-91\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>82<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/Collectible_card\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Collectible card\">collectible cards</a>, such as <a href=\"/wiki/Baseball_card\" title=\"Baseball card\">baseball cards</a>, <i><a href=\"/wiki/Ultraman\" title=\"Ultraman\">Ultraman</a></i> cards and <i><a href=\"/wiki/Menko\" title=\"Menko\">menko</a></i>;<sup id=\"cite_ref-96\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-96\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>V<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <i><a href=\"/wiki/The_Final_Fantasy_Legend\" title=\"The Final Fantasy Legend\">The Final Fantasy Legend</a></i> (1989), the first RPG for the Game Boy;<sup id=\"cite_ref-taidan1_page02_97-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-taidan1_page02-97\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>87<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> and <a href=\"/wiki/Pet_culture_in_Japan\" title=\"Pet culture in Japan\">petting in Japan</a>, with Tajiri noting that having Pokemon is similar to having pets.<sup id=\"cite_ref-98\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-98\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>88<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Tajiri initially named his project <i>Capsule Monsters</i>, which GF's staff <a href=\"/wiki/Japanese_abbreviated_and_contracted_words\" title=\"Japanese abbreviated and contracted words\">commonly shortened</a> to <i>Capumon</i>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Tomisawa_(2000)_p65-66_99-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Tomisawa_(2000)_p65-66-99\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>89<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> However, it later turned out that the term <i>Capsule Monsters</i> could not be trademarked, and it was subsequently decided to call the game <i>Pocket Monsters</i>, which became <i>Pokemon</i>. Former GF staff member Akihito Tomisawa wrote that the phrase \"Capsule Monsters\" was already registered.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Tomisawa_(2000)_p65-66_99-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Tomisawa_(2000)_p65-66-99\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>89<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> According to journalist Kenji Hatakeyama, the word \"capsule\" could not be used in the trademark.<sup id=\"cite_ref-100\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-100\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>90<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Tomisawa wrote that the Game Freak staff then came up with several alternatives, before someone within the team suggested \"Pocket Monsters\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-Tomisawa_(2000)_p65-66_99-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Tomisawa_(2000)_p65-66-99\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>89<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>In March 1989, Nintendo co-founded Ape, Inc. with Itoi. Ape's principal work was <i><a href=\"/wiki/Mother_(video_game)\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Mother (video game)\">Mother</a></i> (1989), a role-playing game written by Itoi, but it was also founded with the intent to give outside talent a chance to pitch new, innovative games.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Tomisawa_(2000)_p30_59-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Tomisawa_(2000)_p30-59\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>53<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Kawaguchi_interview_64-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Kawaguchi_interview-64\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>58<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> At the time, Ape was housed in the same <a href=\"/wiki/Kanda-Sudach%C5%8D\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Kanda-Sudachō\">Kanda-Sudachō</a> office building as Nintendo, located in Tokyo.<sup id=\"cite_ref-101\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-101\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>91<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Ishihara, a friend of both Itoi and Tajiri, was involved with Ape's management (and would become its vice-president in 1991).<sup id=\"cite_ref-Tomisawa_(2000)_p30_59-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Tomisawa_(2000)_p30-59\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>53<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p97-98_62-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p97-98-62\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>56<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Tajiri's relationship with Ishihara prompted Tajiri to present his idea for <i>Pocket Monsters</i> at Ape's office.<sup id=\"cite_ref-taidan2_page01_102-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-taidan2_page01-102\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>92<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-103\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-103\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>93<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Present during Tajiri's pitch was Takashi Kawaguchi, who worked at Nintendo's General Affairs Department and was also a manager at Ape.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Kawaguchi_interview_64-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Kawaguchi_interview-64\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>58<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-104\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-104\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>94<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Kawaguchi brought the idea to Nintendo president <a href=\"/wiki/Hiroshi_Yamauchi\" title=\"Hiroshi Yamauchi\">Hiroshi Yamauchi</a>, who reportedly said: \"This is it. This is the idea I've been waiting for.\"<sup id=\"cite_ref-105\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-105\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>95<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> By pure coincidence, Ishihara had come up with an idea for a game similar to that of Tajiri, and around the same time was discussing it with Ape. This game, <i>Toto</i>, involved \"using the Game Boy as an insect cage\". Ishihara emphasized, however, that the idea of trading creatures with the link cable was Tajiri's. GF and Ape agreed to merge their projects together.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Tomisawa_(2000)_p31-32_106-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Tomisawa_(2000)_p31-32-106\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>96<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> According to Tajiri, the two teams initially collaborated on the game, but the work proved difficult, one of the reasons being that Ape was busy developing <i><a href=\"/wiki/EarthBound\" title=\"EarthBound\">EarthBound</a></i>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Miya_Tajiri_(2004)_p104_107-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Miya_Tajiri_(2004)_p104-107\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>97<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-108\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-108\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>98<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Tajiri eventually figured that \"rather than working with Ape, we had to do something on our own, or the project would never get finished\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-Miya_Tajiri_(2004)_p104_107-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Miya_Tajiri_(2004)_p104-107\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>97<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Ape, Inc. is not credited on the final product.\n</p><p>The development contract was signed at the beginning of 1990, with a planned delivery of the game in October.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Tomisawa_(2000)_p32-33_109-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Tomisawa_(2000)_p32-33-109\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>99<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Tajiri directed the project, working under Ishihara.<sup id=\"cite_ref-110\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-110\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>100<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Ishihara was the producer – he managed the budget, staff, and work schedule, monitored the game's overall progress, and served as a liaison between Game Freak and Nintendo.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Tomisawa_(2000)_p31-32_106-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Tomisawa_(2000)_p31-32-106\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>96<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-111\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-111\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>101<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Ishihara also contributed ideas to the development,<sup id=\"cite_ref-Masuda_2019_interview_65-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Masuda_2019_interview-65\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>59<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> and helped with <a href=\"/wiki/Debugging\" title=\"Debugging\">debugging</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-112\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-112\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>102<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-113\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-113\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>103<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Sugimori was in charge of the graphics and character design.<sup id=\"cite_ref-114\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-114\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>104<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Masuda created all music and sound effects, and did part of the programming.<sup id=\"cite_ref-115\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-115\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>105<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The budget that Nintendo granted to Game Freak was low;<sup id=\"cite_ref-Tomisawa_(2000)_p32-33_109-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Tomisawa_(2000)_p32-33-109\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>99<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> thus, <i>Pocket Monsters</i> was initially planned as a small, compact game, based primarily around Tajiri's core idea of exchanging.<sup id=\"cite_ref-taidan1_page02_97-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-taidan1_page02-97\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>87<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-116\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-116\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>106<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> However, as development progressed, GF's ideas and ambitions for <i>Pokemon</i> grew.<sup id=\"cite_ref-taidan1_page02_97-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-taidan1_page02-97\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>87<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> They soon realized that the game they were beginning to envision would not be easy to make. Sugimori admitted that, at the time, no one at GF had much knowledge of RPGs. \"We thought we could handle it, but as we began working, we realized it was going to be tough\", he acknowledged.<sup id=\"cite_ref-117\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-117\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>107<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <i>Pocket Monsters</i> was suspended indefinitely, and GF turned their focus on other titles (see <a href=\"/wiki/Game_Freak#Games\" title=\"Game Freak\">Game Freak §&nbsp;Games</a>).\n</p><p>After the game's initial development phase in 1990 and 1991,<sup id=\"cite_ref-118\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-118\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>108<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> the staff \"tinkered with it from time to time\", as Sugimori put it.<sup id=\"cite_ref-119\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-119\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>109<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> For instance, by October 1992, a large number of Pokemon had been designed, and a poll was held that month among all staff members to gauge the popularity of the different species. Several more such votes followed to determine collectively which Pokemon should be included.<sup id=\"cite_ref-120\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-120\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>110<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Still, development had mostly come to a halt until the summer of 1994, after the release of the platform game <i><a href=\"/wiki/Pulseman\" title=\"Pulseman\">Pulseman</a></i>, upon which Tajiri decided it was time to make a serious effort towards finishing <i>Pocket Monsters</i>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-121\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-121\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>111<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> By this point, Game Freak's experience had grown considerably. Over the years, a number of new staff members had been added to the company. One of them was <a href=\"/wiki/Atsuko_Nishida\" title=\"Atsuko Nishida\">Atsuko Nishida</a>, a graphic artist who created <a href=\"/wiki/Pikachu\" title=\"Pikachu\">Pikachu</a>, among others.<sup id=\"cite_ref-122\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-122\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>112<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-123\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-123\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>113<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-124\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-124\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>114<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Ishihara used his knowledge of card games to add more depth to the battle system, and among other things suggested Pokemon types. Ishihara also came up with the idea of the Pokedex, a portable encyclopedic device which players can use to keep track of the Pokemon they caught.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Masuda_2019_interview_65-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Masuda_2019_interview-65\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>59<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Throughout the years, Tajiri had several conversations with <a href=\"/wiki/Shigeru_Miyamoto\" title=\"Shigeru Miyamoto\">Shigeru Miyamoto</a>,<sup id=\"cite_ref-125\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-125\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>115<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Nintendo's top game designer who Tajiri described as a mentor figure.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Tajiri_Time_interview_88-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Tajiri_Time_interview-88\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>79<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Although, in a 2018 retrospect, Miyamoto downplayed his role in advising Tajiri, and stated that his contributions to <i>Pokemon</i> were in fact limited.<sup id=\"cite_ref-126\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-126\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>116<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Miyamoto did, however, suggest the use of different colored cartridges for the game, in response to Tajiri's and Ishihara's musings about making each playthrough slightly different, as to 'individualize' the player's experience.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p152-154_127-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p152-154-127\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>117<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> According to Tajiri, \"five or seven colors\" were considered,<sup id=\"cite_ref-128\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-128\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>118<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> but they eventually settled on two versions of the game: a <i>Red</i> version and a <i>Green</i> version. Otherwise identical, each had Pokemon not found in the other, encouraging players to socialize and trade to complete their collection.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p152-154_127-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p152-154-127\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>117<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Ishihara aspired to create video games of his own.<sup id=\"cite_ref-129\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-129\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>119<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> As <i>Pocket Monsters Red</i> and <i>Green</i> were nearing completion, Ishihara founded <a href=\"/wiki/Creatures,_Inc.\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Creatures, Inc.\">Creatures, Inc.</a> on 8 November 1995. Upon founding, the company was housed in the same office building as Nintendo in Tokyo.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Creatures_profile_130-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Creatures_profile-130\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>120<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Co-ownership of the <i>Pokemon</i> property, which Ishihara helped create, was subsequently assigned to Creatures. This resulted in <i>Pokemon</i> having three legal owners: Game Freak, the main developer; Creatures, representing producer Ishihara; and Nintendo, the publisher. <a href=\"/wiki/Anne_Allison\" title=\"Anne Allison\">Anne Allison</a> wrote that Nintendo also bought the property after <i>Red</i> and <i>Green</i> were finished.<sup id=\"cite_ref-131\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-131\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>121<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Kenji Hatakeyama noted that the ownership structure of <i>Pokemon</i> is uncommon.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p474-475_15-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p474-475-15\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>12<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> He wrote that \"Pokemon is probably the only property in the world today for which the original rights are not concentrated in a single company\", like <a href=\"/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Company\" title=\"The Walt Disney Company\">The Walt Disney Company</a> does with their <a href=\"/wiki/Intellectual_property\" title=\"Intellectual property\">IPs</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-132\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-132\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>122<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Tajiri and Ishihara did consider merging Game Freak and Creatures at one point. However, Tajiri decided against it because he feared it would erase what he had built up since he was a teenager. \"I felt threatened by the idea of changing how Game Freak was operating, and starting back over with Mr. Ishihara\", he said. \"It was an identity problem. If Game Freak ceased to exist, then so would I\". Tajiri noted that, since Game Freak and Creatures both focus on <i>Pokemon</i>, it sometimes felt more like different departments than different companies.<sup id=\"cite_ref-taidan2_page01_102-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-taidan2_page01-102\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>92<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p><i>Pocket Monsters Red</i> and <i>Green</i> were finally finished in December 1995.<sup id=\"cite_ref-133\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-133\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>123<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> A release date of 21 December that year was announced,<sup id=\"cite_ref-134\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-134\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>124<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> but missed. After sufficient cartridges, manuals and packages had been manufactured, the pair of games ended up being published on 27 February 1996. However, the property was copyrighted in 1995, and \"©1995\" is shown on the title screens<sup id=\"cite_ref-135\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-135\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>125<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> and cartridges.<sup id=\"cite_ref-136\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-136\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>126<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> This year is since used on the <a href=\"/wiki/Copyright_notice\" title=\"Copyright notice\">copyright notice</a><sup id=\"cite_ref-Legal_2-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Legal-2\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>2<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> seen on many <i>Pokemon</i> products, even though no actual <i>Pokemon</i> product was released in 1995.<sup id=\"cite_ref-137\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-137\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>127<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading3\"><h3 id=\"1996–1998:_Rise_in_Japan\"><span id=\"1996.E2.80.931998:_Rise_in_Japan\"></span>1996–1998: Rise in Japan</h3></div>\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading4\"><h4 id=\"Release_of_Red_and_Green\">Release of <i>Red</i> and <i>Green</i></h4></div>\n<p>Nintendo had no high expectations of <i>Pocket Monsters Red</i> and <i>Green</i>, and media largely ignored the game(s).<sup id=\"cite_ref-138\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-138\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>128<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/1996_in_video_games\" title=\"1996 in video games\">By 1996</a>, the seven-year-old <a href=\"/wiki/Game_Boy\" title=\"Game Boy\">Game Boy</a> console was considered yesterday's news and near the <a href=\"/wiki/End-of-life_product\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"End-of-life product\">end of its lifecycle</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Chua-Eoan_Larimer_(1999)_32-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Chua-Eoan_Larimer_(1999)-32\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>27<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-139\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-139\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>129<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-140\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-140\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>130<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> On the other hand, new Game Boys continued to be manufactured and sold.<sup id=\"cite_ref-141\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-141\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>131<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The console was widespread and, due to its age, affordable to children.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Chua-Eoan_Larimer_(1999)_32-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Chua-Eoan_Larimer_(1999)-32\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>27<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-142\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-142\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>132<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Also, the Game Boy had experienced a small revival in Japan in 1995 due to the success of <i><a href=\"/wiki/Mario%27s_Picross\" title=\"Mario's Picross\">Mario's Picross</a></i>. Coincidentally, this game was directed by Ishihara, and co-developed by Ape. The popularity of <i>Mario's Picross</i> incited Nintendo to develop the <a href=\"/wiki/Game_Boy_Pocket\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Game Boy Pocket\">Game Boy Pocket</a>,<sup id=\"cite_ref-143\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-143\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>133<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> a slimmer and improved version of the Game Boy, released in Japan on 21 July 1996.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Sato_(1998)_p118_144-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Sato_(1998)_p118-144\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>134<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Because of the timing and naming, some were under the impression that the Game Boy <i>Pocket</i> was made to promote <i>Pocket Monsters</i>, but this was in fact a coincidence that would end up benefiting both.<sup id=\"cite_ref-145\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-145\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>135<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading4\"><h4 id=\"CoroCoro_manga,_Mew_lottery\"><span id=\"CoroCoro_manga.2C_Mew_lottery\"></span><i>CoroCoro</i> manga, Mew lottery</h4></div>\n<p>Two media channels that would play important roles in the <i>Pokemon</i> franchise were the <i><a href=\"/wiki/CoroCoro_Comic\" title=\"CoroCoro Comic\">CoroCoro Comic</a></i>, released monthly, and its sister magazine <i>Bessatsu CoroCoro Comic</i>, released bi-monthly. Both <a href=\"/wiki/Manga\" title=\"Manga\">manga</a> magazines are published by <a href=\"/wiki/Shogakukan\" title=\"Shogakukan\">Shogakukan</a>, a long-time business partner of Nintendo, and have featured manga based on Nintendo properties (e.g. <i><a href=\"/wiki/Super_Mario-kun\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Super Mario-kun\">Super Mario-kun</a></i>, <i><a href=\"/wiki/Kirby_of_the_Stars:_The_Story_of_Dedede_Who_Lives_in_Pupupu\" title=\"Kirby of the Stars: The Story of Dedede Who Lives in Pupupu\">Kirby of the Stars</a></i>, <i>Donkey Kong</i>). At the time of <i>Pokemon</i><span class=\"nowrap\" style=\"padding-left:0.1em;\">'</span>s release, the main <i>CoroCoro</i> magazine was read by one in four elementary school students.<sup id=\"cite_ref-146\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-146\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>136<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <i>CoroCoro'</i>s deputy editor-in-chief was <a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Masakazu_Kubo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1\" class=\"new\" title=\"Masakazu Kubo (page does not exist)\">Masakazu Kubo</a><span class=\"noprint\" style=\"font-size:85%; font-style: normal;\">&nbsp;[<a href=\"https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E4%B9%85%E4%BF%9D%E9%9B%85%E4%B8%80\" class=\"extiw\" title=\"ja:久保雅一\">ja</a>]</span>. On Ishihara's suggestion,<sup id=\"cite_ref-147\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-147\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>137<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Kubo commissioned the creation of <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Pocket_Monsters\" title=\"Pokémon Pocket Monsters\">a manga adaptation</a>. Written and illustrated by <a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Kosaku_Anakubo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1\" class=\"new\" title=\"Kosaku Anakubo (page does not exist)\">Kosaku Anakubo</a><span class=\"noprint\" style=\"font-size:85%; font-style: normal;\">&nbsp;[<a href=\"https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E7%A9%B4%E4%B9%85%E4%BF%9D%E5%B9%B8%E4%BD%9C\" class=\"extiw\" title=\"ja:穴久保幸作\">ja</a>]</span>, its first chapter was featured in the March/April issue of <i>Bessatsu CoroCoro Comic</i>, released on 28 February 1996, the day after <i>Red</i> and <i>Green</i><span class=\"nowrap\" style=\"padding-left:0.1em;\">'</span>s release.<sup id=\"cite_ref-148\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-148\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>138<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Shogakukan, which frequently surveys their target groups, determined that the <i>Pocket Monsters</i> manga was well received.<sup id=\"cite_ref-149\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-149\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>139<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>To further promote <i>Red</i> and <i>Green</i>, the May issue of <i>CoroCoro</i>, released on 15 April 1996, announced the \"Legendary Pokemon Offer\", centered around a mysterious, secret Pokemon called <a href=\"/wiki/Mew_(Pok%C3%A9mon)\" title=\"Mew (Pokémon)\">Mew</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-150\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-150\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>140<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-CoroCoro_May_96_151-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-CoroCoro_May_96-151\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>141<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Mew was a last-minute addition to <i>Red &amp; Green</i>. It is unobtainable in the game(s) through usual means, and was intended to be used at a later point in some post-launch activity.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Iwata_Asks_1_152-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Iwata_Asks_1-152\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>142<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> To participate in the promotion, <i>CoroCoro</i> readers had to send in a postcard, and from the entrants, 20 were selected at random. The winners then had to send in their cartridge so that Mew could be uploaded onto it. The lottery was a success and increased <a href=\"/wiki/Word-of-mouth_marketing\" title=\"Word-of-mouth marketing\">word-of-mouth</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Chua-Eoan_Larimer_(1999)_32-3\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Chua-Eoan_Larimer_(1999)-32\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>27<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Iwata_Asks_1_152-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Iwata_Asks_1-152\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>142<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> By September, sales of <i>Red</i> and <i>Green</i> had surpassed 1 million units.<sup id=\"cite_ref-153\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-153\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>143<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading4\"><h4 id=\"Pokemon_Blue\"><i>Pokemon Blue</i></h4></div>\n<p>Even after the release of <i>Pokemon Red</i> and <i>Green</i>, Game Freak continued testing their game(s) for the purpose of <a href=\"/wiki/Debugging\" title=\"Debugging\">bug fixing</a><sup id=\"cite_ref-bugfixing_155-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-bugfixing-155\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>f<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> and training new staff members. Trainees were also tasked with creating new <a href=\"/wiki/Sprite_(computer_graphics)\" title=\"Sprite (computer graphics)\">sprites</a> for the game. The resulting new version was dubbed <i><a href=\"/wiki/Pokemon_Blue\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Pokemon Blue\">Pokemon Blue</a></i>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-156\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-156\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>145<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> It was originally not meant to be sold. Only a small number of handmade copies were made, intended as a special gift to \"20 to 100 people\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-157\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-157\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>146<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> After Kubo learned of it, he encouraged Tajiri and Ishihara to allow an official release of <i>Blue</i>. President <a href=\"/wiki/Hiroshi_Yamauchi\" title=\"Hiroshi Yamauchi\">Hiroshi Yamauchi</a> initially rejected this, fearing it would confuse people into believing it was an entirely new <i>Pokemon</i> game. Kawaguchi then suggested an alternative, which Yamauchi agreed with: <i>Blue</i> would not receive a normal retail release, but would instead be made available only through mail order for a limited time as a special offer.<sup id=\"cite_ref-158\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-158\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>147<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> It was announced in the November issue of <i>CoroCoro</i>, which explicitly stated that <i>Blue</i> was not a new game, but rather a special, limited edition to celebrate 1 million sales of <i>Red</i> and <i>Green</i>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-CoroCoro_May_96_151-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-CoroCoro_May_96-151\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>141<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The offer was a surprisingly big success: 300,000 units were expected to be sold, but more than double that amount was ordered.<sup id=\"cite_ref-159\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-159\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>148<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-160\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-160\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>149<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading4\"><h4 id=\"Trading_Card_Game\">Trading Card Game</h4></div>\n<p>The <i><a href=\"/wiki/Pokemon_Trading_Card_Game\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Pokemon Trading Card Game\">Pokemon Trading Card Game</a></i> was one of the first <a href=\"/wiki/Collectible_card_game\" title=\"Collectible card game\">collectible card games</a> (CCGs) developed in Japan. Its creation was influenced by <i><a href=\"/wiki/Magic:_The_Gathering\" title=\"Magic: The Gathering\">Magic: The Gathering</a></i>, the first CCG in history.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p153_161-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p153-161\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>150<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Pokemon_Business_Study_Group_(1998)_p112-117_162-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Pokemon_Business_Study_Group_(1998)_p112-117-162\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>151<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Kimura_2006_163-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Kimura_2006-163\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>152<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Indeed, the <i>Pokemon Trading Card Game</i> can be considered a simplified version of <i>Magic</i>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-164\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-164\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>153<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-165\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-165\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>154<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> First released in the United States in 1993, <i>Magic</i> had gained popularity not just in North America and Europe, but also in Asia.<sup id=\"cite_ref-166\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-166\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>155<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Ishihara was fond of <a href=\"/wiki/Playing_card\" title=\"Playing card\">playing cards</a>,<sup id=\"cite_ref-Masuda_2019_interview_65-3\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Masuda_2019_interview-65\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>59<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> and had contributed to the development of at least three simple card games designed by <a href=\"/wiki/Shigesato_Itoi\" title=\"Shigesato Itoi\">Shigesato Itoi</a> and released through Ape, Inc.<sup id=\"cite_ref-cardgames_72-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-cardgames-72\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>d<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> At the time, Ishihara was particularly interested in <i>Magic: The Gathering</i>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p153_161-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p153-161\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>150<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> While developing the <i>Pokemon</i> RPG, he realized that the concept behind it could be adapted into a <i>Magic</i>-like CCG.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Kawaguchi_interview_64-3\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Kawaguchi_interview-64\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>58<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The <i>Pokemon Trading Card Game</i> was designed by Ishihara,<sup id=\"cite_ref-167\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-167\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>156<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Akihiko Miura, Kōichi Ōyama, and Takumi Akabane.<sup id=\"cite_ref-168\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-168\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>157<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> All were former staff members of Ape and had previously worked on <i><a href=\"/wiki/EarthBound\" title=\"EarthBound\">EarthBound</a></i> (1994): Miura was the game's main designer, Ōyama was its art director, and Akabane was one of its chief debuggers.<sup id=\"cite_ref-169\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-169\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>158<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>While card games <a href=\"/wiki/Karuta\" title=\"Karuta\">have a long history in Japan</a>, a collectible card game was a relatively new concept there, and at the time not widely known.<sup id=\"cite_ref-170\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-170\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>159<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Because of this, Ishihara had difficulties finding distributors. Sometime in 1995, Ishihara pitched the card game to Nintendo. They agreed to have the cards manufactured, subcontracting an unidentified printing company. However, Nintendo did not want the hassle of having to develop a distribution system from the ground up, i.e. finding retailers willing to sell a CCG.<sup id=\"cite_ref-171\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-171\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>160<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Ishihara was then contacted by Satoshi Kayama, director of a small firm called <a href=\"/wiki/Media_Factory\" title=\"Media Factory\">Media Factory</a>. Like Ishihara, Kayama was a fan of card games. He felt that CCGs would soon rise to prominence in Japan, and had been gathering information on the possibility of developing such a game in some form. When Kayama heard that Creatures had developed a CCG, he contacted Ishihara and offered to distribute it, signing the contract near the end of 1995.<sup id=\"cite_ref-172\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-172\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>161<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p><i>CoroCoro</i> again proved a valuable information channel. The <i>Trading Card Game</i> was first announced in the November issue, the same one that announced <i>Pokemon Blue</i>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-173\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-173\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>162<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The issue came bundled with two promo cards: one of Purin (<a href=\"/wiki/Jigglypuff\" title=\"Jigglypuff\">Jigglypuff</a>) and one of <a href=\"/wiki/Pikachu\" title=\"Pikachu\">Pikachu</a>. Surveys showed that they were respectively the most and second-most popular Pokemon at the time.<sup id=\"cite_ref-174\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-174\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>163<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> On 20 October 1996, the first card set was released.<sup id=\"cite_ref-175\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-175\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>164<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/Booster_pack\" title=\"Booster pack\">Booster packs</a> were launched the same day, containing 10 randomly inserted cards.<sup id=\"cite_ref-176\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-176\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>165<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> In the West, the booster packs would contain 11 cards.<sup id=\"cite_ref-boosters_177-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-boosters-177\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>g<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The original set would be titled the <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_Pok%C3%A9mon_Trading_Card_Game_sets#Pokémon_Base_Set\" title=\"List of Pokémon Trading Card Game sets\">Base Set</a> in English. Many more sets would follow. Despite being ignored by the media, except for <i>CoroCoro</i>,<sup id=\"cite_ref-178\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-178\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>166<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> the cards became an instant success upon release. 87 million <i>Pokemon</i> cards were shipped by the end of March 1997, six months after its launch, and one month before the debut of the next big installment of the franchise: the <i>Pokemon</i> anime. The success of the TV series would cause the cards' sales figure to explode: by March 1998, a total of 499 million cards had been produced in Japan.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p246-247_179-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p246-247-179\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>167<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading4\"><h4 id=\"Anime_production_and_premiere\">Anime production and premiere</h4></div>\n<p>By August 1996, Kubo had become convinced of <i>Pokemon</i><span class=\"nowrap\" style=\"padding-left:0.1em;\">'</span>s potential, and believed Shogakukan should create <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_(TV_series)\" title=\"Pokémon (TV series)\">an anime adaptation</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-180\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-180\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>168<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Nintendo felt reluctant, believing that the property had developed enough as it had over the course of six months. At that time, they did not consider such a significant expansion to be necessary.<sup id=\"cite_ref-181\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-181\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>169<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Nintendo also noted that if the anime would flop, it would negatively affect future <i>Pokemon</i> games.<sup id=\"cite_ref-182\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-182\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>170<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Ishihara initially opposed the idea, because he thought it would overly hasten the 'consumption' of the property: he feared that if the series would end, people would assume that <i>Pokemon</i> has ended, and move on to the next thing.<sup id=\"cite_ref-183\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-183\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>171<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> At the time, Creatures and Game Freak were planning the sequel(s) to <i>Red</i> and <i>Green</i>, <a href=\"/wiki/Pokemon_Gold_and_Silver\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Pokemon Gold and Silver\"><i>Pokemon Gold</i> and <i>Silver</i></a>, and Ishihara did not want the anime to end before they could release their new games.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Iwata_Asks_2_184-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Iwata_Asks_2-184\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>172<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-185\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-185\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>173<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Kubo was ultimately able to resolve the concerns of all parties involved. An important aspect of Kubo's bargaining power was the then-ongoing <a href=\"/wiki/Mini_4WD\" title=\"Mini 4WD\">Mini 4WD</a> craze and its accompanying hit series <i><a href=\"/wiki/Bakus%C5%8D_Ky%C5%8Ddai_Let%27s_%26_Go!!\" title=\"Bakusō Kyōdai Let's &amp; Go!!\">Bakusō Kyōdai Let's &amp; Go!!</a></i>. Kubo had an important role in the creation of both, which impressed the stakeholders.<sup id=\"cite_ref-186\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-186\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>174<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> To appease Ishihara, Kubo promised him that the anime would last for at least a year and a half.
