This was unusually long for a debuting anime, and required a big investment.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Iwata_Asks_2_184-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Iwata_Asks_2-184\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>172<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-187\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-187\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>175<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Kubo's proposal for <i>Pocket Monsters</i> was officially approved on 26 September 1996.<sup id=\"cite_ref-188\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-188\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>176<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> For Nintendo of Japan, it was the first time they licensed a TV series.<sup id=\"cite_ref-189\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-189\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>177<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Kubo assigned independent producer <a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Choji_Yoshikawa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1\" class=\"new\" title=\"Choji Yoshikawa (page does not exist)\">Choji Yoshikawa</a><span class=\"noprint\" style=\"font-size:85%; font-style: normal;\">&nbsp;[<a href=\"https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E5%90%89%E5%B7%9D%E5%85%86%E4%BA%8C\" class=\"extiw\" title=\"ja:吉川兆二\">ja</a>]</span> to lead the project.<sup id=\"cite_ref-190\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-190\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>178<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/Shogakukan_Productions\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Shogakukan Productions\">Shogakukan Productions</a>, commonly called ShoPro, was Shogakukan's production company. The animation company they commissioned was <a href=\"/wiki/OLM,_Inc.\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"OLM, Inc.\">OLM, Inc.</a> (Oriental Light and Magic), on Kubo's suggestion.<sup id=\"cite_ref-191\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-191\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>179<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/Kunihiko_Yuyama\" title=\"Kunihiko Yuyama\">Kunihiko Yuyama</a>, one of OLM's founding members, became the anime's director. ShoPro assembled a team of five writers, plus two supporting writers.<sup id=\"cite_ref-192\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-192\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>180<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> All key people involved with the production of <i>Pokemon</i> were well-experienced and had proven track records within Japan's anime industry. Yoshikawa felt that the team got lucky. \"The probability of so many great people coming together at the same time is very low\", he said.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p340_193-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p340-193\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>181<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Per Tajiri's explicit condition,<sup id=\"cite_ref-194\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-194\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>182<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> every anime team member had to play the game extensively, including the illustrators and voice actors.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p340_193-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p340-193\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>181<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The anime staff \"unanimously agreed that the game was interesting\"<sup id=\"cite_ref-195\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-195\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>183<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> and \"felt connected with each other through the world of <i>Pokemon</i>\",<sup id=\"cite_ref-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p340_193-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p340-193\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>181<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> feeling positively challenged to make an anime that would match the game's quality.<sup id=\"cite_ref-196\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-196\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>184<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<figure class=\"mw-default-size\" typeof=\"mw:File/Thumb\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Liam_meets_pikachu_(14438634188).jpg\" class=\"mw-file-description\"><img src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Liam_meets_pikachu_%2814438634188%29.jpg/250px-Liam_meets_pikachu_%2814438634188%29.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"250\" height=\"189\" class=\"mw-file-element\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Liam_meets_pikachu_%2814438634188%29.jpg/500px-Liam_meets_pikachu_%2814438634188%29.jpg 1.5x\" data-file-width=\"1704\" data-file-height=\"1288\"></a><figcaption>A boy hugging a Pikachu-<a href=\"/wiki/Costumed_performer\" title=\"Costumed performer\">costumed performer</a>. Pikachu became a popular character among both boys and girls.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Pokemon_Business_Study_Group_p98_197-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Pokemon_Business_Study_Group_p98-197\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>185<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>\n<p>A production council was formed to produce the anime. Different people appeared at different meetings, but four individuals usually present were Ishihara of Creatures, Sugimori of Game Freak, Yuyama of OLM, and independent producer Yoshikawa. Yoshikawa had the final say. The council decided on the anime's worldview, characters, general storyline, and various important details. The early meetings, which were also attended by Tajiri, usually started with a Q&amp;A session in which Tajiri and Ishihara were asked about the Pokemon universe.<sup id=\"cite_ref-198\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-198\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>186<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The council was careful to have the anime be in concordance with the video game. Inevitably, there had to be differences between the two, but all agreed that the overall worldview as envisioned by Tajiri should not be disturbed.<sup id=\"cite_ref-199\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-199\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>187<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> At the start of the video game, the player has to choose one of three starter Pokemon: Fushigidane, Hitokage, or Zenigame (<a href=\"/wiki/Bulbasaur\" title=\"Bulbasaur\">Bulbasaur</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Charmander\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Charmander\">Charmander</a>, or <a href=\"/wiki/Squirtle\" title=\"Squirtle\">Squirtle</a>). The council didn't want to unfairly popularize any of them, and wanted the protagonist to start out with a different Pokemon.<sup id=\"cite_ref-200\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-200\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>188<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-201\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-201\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>189<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Kenji Hatakeyama, who interviewed various people involved with the creation of <i>Pokemon</i>, wrote that, by coincidence, three people independently suggested to the council that a <a href=\"/wiki/Pikachu\" title=\"Pikachu\">Pikachu</a> should be a main character in the anime: Kubo, Yuyama, and Keisuke Iwata of TV Tokyo's Film Department.<sup id=\"cite_ref-202\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-202\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>190<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> In the end, all council members agreed that Pikachu should be one of <i>Pocket Monsters</i><span class=\"nowrap\" style=\"padding-left:0.1em;\">'</span> central icons, as they expected Pikachu to appeal to both boys and girls, as well as their mothers. This would expand the franchise's audience, which was considered a core objective of the anime.<sup id=\"cite_ref-203\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-203\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>191<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-204\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-204\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>192<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>During the council's first meeting, Yoshikawa brought up the issue on whether the Pokemon in the anime could talk, and if not, how they could communicate. In the video games, each has a specific cry. In <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Pocket_Monsters\" title=\"Pokémon Pocket Monsters\">Anakubo's <i>CoroCoro</i> manga</a>, most could speak. At first, the council believed there should be a mixture of Pokemon that could talk and some that could not. However, this idea was eventually discarded: the Pokemon had to make a specific cry. The council agreed that Pokemon were like animals, and while they and humans should be able to understand each other in the series, they should not speak each other's language.<sup id=\"cite_ref-205\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-205\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>193<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> It was decided that Pikachu would repeatedly say its own name in various intonations. The role of Pikachu was given to <a href=\"/wiki/Ikue_Otani\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Ikue Otani\">Ikue Otani</a>. During try-outs, Yuyama had Otani voice Pikachu in normal Japanese, as well as in 'Pikachu talk', in which it only said the syllables of its name. Yuyama realized that, even in the latter style of limited communication, Otani was experienced enough to still convey the messages and emotions needed.<sup id=\"cite_ref-206\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-206\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>194<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>ShoPro paid half of the production cost of <i>Pokemon</i>. <a href=\"/wiki/TV_Tokyo\" title=\"TV Tokyo\">TV Tokyo</a> paid the other half and was granted co-ownership of the anime.<sup id=\"cite_ref-207\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-207\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>195<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The ads during the show<span class=\"nowrap\" style=\"padding-left:0.1em;\">'</span>s commercial breaks were managed by advertisement agency <a href=\"/w/index.php?title=JR_Kikaku&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1\" class=\"new\" title=\"JR Kikaku (page does not exist)\">JR Kikaku</a><span class=\"noprint\" style=\"font-size:85%; font-style: normal;\">&nbsp;[<a href=\"https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E3%82%B8%E3%82%A7%E3%82%A4%E3%82%A2%E3%83%BC%E3%83%AB%E6%9D%B1%E6%97%A5%E6%9C%AC%E4%BC%81%E7%94%BB\" class=\"extiw\" title=\"ja:ジェイアール東日本企画\">ja</a>]</span>, which was in turn paid by sponsors buying advertisement space.<sup id=\"cite_ref-208\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-208\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>196<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> In negotiating with TV Tokyo, Kubo managed to secure the 19:00 – 19:30 timeslot on Tuesdays.<sup id=\"cite_ref-209\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-209\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>197<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <i>Pocket Monsters</i> premiered on 1 April 1997. By November, it had become the highest-rated program on TV Tokyo.<sup id=\"cite_ref-210\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-210\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>198<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The anime succeeded in its goal of widening <i>Pokemon</i><span class=\"nowrap\" style=\"padding-left:0.1em;\">'</span>s audience. Although the video games and the cards remained mostly of interest to boys, the anime also got more girls interested in the franchise, and girls' purchases of <i>Pokemon</i> products increased.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Pokemon_Business_Study_Group_p98_197-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Pokemon_Business_Study_Group_p98-197\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>185<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> This has been partly credited to Pikachu, who gained widespread popularity among both boys and girls.<sup id=\"cite_ref-211\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-211\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>199<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The success of this character would later lead to the game <i>Pocket Monsters Pikachu</i> (<i><a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Yellow\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Pokémon Yellow\">Pokémon Yellow: Special Pikachu Edition</a></i>), released in Japan on 12 September 1998.<sup id=\"cite_ref-212\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-212\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>200<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-213\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-213\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>201<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> An adaptation of <i>Pokemon Blue</i>, this version was made to resemble the TV series more.<sup id=\"cite_ref-214\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-214\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>202<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading4\"><h4 id=\"Copyright_council_formed,_merchandising_expands\"><span id=\"Copyright_council_formed.2C_merchandising_expands\"></span>Copyright council formed, merchandising expands</h4></div>\n<p>In the early months of the franchise, Nintendo was the contractual representative for <i>Pokemon</i>, and thus the central contact point for all <i>Pokemon</i>-related <a href=\"/wiki/Brand_licensing\" title=\"Brand licensing\">licensing</a> (the approval of branded products).<sup id=\"cite_ref-215\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-215\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>203<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Around the time that planning of the anime begun, licensing requests for <i>Pokemon</i> started to increase, which Nintendo had difficulties handling due to a lack of (experienced) staff.<sup id=\"cite_ref-216\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-216\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>204<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Nintendo consequently granted ShoPro exclusive licensor rights. This was the first time that Nintendo of Japan (NoJ) granted licensor rights to another company, aside from its overseas subsidiaries Nintendo of America (NoA) and Nintendo of Europe (NoE).<sup id=\"cite_ref-217\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-217\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>205<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>A copyright council was formed, headed by Ishihara. Beginning in April 1997, the council met every Tuesday, in the conference room of Creatures' office, at the Nintendo Kanda Building in <a href=\"/wiki/Sudach%C5%8D\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Sudachō\">Sudachō</a>, Tokyo.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Creatures_profile_130-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Creatures_profile-130\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>120<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-218\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-218\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>206<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-219\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-219\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>207<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Attendees usually included Ishihara and his secretary, representatives of Nintendo, Game Freak, ShoPro, TV Tokyo, and JR Kikaku, as well as head of the anime Yoshikawa.<sup id=\"cite_ref-220\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-220\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>208<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Broadly put, every meeting had three types of agenda items: discussing <i>Pokemon</i>-related events and basic policies in Japan, discussing Shogakukan publication plans, and considering <a href=\"/wiki/Merchandise\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Merchandise\">merchandise</a> proposals.<sup id=\"cite_ref-221\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-221\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>209<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> For merchandising, the council set the bar high. Fiercely protective of <i>Pokemon</i><span class=\"nowrap\" style=\"padding-left:0.1em;\">'</span>s <a href=\"/wiki/Brand_equity\" title=\"Brand equity\">brand equity</a>, Ishihara was unwilling to greenlit an item just because it had a picture of a Pokemon printed on it. To avoid the market being flooded with low-quality goods, Ishihara put very specific demands on the products he evaluated.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Iwata_Asks_2_184-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Iwata_Asks_2-184\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>172<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-222\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-222\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>210<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Furthermore, in most cases, the council opted to contract one company for each product category.<sup id=\"cite_ref-223\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-223\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>211<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Because of this, most merchandise proposals were rejected: of the approximately 7,500 applications submitted in 1997, only about 5% was approved.<sup id=\"cite_ref-224\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-224\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>212<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>By March 1998, 35 companies offered licensed <i>Pokemon</i> goods, and there were approximately 700 <i>Pokemon</i> products.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Sato_(1998)_p118_144-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Sato_(1998)_p118-144\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>134<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-225\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-225\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>213<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/Tomy\" title=\"Tomy\">Tomy</a> manufactured <i>Pokemon</i> toy figures and plush dolls.<sup id=\"cite_ref-226\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-226\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>214<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/Bandai\" title=\"Bandai\">Bandai</a> made <i>Pokemon</i> <i><a href=\"/wiki/Gashapon\" title=\"Gashapon\">gashapon</a></i>, dolls and <i><a href=\"/wiki/Ramune\" title=\"Ramune\">ramune</a></i>-flavored candy in a plastic box in the shape of a Game Boy.<sup id=\"cite_ref-227\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-227\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>215<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/Meiji_Seika\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Meiji Seika\">Meiji Seika</a> produced <i>Pokemon</i> chocolate snacks and pudding.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Sato_(1998)_p118_144-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Sato_(1998)_p118-144\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>134<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-228\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-228\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>216<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The lucrative franchise provided a much-needed boost to Japan's economy, which was stagnating in what would later be called the <a href=\"/wiki/Lost_Decades\" title=\"Lost Decades\">Lost Decade</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Allison_p._194,_236_229-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Allison_p._194,_236-229\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>217<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-230\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-230\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>218<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> An example of a firm that benefited greatly from <i>Pokemon</i> was food manufacturer <a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Nagatanien&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1\" class=\"new\" title=\"Nagatanien (page does not exist)\">Nagatanien</a><span class=\"noprint\" style=\"font-size:85%; font-style: normal;\">&nbsp;[<a href=\"https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E6%B0%B8%E8%B0%B7%E5%9C%92\" class=\"extiw\" title=\"jp:永谷園\">jp</a>]</span>. From May 1997, the company began selling <i>Pokemon</i>-branded <a href=\"/wiki/Japanese_curry\" title=\"Japanese curry\">curry</a>, <i><a href=\"/wiki/Furikake\" title=\"Furikake\">furikake</a></i>, and <a href=\"/wiki/Baking_mix\" title=\"Baking mix\">baking mixes</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Sato_(1998)_p118_144-3\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Sato_(1998)_p118-144\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>134<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Magic_p61_231-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Magic_p61-231\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>219<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> In December 1997, Nagatanien was hit hard by the collapse of one of its biggest sales channels, <a href=\"https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E3%82%AB%E3%83%BC%E3%82%AE%E3%83%AB%E3%82%B8%E3%83%A3%E3%83%91%E3%83%B3#東食\" class=\"extiw\" title=\"jp:カーギルジャパン\">Toshoku</a>, in what was then the third-largest bankruptcy in Japan's postwar history.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Pokemon_Business_Study_Group_p._266_232-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Pokemon_Business_Study_Group_p._266-232\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>220<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-233\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-233\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>221<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Nonetheless, due to their <i>Pokemon</i>-licensed products, Nagatanien reported net profits in fiscal years '97 and '98, despite having forecasted losses.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Magic_p61_231-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Magic_p61-231\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>219<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Pokemon_Business_Study_Group_p._266_232-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Pokemon_Business_Study_Group_p._266-232\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>220<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-234\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-234\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>222<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading4\"><h4 id=\"&quot;Dennō_Senshi_Porygon&quot;_incident\"><span id=\".22Denn.C5.8D_Senshi_Porygon.22_incident\"></span>\"Dennō Senshi Porygon\" incident</h4></div>\n<link rel=\"mw-deduplicated-inline-style\" href=\"mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320\"><div role=\"note\" class=\"hatnote navigation-not-searchable\">See also: <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_episodes_removed_from_rotation\" title=\"Pokémon episodes removed from rotation\">Pokémon episodes removed from rotation</a></div>\n<p>In the evening of 16 December 1997, the <i>Pokemon</i> franchise was hit by a crisis related to the broadcast of the anime's 38th episode, \"<a href=\"/wiki/Denn%C5%8D_Senshi_Porygon\" title=\"Dennō Senshi Porygon\">Dennō Senshi Porygon</a>\" (Computer Warrior Porygon). It was watched by approximately 4.6&nbsp;million households.<sup id=\"cite_ref-235\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-235\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>223<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> In the episode, the cast is transported into a virtual world, accompanied by a <a href=\"/wiki/Porygon\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Porygon\">Porygon</a>, an artificially-made Pokemon. While flying through cyberspace, they are attacked by an anti-virus program which mistakes them for viruses, shooting \"vaccine missiles\" at them resulting in explosions of bright, rapidly swapping red and blue flashes.<sup id=\"cite_ref-236\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-236\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>224<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>The intense stimuli brought about by the episode triggered a variety of adverse health effects in more than 10,000 viewers,<sup id=\"cite_ref-237\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-237\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>225<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> primarily irritated eyes, headaches, dizziness, and nausea.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Kōsei-shō_report_238-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Kōsei-shō_report-238\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>226<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> A small part suffered a <a href=\"/wiki/Photosensitive_epilepsy\" title=\"Photosensitive epilepsy\">photosensitive epileptic</a> <a href=\"/wiki/Seizure\" title=\"Seizure\">seizure</a>, manifested in loss of conscious and/or convulsions.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Kōsei-shō_report_238-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Kōsei-shō_report-238\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>226<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-239\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-239\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>227<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Hundreds<sup id=\"cite_ref-245\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-245\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>h<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> of children were brought to hospitals, although some had recovered enough upon arrival and did not need to be hospitalized. No one died. Broadcasting of <i>Pokemon</i> was halted, and new guidelines were implemented to help prevent similar events from happening.<sup id=\"cite_ref-246\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-246\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>233<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> With the show on <a href=\"/wiki/Hiatus_(television)\" title=\"Hiatus (television)\">hiatus</a>, ShoPro and OLM worked on a feature <i>Pokemon</i> film. By the time the incident occurred, its script was already written and storyboards were being made. In mid-January, the staff resumed creating new episodes.<sup id=\"cite_ref-247\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-247\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>234<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The anime series returned on 16 April 1998.<sup id=\"cite_ref-248\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-248\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>235<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The film, titled <i>Pocket Monsters the Movie: Mewtwo Strikes Back</i> (<i><a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon:_The_First_Movie\" title=\"Pokémon: The First Movie\">Pokémon: The First Movie</a></i>), premiered on 18 July 1998, becoming the fourth highest grossing film of the year in Japan.<sup id=\"cite_ref-249\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-249\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>236<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-250\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-250\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>237<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Ultimately, the incident did not damage the <i>Pokemon</i> franchise – it in fact grew further during and after the anime's hiatus. While video rental tapes were removed from shelves,<sup id=\"cite_ref-251\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-251\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>238<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-252\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-252\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>239<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> all other <i>Pokemon</i> products continued to be sold as usual, and customer demand for them remained high.<sup id=\"cite_ref-253\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-253\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>240<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-254\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-254\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>241<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Helping matters was a general understanding among businesses that the anime was not canceled, but rather suspended, and many executives (correctly) expected the show to be resumed after precautions had been taken. Supermarkets and other distribution outlets responded calmly to the crisis, and did not remove <i>Pokemon</i> products from their sales floors.<sup id=\"cite_ref-255\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-255\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>242<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading3\"><h3 id=\"1998–2000:_International_expansion\"><span id=\"1998.E2.80.932000:_International_expansion\"></span>1998–2000: International expansion</h3></div>\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading4\"><h4 id=\"North_America\">North America</h4></div>\n<style data-mw-deduplicate=\"TemplateStyles:r1224211176\">.mw-parser-output .quotebox{background-color:#F9F9F9;border:1px solid #aaa;box-sizing:border-box;padding:10px;font-size:88%;max-width:100%}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatleft{margin:.5em 1.4em .8em 0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatright{margin:.5em 0 .8em 1.4em}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.centered{overflow:hidden;position:relative;margin:.5em auto .8em auto}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatleft span,.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatright span{font-style:inherit}.mw-parser-output .quotebox>blockquote{margin:0;padding:0;border-left:0;font-family:inherit;font-size:inherit}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-title{text-align:center;font-size:110%;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote>:first-child{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote:last-child>:last-child{margin-bottom:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote.quoted:before{font-family:\"Times New Roman\",serif;font-weight:bold;font-size:large;color:gray;content:\" “ \";vertical-align:-45%;line-height:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote.quoted:after{font-family:\"Times New Roman\",serif;font-weight:bold;font-size:large;color:gray;content:\" ” \";line-height:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .left-aligned{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .right-aligned{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .center-aligned{text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .quote-title,.mw-parser-output .quotebox .quotebox-quote{display:block}.mw-parser-output .quotebox cite{display:block;font-style:normal}@media screen and (max-width:640px){.mw-parser-output .quotebox{width:100%!important;margin:0 0 .8em!important;float:none!important}}</style><div class=\"quotebox pullquote floatright\" style=\"width:40%; ;\">\n<blockquote class=\"quotebox-quote left-aligned\" style=\"\">\n<p>\"When we started this project in Japan, one of the first things I was told was that this kind of thing would never appeal to American audiences. They said, 'Because the characters are in a very Japanese style, you cannot sell them to Americans'. So from the very beginning, I never thought there would be an English version. Now, it's just as popular in the United States [as in Japan], and I realized that we shouldn't always believe the opinions of conservative marketers.\"\n</p>\n</blockquote>\n<div style=\"padding-bottom: 0; padding-top: 0.5em\"><cite class=\"left-aligned\" style=\"\"><a href=\"/wiki/Shigeru_Miyamoto\" title=\"Shigeru Miyamoto\">Shigeru Miyamoto</a>, August 1999<sup id=\"cite_ref-256\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-256\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>243<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup></cite></div>\n</div>\n<p>Possibly the first official to show interest in a North American launch of <i>Pokemon</i> was <a href=\"/wiki/Minoru_Arakawa\" title=\"Minoru Arakawa\">Minoru Arakawa</a>, founder and then-president of <a href=\"/wiki/Nintendo_of_America\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Nintendo of America\">Nintendo of America</a> (NoA). Arakawa visited Japan to participate in <a href=\"/wiki/Nintendo_Space_World#Shoshinkai_1996\" title=\"Nintendo Space World\">Shoshinkai 1996</a>, held 22–24 November. It was around this time when he first played one of the three <i>Pokemon</i> titles released at the time. He thought the games were promising, but Nintendo of Japan (NoJ) had no plans at the time to release them elsewhere. He returned to America with a few cartridges and tested the game on his employees – they did not believe it would work in the US.<sup id=\"cite_ref-257\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-257\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>244<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> At the time, <a href=\"/wiki/Role-playing_video_game\" title=\"Role-playing video game\">role-playing games</a> (RPGs) were not very popular outside Japan,<sup id=\"cite_ref-Lippman_(1999)_258-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Lippman_(1999)-258\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>245<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> and NoA executives believed that American children did not have the <a href=\"/wiki/Attention_span\" title=\"Attention span\">attention span</a> for such a complex title.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Moss_(2019)_259-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Moss_(2019)-259\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>246<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Americans were said to be more interested in sport- and action-oriented games, preferably with realistic graphics.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Baylis_(1999)_20-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Baylis_(1999)-20\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>17<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Gellene_(1998)_260-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Gellene_(1998)-260\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>247<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Japanese people, by contrast, were alleged to care more about characters and plot.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Eisenberg_(1998)_261-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Eisenberg_(1998)-261\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>248<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Up to that point, few Japanese properties had been successfully mainstreamed in the US, and if they were, it was alleged to be on account of having been properly <a href=\"/wiki/Americanized\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Americanized\">Americanized</a>: <i><a href=\"/wiki/Mighty_Morphin_Power_Rangers\" title=\"Mighty Morphin Power Rangers\">Mighty Morphin Power Rangers</a></i> was considered a prime example of this.<sup id=\"cite_ref-262\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-262\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>249<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Visually, <i>Pokemon</i> was believed to be too <i><a href=\"/wiki/Kawaii\" title=\"Kawaii\">kawaii</a></i>, or <a href=\"/wiki/Cuteness\" title=\"Cuteness\">cute</a>. It was assumed that <i>Pokemon</i> could not succeed on cute alone – it must also be <a href=\"/wiki/Cool_(aesthetic)\" title=\"Cool (aesthetic)\">cool</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-taidan1_page03_263-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-taidan1_page03-263\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>250<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p407-408_264-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p407-408-264\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>251<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> In an effort to enhance the franchise's coolness, NoA considered a graphical redesign and contracted a few external artists to create some test-designs for the American market.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Moss_(2019)_259-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Moss_(2019)-259\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>246<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p407-408_264-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p407-408-264\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>251<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The <a href=\"/wiki/Mockup\" title=\"Mockup\">mockups</a> they proposed included 'graffiti style' drawings,<sup id=\"cite_ref-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p407-408_264-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p407-408-264\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>251<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> 'beefed-up' and more muscular looking Pokemon,<sup id=\"cite_ref-265\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-265\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>252<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> and a new Pikachu that looked like \"a tiger with huge breasts\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-taidan1_page03_263-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-taidan1_page03-263\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>250<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Arakawa concluded that it \"didn't work\",<sup id=\"cite_ref-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p407-408_264-3\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p407-408-264\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>251<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> and by that time, the anime had begun its production in Japan, leading NoA to conclude it was too late for a graphical revamp anyway.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Moss_(2019)_259-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Moss_(2019)-259\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>246<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Of pivotal importance to <i>Pokemon</i><span class=\"nowrap\" style=\"padding-left:0.1em;\">'</span>s global expansion was <a href=\"/wiki/Alfred_R._Kahn\" title=\"Alfred R. Kahn\">Alfred R. Kahn</a>, CEO of US-based <a href=\"/wiki/4Kids_Entertainment\" title=\"4Kids Entertainment\">4Kids Entertainment</a>, NoA's licensing agent since 1987.<sup id=\"cite_ref-4Kids_History_266-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-4Kids_History-266\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>253<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Rogers_(2000)_267-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Rogers_(2000)-267\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>254<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Convinced of the franchise's potential, Kahn agreed to invest an undisclosed sum in return for both the anime and licensing rights.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Lippman_(1999)_258-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Lippman_(1999)-258\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>245<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <i>Pokemon</i> became one of the first Japanese media franchises in which both the localization of the anime and the licensing of merchandise was handled by a single company, as well as a non-Japanese company.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Stewart_(2004)_268-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Stewart_(2004)-268\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>255<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Kahn suggested to use the short version of the name, \"Pokémon\", adding an <a href=\"/wiki/Acute_accent\" title=\"Acute accent\">acute accent</a> (´) over the <i>e</i> to assist with pronunciation and \"give it a little flair\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-Tsukayama_(2016)_18-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Tsukayama_(2016)-18\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>15<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> NoJ president <a href=\"/wiki/Hiroshi_Yamauchi\" title=\"Hiroshi Yamauchi\">Hiroshi Yamauchi</a> officially approved the project in late November,<sup id=\"cite_ref-269\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-269\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>256<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> and subsequently announced it at <a href=\"/wiki/Nintendo_Space_World#Space_World_1997\" title=\"Nintendo Space World\">Space World 1997</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-EGM_124_270-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-EGM_124-270\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>257<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> However, three weeks later, the \"<a href=\"/wiki/Denn%C5%8D_Senshi_Porygon\" title=\"Dennō Senshi Porygon\">Dennō Senshi Porygon</a>\" incident happened, which Kubo felt made even more people resistant to the idea of an overseas introduction.<sup id=\"cite_ref-271\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-271\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>258<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/Market_research\" title=\"Market research\">Market research</a> turned back negative: American kids reportedly did not like <i>Pokémon</i>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-272\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-272\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>259<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Arakawa ignored the study and, convinced of the franchise's potential, allocated an enormous budget to <i>Pokémon</i><span class=\"nowrap\" style=\"padding-left:0.1em;\">'</span>s launch. The exact amount was not disclosed, but was reportedly equal to or more than $50&nbsp;million (c. $96.46 million in 2024), approximately the same amount as the launch budget of the <a href=\"/wiki/Nintendo_Entertainment_System\" title=\"Nintendo Entertainment System\">Nintendo Entertainment System</a> in 1985. Arakawa admitted that it was \"quite a bit of money\", but NoA \"had been doing well for several years, so we had a lot of money to spare\". He opined that if <i>Pokémon</i> would be as successful in the US as it had been in Japan, \"an investment of 1 would turn into 100\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-273\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-273\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>260<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> NoA and 4Kids proceeded to devise a strategy on how to localize <i>Pokémon</i> for the United States.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Moss_(2019)_259-3\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Moss_(2019)-259\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>246<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Arakawa appointed <a href=\"/wiki/Gail_Tilden\" title=\"Gail Tilden\">Gail Tilden</a> to lead the project, prompting her to leave her position at <i><a href=\"/wiki/Nintendo_Power\" title=\"Nintendo Power\">Nintendo Power</a></i> magazine.<sup id=\"cite_ref-274\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-274\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>261<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Tilden said that they \"decided to make an all-out effort to repeat the phenomenon in the Western world\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-Chua-Eoan_Larimer_(1999)_32-4\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Chua-Eoan_Larimer_(1999)-32\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>27<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> In two press releases, NoA self-described <i>Pokémon</i><span class=\"nowrap\" style=\"padding-left:0.1em;\">'</span>s marketing campaign as \"aggressive\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-275\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-275\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>262<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-276\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-276\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>263<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a href=\"/wiki/Editing_of_anime_in_distribution#Localization\" title=\"Editing of anime in distribution\">localization</a> of the <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_(TV_series)\" title=\"Pokémon (TV series)\"><i>Pokémon</i> anime</a> was done by 4Kids, and directed by <a href=\"/wiki/Norman_J._Grossfeld\" title=\"Norman J. Grossfeld\">Norman J. Grossfeld</a>. Grossfeld strongly believed that the anime should be <a href=\"/wiki/Americanization\" title=\"Americanization\">Americanized</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-277\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-277\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>264<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> At <a href=\"/wiki/NATPE\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"NATPE\">NATPE</a> 1998, he asked ShoPro for a \"kind of <a href=\"https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/carte_blanche#Noun\" class=\"extiw\" title=\"wikt:carte blanche\">carte blanche</a>, to let me change the show as I think would work for this market\", to which ShoPro agreed.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Dockery_(2022)_p43-44_278-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Dockery_(2022)_p43-44-278\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>265<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> However, no national TV station  was interested in buying the anime or financing its localization.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Tsukayama_(2016)_18-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Tsukayama_(2016)-18\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>15<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Lippman_(1999)_258-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Lippman_(1999)-258\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>245<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Kahn then decided to self-finance <i>Pokémon'</i>s production costs, despite realizing this \"could very well bring down 4Kids\" if the show would fail.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Dockery_(2022)_p43-44_278-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Dockery_(2022)_p43-44-278\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>265<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> According to Kahn, they \"spend a fortune\" on the localization.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Mallory_(2001)_30-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Mallory_(2001)-30\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>26<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> To have it <a href=\"/wiki/Broadcast_syndication\" title=\"Broadcast syndication\">broadcast in syndication</a>, 4Kids offered the show for free to local TV stations across the country, in exchange for a portion of the advertising revenue.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Tsukayama_(2016)_18-3\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Tsukayama_(2016)-18\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>15<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Lippman_(1999)_258-3\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Lippman_(1999)-258\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>245<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> NoA assisted, persuading dozens of stations to carry the series by offering to buy some of their advertisement space, spending a total of $5&nbsp;million (c. $9.65 million in 2024).<sup id=\"cite_ref-Gellene_(1998)_260-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Gellene_(1998)-260\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>247<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Dockery_(2022)_p43-44_278-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Dockery_(2022)_p43-44-278\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>265<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Despite all this, most broadcasters were still reluctant to carry <i>Pokémon</i>, with Grossfeld experiencing difficulties getting through their \"preconceived notions or their snobbery for Western-produced animation over something from Asia\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-Dockery_(2022)_p43-44_278-3\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Dockery_(2022)_p43-44-278\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>265<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> At the time, anime had not yet found mainstream popularity in the West. Contemporary news reports cited <i><a href=\"/wiki/Sailor_Moon\" title=\"Sailor Moon\">Sailor Moon</a></i><sup id=\"cite_ref-281\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-281\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>VI<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> as an example of an anime that had failed to catch on with American youth.<sup id=\"cite_ref-285\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-285\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>i<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Still, with NoA's help, 4Kids ultimately succeeded in contracting 112 broadcasters for <i>Pokémon</i>,<sup id=\"cite_ref-286\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-286\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>271<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> reaching \"about 85 to 90 percent\"<sup id=\"cite_ref-Saunders_(1998)_287-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Saunders_(1998)-287\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>272<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> of television households. However, many broadcasters gave it off-peak time slots, with starting times like 06:00 or 06:30.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Tsukayama_(2016)_18-4\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Tsukayama_(2016)-18\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>15<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Gellene_(1998)_260-3\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Gellene_(1998)-260\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>247<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Prior to the late 1990s, this was the case for many anime in the US.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Stewart_(2004)_268-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Stewart_(2004)-268\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>255<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Grossfeld came up with the <a href=\"/wiki/Advertising_slogan\" title=\"Advertising slogan\">advertising slogan</a> \"Gotta catch 'em all!\" as the English equivalent to the Japanese <span title=\"Hepburn transliteration\"><i lang=\"ja-Latn\">Pokemon GETTO daze~!</i></span><span style=\"font-weight: normal\"> (<span title=\"Japanese-language text\"><span lang=\"ja\">ポケモンゲットだぜー！</span></span>, Get (the) Pokémon!)</span>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-288\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-288\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>273<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Van_Luling_(2017)_289-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Van_Luling_(2017)-289\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>274<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The phrase \"miraculously managed to gain approval\" by the <a href=\"/wiki/Federal_Communications_Commission\" title=\"Federal Communications Commission\">Federal Communications Commission</a> (FCC), which normally prohibits the use of injunctions in <a href=\"/wiki/Advertising_to_children\" title=\"Advertising to children\">ads directed at children</a> (e.g. \"You must buy this!\"). While the tagline may sound commanding, the FCC reasoned that the act of <i>catching</i> is at the core of <i>Pokémon</i><span class=\"nowrap\" style=\"padding-left:0.1em;\">'</span>s play. Therefore, the phrase was allowed.<sup id=\"cite_ref-290\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-290\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>275<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Theme\" title=\"Pokémon Theme\">The series' theme song</a> was written by <a href=\"/wiki/John_Loeffler\" title=\"John Loeffler\">John Loeffler</a> and John Siegler, and performed by <a href=\"/wiki/Jason_Paige\" title=\"Jason Paige\">Jason Paige</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-291\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-291\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>276<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> In commissioning the track, Grossfeld specifically requested the song's chorus to be written around the \"Gotta catch 'em all\" phrase, firmly embedding the slogan into the theme.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Van_Luling_(2017)_289-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Van_Luling_(2017)-289\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>274<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>While NoA and 4Kids were allowed a fair degree of liberty in their localization of <i>Pokémon</i>, the Japanese copyright council, headed by Ishihara, had the last say over it. All decisions regarding adjustments and promotion had to gain final approval of the Japan side.<sup id=\"cite_ref-292\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-292\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>277<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> This included all of the merchandise, for which a 'two-step system' was created. All (aspiring) licensees in North America were to send their merchandise proposals to 4Kids.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Lippman_(1999)_258-4\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Lippman_(1999)-258\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>245<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Staff of both 4Kids and NoA then made a pre-selection and send the approved proposals to Japan, where the council made the final decision. Many submissions were bounced at the US stage, and thus never got sent to Japan. Tilden noted that processing all license applications, and mailing all approved prototypes and their documentation to Japan, was a lot of work. Arakawa did consider streamlining the process by moving someone from Japan to the US, but no person could be found who was as competent as Ishihara.<sup id=\"cite_ref-293\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-293\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>278<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>The <i>Pokémon</i> anime was first broadcast on 7 September 1998.<sup id=\"cite_ref-294\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-294\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>279<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-295\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-295\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>280<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Red,_Blue,_and_Yellow\" title=\"Pokémon Red, Blue, and Yellow\"><i>Pokémon Red Version</i> and <i>Blue Version</i></a> were released three weeks later, on 28 September 1998.<sup id=\"cite_ref-296\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-296\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>281<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> To localize the card game, Nintendo contracted <a href=\"/wiki/Wizards_of_the_Coast\" title=\"Wizards of the Coast\">Wizards of the Coast</a>, the creator of <i><a href=\"/wiki/Magic:_The_Gathering\" title=\"Magic: The Gathering\">Magic: The Gathering</a></i>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-297\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-297\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>282<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The <i><a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Trading_Card_Game\" title=\"Pokémon Trading Card Game\">Pokémon Trading Card Game</a></i> was officially launched nationwide on 9 January 1999, although pre-sold in select stores in December.<sup id=\"cite_ref-298\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-298\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>283<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Coinciding with the North American launch of <i>Pokémon</i> was the release of the <a href=\"/wiki/Game_Boy_Color\" title=\"Game Boy Color\">Game Boy Color</a> on 23 November 1998.<sup id=\"cite_ref-299\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-299\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>284<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading4\"><h4 id=\"Other_regions\">Other regions</h4></div>\n<p>The American version of the <i>Pokémon</i> anime started broadcasting in Australia and New Zealand on 28 September 1998. <i>Red</i> and <i>Blue</i> were subsequently released there on 23 October. Various territories in Asia followed: the anime series debuted in Hong Kong on 16 November, in <a href=\"/wiki/Taiwan\" title=\"Taiwan\">Taiwan</a> on 23 November, in Shanghai on 24 November, in Beijing on 10 January 1999, and in <a href=\"/wiki/South_Korea\" title=\"South Korea\">South Korea</a> on 14 July 1999.<sup id=\"cite_ref-300\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-300\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>285<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Outside North America, 4Kids distributed the anime in cooperation with <a href=\"/wiki/Brian_Lacey_(entertainment_executive)\" title=\"Brian Lacey (entertainment executive)\">Brian Lacey</a> of <a href=\"/wiki/Lacey_Entertainment\" title=\"Lacey Entertainment\">Lacey Entertainment</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Dinoff_(1999)_301-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Dinoff_(1999)-301\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>286<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-302\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-302\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>287<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The series was presented at <a href=\"/wiki/MIPTV_Media_Market\" title=\"MIPTV Media Market\">MIP TV</a>, in Cannes, France, from 3–8 April 1998.<sup id=\"cite_ref-303\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-303\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>288<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Broadcasters were initially not interested due to its Japanese origins, and preferred to wait and see how the anime would fare in the US. After its American success, Lacey received inquiries about the series throughout 1999 from multiple international broadcasters.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Dinoff_(1999)_301-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Dinoff_(1999)-301\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>286<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-proves_to_be_gold_304-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-proves_to_be_gold-304\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>289<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Lacey noted that, in Europe, this was a stark contrast compared to previous years: \"I was trying to sell this sort of stuff for years and buyers would tell me they were moving away from <a href=\"/wiki/Anime\" title=\"Anime\">Japanese animation</a> shows\", he said.<sup id=\"cite_ref-proves_to_be_gold_304-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-proves_to_be_gold-304\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>289<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> In October 1999, the franchise was launched in the European key markets of Germany, the United Kingdom, France, and Spain.<sup id=\"cite_ref-305\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-305\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>290<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The anime started broadcasting in Denmark, Norway, and Sweden in December 1999.<sup id=\"cite_ref-proves_to_be_gold_304-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-proves_to_be_gold-304\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>289<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> In 2000, broadcasting rights for the first season were secured by TV stations in South Africa, Russia, Iceland, and Finland.<sup id=\"cite_ref-306\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-306\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>291<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> In Israel, the anime debuted in February 2000. For unclear reasons, <i>Red</i> and <i>Blue</i> were not officially released there. Thriving only on the strength of the TV series, <i>The First Movie</i>, the cards, and <a href=\"/wiki/Parallel_importing_in_video_games\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Parallel importing in video games\">imported video games</a>, the Israeli <i>Pokémon</i> still became a success.<sup id=\"cite_ref-307\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-307\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>292<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-308\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-308\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>293<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>By the end of 2000, <i>Pokémon</i> games had been released in 70 countries, the anime was broadcast in 51 countries, the films were released in 33 countries, and the cards had been translated into 11 languages.<sup id=\"cite_ref-309\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-309\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>294<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading3\"><h3 id=\"1999–2000:_Pokémania\"><span id=\"1999.E2.80.932000:_Pok.C3.A9mania\"></span>1999–2000: Pokémania</h3></div>\n<p>In North America, the debuting <i>Pokémon</i> franchise quickly rose to success. <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Red,_Blue,_and_Yellow\" title=\"Pokémon Red, Blue, and Yellow\"><i>Red</i> and <i>Blue</i></a> sold 200,000 copies in its first month. By December 1998, the <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_(TV_series)\" title=\"Pokémon (TV series)\"><i>Pokémon</i> anime</a> had become the highest-rated syndicated children's show during the weekdays.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Dinoff_(1999)_301-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Dinoff_(1999)-301\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>286<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> This attracted the attention of two media companies: <a href=\"/wiki/Warner_Bros.\" title=\"Warner Bros.\">Warner Bros.</a>, co-owner of <a href=\"/wiki/The_WB\" title=\"The WB\">The WB</a> channel; and <a href=\"/wiki/Saban_Entertainment\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Saban Entertainment\">Saban Entertainment</a>/<a href=\"/wiki/Fox_Family_Worldwide\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Fox Family Worldwide\">Fox Family Worldwide</a>, owners of the <a href=\"/wiki/Fox_Kids\" title=\"Fox Kids\">Fox Kids</a> channel. A bidding war ensued between the parties, which was won by Warner Bros.<sup id=\"cite_ref-310\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-310\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>295<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> On 13 February 1999, <i>Pokémon</i> launched on the <a href=\"/wiki/Kids%27_WB\" title=\"Kids' WB\">Kids' WB</a> national television block. The debut episode became the most watched premiere in Kids' WB's history.<sup id=\"cite_ref-311\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-311\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>296<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> In European countries, the anime received similar levels of success. For example, in Germany, \"a highly competitive kids market\", <i>Pokémon</i> was purchased by <a href=\"/wiki/RTL_Zwei\" title=\"RTL Zwei\">RTL 2</a>. The show's popularity bolstered the entire program block, more than tripling its viewers. Andrea Lang, RTL 2's editor of cartoons and children's programs, said: \"We were speechless. We've never had a comparable success\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-proves_to_be_gold_304-3\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-proves_to_be_gold-304\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>289<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> By March 1998, half a year before <i>Pokémon</i><span class=\"nowrap\" style=\"padding-left:0.1em;\">'</span>s overseas launch, 499 million <i>Pokémon</i> cards had been produced. By March 1999, the total number of cards shipped reached 764 million. By March 2000, this figure would grow further to 4.255 billion cards, manufactured in both Japanese and American factories.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p246-247_179-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p246-247-179\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>167<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>By April 1999, there was a general consensus in the US that <i>Pokémon</i> had become a phenomenon and the newest children's <a href=\"/wiki/Fad\" title=\"Fad\">fad</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-315\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-315\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>VII<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> By some, the fad was referred to as \"Pokémania\",<sup id=\"cite_ref-320\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-320\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>VIII<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> including journalists of <i><a href=\"/wiki/Time_(magazine)\" title=\"Time (magazine)\">Time</a></i><sup id=\"cite_ref-Chua-Eoan_Larimer_(1999)_32-5\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Chua-Eoan_Larimer_(1999)-32\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>27<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> and <i><a href=\"/wiki/USA_Today\" title=\"USA Today\">USA Today</a></i>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-321\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-321\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>304<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> In the US, severe <a href=\"/wiki/Scarcity\" title=\"Scarcity\">scarcity</a> occurred of <i>Pokémon</i> goods,<sup id=\"cite_ref-Thomas-Lester_(1999)_29-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Thomas-Lester_(1999)-29\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>25<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> especially <i>Pokémon</i> cards,<sup id=\"cite_ref-322\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-322\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>305<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> causing companies to miss profits.<sup id=\"cite_ref-323\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-323\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>306<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> A <i><a href=\"/wiki/Milwaukee_Journal_Sentinel\" title=\"Milwaukee Journal Sentinel\">Milwaukee Journal Sentinel</a></i> article, published on 3 August 1999, cited a <a href=\"/wiki/Toys_%22R%22_Us\" title=\"Toys &quot;R&quot; Us\">Toys \"R\" Us</a> manager as saying that a supply of 600 <a href=\"/wiki/Booster_pack\" title=\"Booster pack\">booster packs</a> would last 24 hours. The CEO of one card distributor stated that they were \"thousands of boxes behind\" on orders. In the same article, a Wizards spokeswoman stated that more employees and printers had been hired to increase card production.<sup id=\"cite_ref-324\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-324\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>307<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> However, near the end of the month, a different Wizards spokeswoman told <i><a href=\"/wiki/The_Washington_Post\" title=\"The Washington Post\">The Washington Post</a></i> that they had \"exhausted most of the card-printing capacity of the United States\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-Baylis_(1999)_20-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Baylis_(1999)-20\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>17<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Similarly, <i>USA Today</i> reported in November 1999 that factories making <a href=\"/wiki/Hasbro\" title=\"Hasbro\">Hasbro</a>'s <i>Pokémon</i> toys had expanded production by 20 times, but demand still exceeded supply.<sup id=\"cite_ref-325\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-325\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>308<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> In Europe, scarcity of <i>Pokémon</i> merchandise also occurred.<sup id=\"cite_ref-proves_to_be_gold_304-4\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-proves_to_be_gold-304\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>289<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>In part due to the <i>Pokémon</i> craze, Nintendo saw a 250% increase in profits in 1999 compared to the previous year,<sup id=\"cite_ref-Baylis_(1999)_20-3\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Baylis_(1999)-20\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>17<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> reaching a six-year high.<sup id=\"cite_ref-326\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-326\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>309<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The <i>Pokémon</i> franchise accounted for over 30% of Nintendo's revenue that year.<sup id=\"cite_ref-327\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-327\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>310<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <i>Pokémon</i><span class=\"nowrap\" style=\"padding-left:0.1em;\">'</span>s popularity also caused a sharp increase in sales of the Game Boy line.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Moss_(2019)_259-4\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Moss_(2019)-259\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>246<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-328\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-328\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>311<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-329\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-329\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>312<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The financial windfalls came at a time when Nintendo lost dominance in the home console market, with the <a href=\"/wiki/Nintendo_64\" title=\"Nintendo 64\">Nintendo 64</a> being outsold by <a href=\"/wiki/Sony\" title=\"Sony\">Sony</a>'s <a href=\"/wiki/PlayStation_(console)\" title=\"PlayStation (console)\">PlayStation</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-330\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-330\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>313<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-331\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-331\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>314<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-332\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-332\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>315<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The global success of <i>Pokémon</i> compensated this loss somewhat.<sup id=\"cite_ref-337\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-337\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>IX<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Scholars <a href=\"/wiki/David_Buckingham_(academic)\" title=\"David Buckingham (academic)\">David Buckingham</a> and Julian Sefton-Green went even further, writing in 2004: \"while Nintendo is now among Japan's most profitable corporations, it could be argued that the company would have struggled to survive without Pokémon\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-338\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-338\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>320<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>4Kids, initially a little-known firm,<sup id=\"cite_ref-Lippman_(1999)_258-5\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Lippman_(1999)-258\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>245<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-4Kids_History_266-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-4Kids_History-266\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>253<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> expanded thirty times in revenues,<sup id=\"cite_ref-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p455_339-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p455-339\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>321<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> and was named the fastest-growing company in America in the 4 September 2000, issue of <i><a href=\"/wiki/Fortune_(magazine)\" title=\"Fortune (magazine)\">Fortune</a></i> magazine.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Rogers_(2000)_267-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Rogers_(2000)-267\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>254<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-340\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-340\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>322<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-341\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-341\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>323<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Many businesses that timely obtained a <i>Pokémon</i> license reaped considerable profits.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p455_339-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p455-339\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>321<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-342\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-342\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>324<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> In the summer of 1999, a massive run on stocks of publicly traded <i>Pokémon</i> licensees caused their value to increase dramatically. However, by November, most investors were <a href=\"/wiki/Short_(finance)\" title=\"Short (finance)\">shorting</a> their shares. Realizing that <i>Pokémon</i> was a <a href=\"/wiki/Fad\" title=\"Fad\">fad</a> that would peak and fall at some point, investors were <a href=\"/wiki/Bearish\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Bearish\">bearish</a> about its prospects.<sup id=\"cite_ref-343\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-343\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>325<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p><i><a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon:_The_First_Movie\" title=\"Pokémon: The First Movie\">Pokémon: The First Movie</a></i> premiered in North America on 12 November 1999, and in Europe the following year. Despite being negatively received by many Western critics, it became one of the most successful Japanese animated films of all time.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Sammut_(2023)_344-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Sammut_(2023)-344\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>326<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> In the United States, November 1999 was estimated to have been the peak of Pokémania.<sup id=\"cite_ref-349\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-349\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>X<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Supporting the American release of <i>The First Movie</i> was a promotional action with <a href=\"/wiki/Burger_King\" title=\"Burger King\">Burger King</a>, one of the largest in the history of the <a href=\"/wiki/Fast_food\" title=\"Fast food\">fast-food industry</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-350\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-350\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>331<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-351\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-351\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>332<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Hernandez_(1999)_352-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Hernandez_(1999)-352\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>333<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The success of the promotion resulted in supply issues; restaurants often ran out of <i>Pokémon</i> toys to include with their meals.<sup id=\"cite_ref-353\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-353\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>334<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-354\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-354\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>335<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> On 27 December,<sup id=\"cite_ref-355\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-355\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>336<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Burger King <a href=\"/wiki/Burger_King_Pok%C3%A9mon_container_recall\" title=\"Burger King Pokémon container recall\">recalled its Poké Ball toy</a> after a 13-month-old girl died suffocating on one.<sup id=\"cite_ref-356\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-356\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>337<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-357\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-357\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>338<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Gold,_Silver,_and_Crystal\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Pokémon Gold, Silver, and Crystal\"><i>Pokémon Gold</i> and <i>Silver</i></a>, the successors to <i>Red/Green/Blue</i>, were released in North America on 15 October 2000.<sup id=\"cite_ref-358\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-358\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>339<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> In Europe, they were released on 6 April 2001.<sup id=\"cite_ref-359\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-359\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>340<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading4\"><h4 id=\"The_Pokémon_Company_and_Pokémon_USA_established\"><span id=\"The_Pok.C3.A9mon_Company_and_Pok.C3.A9mon_USA_established\"></span>The Pokémon Company and Pokémon USA established</h4></div>\n<figure typeof=\"mw:File/Thumb\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Mega_Tokyo_Pok%C3%A9mon_Center_wares_4.jpg\" class=\"mw-file-description\"><img src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Mega_Tokyo_Pok%C3%A9mon_Center_wares_4.jpg/500px-Mega_Tokyo_Pok%C3%A9mon_Center_wares_4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"350\" height=\"263\" class=\"mw-file-element\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Mega_Tokyo_Pok%C3%A9mon_Center_wares_4.jpg/960px-Mega_Tokyo_Pok%C3%A9mon_Center_wares_4.jpg 1.5x\" data-file-width=\"4608\" data-file-height=\"3456\"></a><figcaption>Pokémon Center Mega Tokyo, a large Pokémon merchandise shop in <a href=\"/wiki/Sunshine_City,_Tokyo\" title=\"Sunshine City, Tokyo\">Sunshine City</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Ikebukuro\" title=\"Ikebukuro\">Ikebukuro</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-360\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-360\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>341<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>\n<p>On 23 April 1998, Pokémon Center Co. Ltd. was founded as a joint venture by Nintendo, Creatures, and Game Freak.<sup id=\"cite_ref-361\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-361\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>342<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> It was initially formed for the management of specialized merchandise stores called Pokemon Centers, of which the first location opened in <a href=\"/wiki/Nihonbashi\" title=\"Nihonbashi\">Nihonbashi</a>, Tokyo, on 18 July 1998.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Company_History_362-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Company_History-362\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>343<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-363\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-363\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>344<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Throughout the years, multiple Japanese Pokémon Centers would open and close. As of September&nbsp;2025<sup class=\"plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update\" style=\"display:none;\"><a class=\"external text\" href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pok%C3%A9mon&amp;action=edit\">[update]</a></sup>, a total of 23 Pokémon merchandise shops exist in Japan.<sup id=\"cite_ref-364\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-364\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>345<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> An American Pokémon Center also existed in New York City from 2001<sup id=\"cite_ref-365\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-365\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>346<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> to 2005.<sup id=\"cite_ref-366\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-366\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>347<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> It was then remodelled into Nintendo World,<sup id=\"cite_ref-367\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-367\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>348<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> later renamed <a href=\"/wiki/Nintendo_New_York\" title=\"Nintendo New York\">Nintendo New York</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-368\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-368\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>349<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>After the release of <i>Gold</i> and <i>Silver</i>, Tsunekazu Ishihara began setting out a number of long-term goals for the <i>Pokémon</i> franchise, which included releasing a movie every year.<sup id=\"cite_ref-369\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-369\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>j<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> As part of Ishihara's plan, the Pokemon Center Co. Ltd. was reformatted into <a href=\"/wiki/The_Pok%C3%A9mon_Company\" title=\"The Pokémon Company\">The Pokémon Company</a> (TPC), and officially renamed in October 2000.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Company_History_362-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Company_History-362\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>343<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Iwata_Asks_3_370-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Iwata_Asks_3-370\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>350<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The goal of TPC is to centralize and streamline the global management of Pokémon.<sup id=\"cite_ref-4Kids_another_5_Years_371-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-4Kids_another_5_Years-371\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>351<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/Satoru_Iwata\" title=\"Satoru Iwata\">Satoru Iwata</a>, who had joined Nintendo of Japan in June, was involved with the company's creation, which was one of his first jobs at Nintendo.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Iwata_Asks_3_370-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Iwata_Asks_3-370\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>350<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>In February 2001, <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_USA\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Pokémon USA\">Pokémon USA</a> (PUSA) was established, an affiliated firm of The Pokémon Company.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Company_History_362-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Company_History-362\"><span
