class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>343<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The company's first president was <a href=\"/wiki/Tatsumi_Kimishima\" title=\"Tatsumi Kimishima\">Tatsumi Kimishima</a> (who would later become president of NoA, and subsequently president of NoJ).<sup id=\"cite_ref-372\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-372\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>352<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> In 2002, Kimishima was succeeded by <a href=\"/wiki/Akira_Chiba\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Akira Chiba\">Akira Chiba</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-373\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-373\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>353<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading3\"><h3 id=\"2001–2006:_End_of_the_craze,_business_reforms\"><span id=\"2001.E2.80.932006:_End_of_the_craze.2C_business_reforms\"></span>2001–2006: End of the craze, business reforms</h3></div>\n<p>In North America, Pokémania peaked in 1999, slowing down throughout the next year.<sup id=\"cite_ref-374\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-374\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>354<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> On 29 April 2000, the anime was bumped off <a href=\"/wiki/Kids%27_WB\" title=\"Kids' WB\">Kids' WB</a>'s No. 1 spot after holding it for 54 weeks. Around the same time, <i>Pokémon</i> was surpassed at <a href=\"/wiki/Fox_Kids\" title=\"Fox Kids\">Fox Kids</a> by its rival <i><a href=\"/wiki/Digimon_Adventure_(1999_TV_series)\" title=\"Digimon Adventure (1999 TV series)\">Digimon</a></i>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-375\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-375\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>355<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> In Europe, the craze peaked in 2000.<sup id=\"cite_ref-376\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-376\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>356<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-377\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-377\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>357<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> On 20 January 2001, <i>The New York Times</i> reported that <i>Pokémon</i><span class=\"nowrap\" style=\"padding-left:0.1em;\">'</span>s trading card market had collapsed in the US.<sup id=\"cite_ref-378\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-378\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>358<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> A June 2001 survey in the United Kingdom confirmed that <i>Pokémon</i><span class=\"nowrap\" style=\"padding-left:0.1em;\">'</span>s popularity was waning there.<sup id=\"cite_ref-379\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-379\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>359<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/Joseph_Tobin\" title=\"Joseph Tobin\">Joseph Tobin</a> wrote: \"By the summer of 2001, Pokémon's shelf space in Japanese and U.S. toy stores was but a fraction of what it enjoyed in the fall of 1999\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-380\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-380\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>360<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> By the end of 2001, Pokémania was fading globally, and by 2002, the fad was largely over.<sup id=\"cite_ref-381\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-381\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>361<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>From 2000 to 2002, Game Freak developed <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Ruby_and_Sapphire\" title=\"Pokémon Ruby and Sapphire\"><i>Pokémon Ruby</i> and <i>Sapphire</i></a>, the successors to <i>Gold</i> and <i>Silver</i>, for the newly released <a href=\"/wiki/Game_Boy_Advance\" title=\"Game Boy Advance\">Game Boy Advance</a>. Masuda, who was appointed to assistant director during <i>Gold</i> and <i>Silver</i>,<sup id=\"cite_ref-382\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-382\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>362<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> was promoted to director for <i>Ruby</i> and <i>Sapphire</i>, with Tajiri making himself executive director.<sup id=\"cite_ref-383\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-383\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>363<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Masuda was concerned that the end of Pokémania indicated the end of <i>Pokémon</i> as a whole: \"After Gold and Silver came out, it was a huge hit around the world, but shortly after everyone was saying, 'That's it. The Pokémon fad is over! It's dead!'.\"<sup id=\"cite_ref-Hilliard_(2017)_384-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Hilliard_(2017)-384\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>364<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Determined to keep the franchise going, GF not only wanted to \"prove people wrong\" with <i>Ruby</i> and <i>Sapphire</i>, but already started planning their sequels: <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Diamond_and_Pearl\" title=\"Pokémon Diamond and Pearl\"><i>Diamond</i> and <i>Pearl</i></a> (2006). They also began planning remakes of older installments, starting with <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_FireRed_and_LeafGreen\" title=\"Pokémon FireRed and LeafGreen\"><i>FireRed</i> and <i>LeafGreen</i></a> (2004), remakes of the original <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Red,_Blue,_and_Yellow\" title=\"Pokémon Red, Blue, and Yellow\"><i>Red</i> and <i>Green</i></a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Hilliard_(2017)_384-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Hilliard_(2017)-384\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>364<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p><i>Ruby</i> and <i>Sapphire</i> were released in Japan on 21 November 2002, and in the rest of the world the next year. The games introduced 135 new Pokémon, bringing the total amount to 386. Because of this, <a href=\"/wiki/Golin_Harris\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Golin Harris\">Golin Harris</a>, NoA's ad agency,<sup id=\"cite_ref-Moss_(2019)_259-5\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Moss_(2019)-259\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>246<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> advised them to move away from the \"Gotta catch 'em all!\" slogan. They reasoned that if new, younger players were drawn into the franchise with <i>Ruby/Sapphire</i>, they would find the concept of \"catching them all\" to be a daunting if not impossible task if they didn't also have <i>Red/Blue/Yellow</i> and <i>Gold/Silver/Crystal</i>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Dockery_(2022)_p197_385-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Dockery_(2022)_p197-385\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>365<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Author Daniel Dockery noted that \"from both a marketing perspective and, really, a legal perspective, it would not be to the company's advantage to keep pushing that slogan\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-Dockery_(2022)_p197_385-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Dockery_(2022)_p197-385\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>365<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>By 2002, the relationship between <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_USA\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Pokémon USA\">Pokémon USA</a> (PUSA) and Wizards of the Coast had deteriorated. That year, at least seven high-profile employees were <a href=\"/wiki/Employee_poaching\" title=\"Employee poaching\">poached</a> from Wizards by PUSA: Wizard's former art director, senior graphic designer, business manager, events marketing director, project management director, and two vice presidents. All employees had signed <a href=\"/wiki/Non-disclosure_agreement\" title=\"Non-disclosure agreement\">NDAs</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Cook_(2003)_386-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Cook_(2003)-386\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>366<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Engleman_(2003)_387-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Engleman_(2003)-387\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>367<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> In March 2003, PUSA told Wizards that their contract would not be renewed, and that Wizards would not be distributing the new <i>Ruby &amp; Sapphire</i> card set.<sup id=\"cite_ref-388\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-388\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>368<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Later, Wizards was also prohibited from releasing the sets <i>Jamboree</i> and <i>Legendary Collection II</i>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-389\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-389\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>369<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Notably, <i>Jamboree</i> was the first set containing cards designed by Wizards themselves. As considerable time and money was invested into creating them, Wizards was upset when they were barred from putting them out. On 1 October 2003, the day after their agreement expired, Wizards filed suit against Pokémon USA, alleging that the defendant had seized their intellectual property and trade secrets, and illegally tried to gain advantage over them in the competitive trading card market.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Cook_(2003)_386-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Cook_(2003)-386\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>366<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Engleman_(2003)_387-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Engleman_(2003)-387\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>367<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The case was settled out of court.<sup id=\"cite_ref-390\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-390\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>370<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <i>Jamboree</i> and <i>Legendary Collection II</i> have remained unreleased.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Engleman_(2003)_387-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Engleman_(2003)-387\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>367<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>In October 2001, <a href=\"/wiki/4Kids_Entertainment\" title=\"4Kids Entertainment\">4Kids Entertainment</a> signed a new contract with PUSA, continuing to serve as <i>Pokémon</i><span class=\"nowrap\" style=\"padding-left:0.1em;\">'</span>s exclusive licensing agent and anime localizer.<sup id=\"cite_ref-4Kids_another_5_Years_371-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-4Kids_another_5_Years-371\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>351<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> On 23 December 2005, it was announced that the agreement would not be renewed and would expire on 31 December, with PUSA moving all licensing in-house.<sup id=\"cite_ref-391\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-391\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>371<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-392\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-392\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>372<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The localization of the anime would be done by PUSA in cooperation with TAJ Productions. PUSA proceeded to replace almost all of the original English voice actors, who were still under contract with 4Kids.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Oak_Interview_393-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Oak_Interview-393\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>373<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> This decision \"raised the ire of fans and the actors themselves\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-394\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-394\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>374<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> According to <a href=\"/wiki/Stuart_Zagnit\" title=\"Stuart Zagnit\">Stuart Zagnit</a>, who voiced <a href=\"/wiki/Professor_Oak\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Professor Oak\">Professor Oak</a>, the recasting was done to cut back on costs.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Oak_Interview_393-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Oak_Interview-393\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>373<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>In March 2003, Pokémon UK was established in London as a British representative of <a href=\"/wiki/The_Pok%C3%A9mon_Company\" title=\"The Pokémon Company\">The Pokémon Company</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Company_History_362-3\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Company_History-362\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>343<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading3\"><h3 id=\"2006–2012:_Generation_IV–V,_TPCi_established\"><span id=\"2006.E2.80.932012:_Generation_IV.E2.80.93V.2C_TPCi_established\"></span>2006–2012: Generation IV–V, TPCi established</h3></div>\n<p>Following <i>Ruby and Sapphire</i>, <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Diamond_and_Pearl\" title=\"Pokémon Diamond and Pearl\"><i>Pokémon Diamond</i> and <i>Pearl</i></a> were released for the <a href=\"/wiki/Nintendo_DS\" title=\"Nintendo DS\">Nintendo DS</a> on 28 September 2006, in Japan<sup id=\"cite_ref-395\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-395\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>375<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> and on 22 April 2007, in North America.<sup id=\"cite_ref-396\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-396\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>376<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> A third version, <i><a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Platinum\" title=\"Pokémon Platinum\">Pokémon Platinum</a></i>, was released on 28 September 2008, in Japan<sup id=\"cite_ref-397\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-397\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>377<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> and on 22 March 2009, in North America.<sup id=\"cite_ref-398\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-398\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>378<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> They form the fourth generation (Generation IV) in the <i>Pokémon</i> video game series.<sup id=\"cite_ref-399\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-399\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>379<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <i>Diamond and Pearl</i> were designed based on the DS's various features such as its Wi-Fi capabilities and slot for Game Boy Advance cartridge.<sup id=\"cite_ref-400\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-400\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>380<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Pokémon president Tsunekazu Ishihara dubbed the games as the \"ultimate\" Pokémon titles because they allowed the player to trade and battle Pokémon including every Pokémon from previous iterations globally through WiFi, as opposed to previously only able to do so locally and with fewer Pokémon.<sup id=\"cite_ref-401\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-401\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>381<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The games' characters are 2D and the environments are rendered in 3D, and it is considerably difficult to differentiate them because Game Freak designed them this way to innovate the graphics while also retaining the traditional game style and feel.<sup id=\"cite_ref-402\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-402\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>382<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-403\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-403\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>383<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>In <i>Platinum,</i> the developers focused on changing the most essential elements from <i>Diamond</i> and <i>Pearl</i> to maintain continuity with the previous games. Director <a href=\"/wiki/Junichi_Masuda\" title=\"Junichi Masuda\">Junichi Masuda</a> stated that since they designed <i>Diamond and Pearl</i> as the \"ultimate\" <i>Pokémon</i> titles, it was only necessary to make <i>Platinum</i> \"even stronger\" than them. They approached this by designing the \"Origin Forme\" for the legendary Pokémon Giratina, ensuring that the design would appear significantly different from its regular form in <i>Diamond</i> and <i>Pearl</i> and to express the games' core antimatter and Distortion World concepts.<sup id=\"cite_ref-gamespot.com_404-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-gamespot.com-404\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>384<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The title Platinum was chosen to reflect a <a href=\"/wiki/Platinum\" title=\"Platinum\">precious material</a> that \"shines\" and is different from diamond and pearl and their associations of \"love\" and \"happiness\" respectively.<sup id=\"cite_ref-interview_405-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-interview-405\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>385<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_HeartGold_and_SoulSilver\" title=\"Pokémon HeartGold and SoulSilver\"><i>Pokémon HeartGold</i> and <i>SoulSilver</i></a> were released on 12 September 2009, in Japan and on 14 March 2010, in North America as part of Generation IV.<sup id=\"cite_ref-406\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-406\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>386<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-407\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-407\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>387<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> They are remakes of <i>Gold</i> and <i>Silver,</i><sup id=\"cite_ref-408\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-408\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>388<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> aiming to balance familiarity for the original games' players and new content for newcomers.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Morimoto_409-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Morimoto-409\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>389<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The titles reflected the theme of the bond between trainers and their Pokémon.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Morimoto_409-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Morimoto-409\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>389<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The developers faithfully recreated the original story and added elements from the Generation IV games and <i>Yellow</i>, the latter of which was released concurrently with <i>Gold</i> and <i>Silver.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Morimoto_409-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Morimoto-409\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>389<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-410\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-410\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>390<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup></i>\n</p><p>In 2009, Pokémon USA and Pokémon UK merged to form <a href=\"/wiki/The_Pok%C3%A9mon_Company_International\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"The Pokémon Company International\">The Pokémon Company International</a> (TPCi).<sup id=\"cite_ref-Daswani_(2009)_16-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Daswani_(2009)-16\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>13<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> This subsidiary of <a href=\"/wiki/The_Pok%C3%A9mon_Company\" title=\"The Pokémon Company\">The Pokémon Company</a> (TPC) has since managed the <i>Pokémon</i> franchise outside of Asia.<sup id=\"cite_ref-TPCi_About_Us_17-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-TPCi_About_Us-17\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>14<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>In Generation V, <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Black_and_White\" title=\"Pokémon Black and White\"><i>Pokémon Black</i> and <i>White</i></a> were released on 18 September 2010, in Japan for the DS<sup id=\"cite_ref-411\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-411\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>391<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> and on 6 March 2011, in North America.<sup id=\"cite_ref-412\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-412\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>392<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The games feature enhanced visual effects and increased use of 3D graphics. The developers excluded old Pokémon and strategies, while introducing over 150 new Pokémon to evoke a sense of novelty and to provide new players a more \"leveled playing field\" against old players.<sup id=\"cite_ref-413\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-413\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>393<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The games seek to attract both new players and returning players through its detailed walkthrough and the addition of C-Gear (a real-time communication tool to improve the trade and battle experiences), respectively.<sup id=\"cite_ref-414\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-414\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>394<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>The games were followed by <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Black_2_and_White_2\" title=\"Pokémon Black 2 and White 2\"><i>Pokémon Black 2</i> and <i>White 2</i></a><i>,</i> which were released on 23 June 2012, in Japan<sup id=\"cite_ref-415\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-415\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>395<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> and on 7 October 2012, in North America.<sup id=\"cite_ref-416\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-416\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>396<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The games were developed for the DS rather than the more powerful <a href=\"/wiki/Nintendo_3DS\" title=\"Nintendo 3DS\">Nintendo 3DS</a> to maintain continuity with the game world in <i>Black</i> and <i>White</i> and they were presented from a different perspective in the storyline.<sup id=\"cite_ref-417\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-417\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>397<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Since the games are their first sequels, director Masuda explained that they have strived to find a \"fine balance\" to appeal to both newcomers and returning players by implementing introductory explanations, and by placing a <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Center\" title=\"Pokémon Center\">Pokémon Center</a> in the first in-game city, they were able to further this approach by providing newcomers with a detailed walkthrough and also returning players with new updates.<sup id=\"cite_ref-418\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-418\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>398<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> During development phase, director Takao Unno revealed that they had experimented with a 100-player multiplayer experience via their communication feature Entralink drawing from their vision of players \"sharing the same space, same time and same game\" but this feature was never implemented due to technical limitations.<sup id=\"cite_ref-419\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-419\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>399<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading3\"><h3 id=\"2013–2018:_3D,_Generation_VI–VII,_Pokémon_Go\"><span id=\"2013.E2.80.932018:_3D.2C_Generation_VI.E2.80.93VII.2C_Pok.C3.A9mon_Go\"></span>2013–2018: 3D, Generation VI–VII, <i>Pokémon Go</i></h3></div>\n<p>In Generation VI, <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_X_and_Y\" title=\"Pokémon X and Y\"><i>Pokémon X</i> and <i>Y</i></a> were released worldwide for the 3DS on 12 October 2013,<sup id=\"cite_ref-420\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-420\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>400<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> and they are the first games to be released in this way. The developers focused on the themes of \"beauty\", \"bond\", and \"evolution\", and it is based on these themes that they created the games' core mechanic where Pokémon could achieve a higher form of evolution by strengthening their bonds with trainers; however, to maintain game balance, they limited this feature to a special, temporary phenomenon.<sup id=\"cite_ref-421\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-421\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>401<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The games' shift to fully 3D graphics allowed the player to freely manipulate the camera angles although due to technical limitations objects far away are rendered in lower <a href=\"/wiki/Polygonal_modeling\" title=\"Polygonal modeling\">polygon models</a>, and producer Hitoshi Yamagami addressed to 2D players that \"Game Freak [developers are also] big fans of 2D graphics... So there are some elements in there that I [Yamagami] think fans of 2D will appreciate as well.\"<sup id=\"cite_ref-Life_422-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Life-422\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>402<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> When asked about the Horde battle and Sky battle types, he stated that Horde battles are to supplant the roles of \"really strong pokemon  [<i><a href=\"/wiki/Sic\" title=\"Sic\">sic</a></i>]\" to help the player more easily progress through the games and also to add \"more excitement to the battles and a sense of danger\", and that they added the Sky battles to take advantage of the games' 3D camera angels capabilities.<sup id=\"cite_ref-423\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-423\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>403<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Omega_Ruby_and_Alpha_Sapphire\" title=\"Pokémon Omega Ruby and Alpha Sapphire\"><i>Pokémon Omega Ruby</i> and <i>Alpha Sapphire</i></a> were released worldwide for the 3DS on 21 November 2014<sup id=\"cite_ref-424\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-424\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>404<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> and on 28 November 2014, in Europe as part of Generation VI.<sup id=\"cite_ref-425\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-425\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>405<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> They are remakes of <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Ruby_and_Sapphire\" title=\"Pokémon Ruby and Sapphire\"><i>Ruby</i> and <i>Sapphire</i></a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-426\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-426\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>406<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The developers adopted <i>X</i> and <i>Y'</i>s core game mechanic and added enhanced 3D graphics.<sup id=\"cite_ref-427\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-427\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>407<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> According to director Masuda, they reviewed the original mechanic and concept and expressed them using modern hardware, such as replacing the original PokéGear feature for the enhanced versions BuzzNav and DexNav to more effectively provide information enabled by the games' hardware capabilities. They seek to explore the concept of Pokémon coexisting with humans and nature, revisiting the concept behind original games' setting, which translated to \"richness or abundance in nature and bonds between people and nature\" in Japanese. To appeal to the newer audience in <i>X</i> and <i>Y</i>, the developers decided to connect the story with <i>X</i> and <i>Y</i> by further exploring their core mechanic.<sup id=\"cite_ref-428\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-428\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>408<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>In Generation VII, <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Sun_and_Moon\" title=\"Pokémon Sun and Moon\"><i>Pokémon Sun</i> and <i>Moon</i></a> were released worldwide for the 3DS on 18 November 2016, and on 23 November 2016, in Europe.<sup id=\"cite_ref-429\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-429\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>409<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The developers chose Hawaii for inspiration due to its distinctive warm sunlight and clear moonlight and unique biomes that helped support the games' regional Pokémon variance concept. Ohmori said, as director, he aimed to focus on the concept of \"Pokémon as these living creatures, [and really focus] on them being alive.\" Having the release date on the 20th anniversary of Pokémon in mind, he treated this project as a \"celebration of that life, and to really express this respect for life\". As he contemplated about life and its origins, Ohmori considered the significance of the Sun, enabling life with its <a href=\"/wiki/Sunlight\" title=\"Sunlight\">light</a>, and the Moon's <a href=\"/wiki/Lunar_effect\" title=\"Lunar effect\">impact</a> on certain species' reproduction. He explained how the Sun, the Moon, and the Earth \"work [together] to influence [one another], and life as a result grows and flourishes based on [this] relationship.\"<sup id=\"cite_ref-430\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-430\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>410<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Ohmori stated that with the innovation to 3D in <i>X</i> and <i>Y</i> the designers decided to examine more minor aspects concerning with the Pokémon themselves such as their motions, such as when they designed the games' first starter Pokémon to capitalize on its owl-like characteristics with its head \"twists round and round\". With the 3DS technologies, the developers are able to design the characters to be more expressive as themselves including different facial expressions and reactions. In addition to portraying Pokémon harmoniously coexisting with people and vice versa in the games, the developers replaced the traditional Gym mechanic with Island Trials, deepening the players' connection with the story and their Pokémon.<sup id=\"cite_ref-431\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-431\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>411<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The enhanced versions <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Ultra_Sun_and_Ultra_Moon\" title=\"Pokémon Ultra Sun and Ultra Moon\"><i>Pokémon Ultra Sun</i> and <i>Ultra Moon</i></a> were released worldwide on 17 November 2017.<sup id=\"cite_ref-432\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-432\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>412<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The games added an alternate storyline and additional characters, Pokémon, and other features.<sup id=\"cite_ref-433\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-433\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>413<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Developer <a href=\"/wiki/Shigeki_Morimoto\" title=\"Shigeki Morimoto\">Shigeki Morimoto</a> revealed that they were developed by the younger staff members and veterans so the more veterans can prioritized on developing more important titles,<sup id=\"cite_ref-434\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-434\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>414<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> and the developers considered them to be their culmination with the 3DS.<sup id=\"cite_ref-435\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-435\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>415<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading4\"><h4 id=\"2016:_Release_of_Pokémon_Go\"><span id=\"2016:_Release_of_Pok.C3.A9mon_Go\"></span>2016: Release of <i>Pokémon Go</i></h4></div>\n<figure class=\"mw-default-size\" typeof=\"mw:File/Thumb\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Pokemon_go_fest.jpg\" class=\"mw-file-description\"><img src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Pokemon_go_fest.jpg/250px-Pokemon_go_fest.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"250\" height=\"188\" class=\"mw-file-element\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Pokemon_go_fest.jpg/500px-Pokemon_go_fest.jpg 1.5x\" data-file-width=\"4048\" data-file-height=\"3036\"></a><figcaption>Players during the <i>Pokémon Go</i> Fest in Chicago in 2017</figcaption></figure>\n<p>In 2016, the <i>Pokémon</i> franchise spawned a second worldwide fad with the release of <i><a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Go\" title=\"Pokémon Go\">Pokémon Go</a></i>, a mobile <a href=\"/wiki/Augmented_reality_game\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Augmented reality game\">augmented reality game</a>. The app originated as a <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_Google_April_Fools%27_Day_jokes\" title=\"List of Google April Fools' Day jokes\">Google April Fools' Day joke</a> in 2014: the \"<a href=\"/wiki/List_of_Google_April_Fools%27_Day_jokes#Google_Maps_Pokémon_Challenge\" title=\"List of Google April Fools' Day jokes\">Google Maps Pokémon Challenge</a>\". The prank was conceived by <a href=\"/wiki/Tsunekazu_Ishihara\" title=\"Tsunekazu Ishihara\">Tsunekazu Ishihara</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Satoru_Iwata\" title=\"Satoru Iwata\">Satoru Iwata</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-436\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-436\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>416<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> On Ishihara's initiation,<sup id=\"cite_ref-Takahasi_(2015)_437-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Takahasi_(2015)-437\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>417<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> the hoax was turned into an actual video game developed by <a href=\"/wiki/Niantic,_Inc.\" title=\"Niantic, Inc.\">Niantic</a>. Ishihara was a fan of Niantic's previous <a href=\"/wiki/Transreality_game\" title=\"Transreality game\">transreality game</a>, <i><a href=\"/wiki/Ingress_(video_game)\" title=\"Ingress (video game)\">Ingress</a></i>, and saw the game's concept as a perfect match for <i>Pokémon</i>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Takahasi_(2015)_437-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Takahasi_(2015)-437\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>417<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Through in-game purchases, the game generated more than <span style=\"white-space: nowrap\">$160&nbsp;million</span> by the end of July 2016,<sup id=\"cite_ref-438\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-438\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>418<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> with App Annie reporting that <i>Pokémon Go</i> had generated around <span style=\"white-space: nowrap\">$10&nbsp;million</span> in revenue every day that month.<sup id=\"cite_ref-439\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-439\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>419<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The same month, Sensor Tower reported that the game had passed more than <span style=\"white-space: nowrap\">$200&nbsp;million</span> in worldwide revenue, beating every existing record set by <i><a href=\"/wiki/Clash_of_Clans\" title=\"Clash of Clans\">Clash of Clans</a></i> and <i><a href=\"/wiki/Candy_Crush\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Candy Crush\">Candy Crush</a></i> by a wide margin.<sup id=\"cite_ref-440\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-440\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>420<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The average daily usage of the app on Android devices in July 2016 exceeded that of <a href=\"/wiki/Snapchat\" title=\"Snapchat\">Snapchat</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Tinder_(app)\" title=\"Tinder (app)\">Tinder</a>, Twitter, <a href=\"/wiki/Instagram\" title=\"Instagram\">Instagram</a>, and Facebook.<sup id=\"cite_ref-441\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-441\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>421<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> By 2 September 2016, <i>Pokémon Go</i> had generated more than $440&nbsp;million in worldwide revenue, according to Sensor Tower.<sup id=\"cite_ref-442\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-442\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>422<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> By 30 September, it had received <span class=\"nowrap\">500 million</span> downloads and grossed <span style=\"white-space: nowrap\">$470&nbsp;million</span> in 80 days, according to market research firm Newzoo.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Newzoo_report_443-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Newzoo_report-443\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>423<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <i>Pokémon Go</i> reached the milestone of $600&nbsp;million in revenue after only 90 days on the market, becoming the fastest mobile game ever to do so.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Makuch_(2016)_444-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Makuch_(2016)-444\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>424<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon:_Let%27s_Go,_Pikachu!_and_Let%27s_Go,_Eevee!\" title=\"Pokémon: Let's Go, Pikachu! and Let's Go, Eevee!\"><i>Pokémon: Let's Go, Pikachu!</i> and <i>Let's Go, Eevee!</i></a> were released for the <a href=\"/wiki/Nintendo_Switch\" title=\"Nintendo Switch\">Nintendo Switch</a> on 16 November 2018. They are part of Generation VII.<sup id=\"cite_ref-445\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-445\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>425<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Inspired by <i><a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Yellow\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Pokémon Yellow\">Pokémon Yellow</a>,</i> the games seek to introduce newcomers and a new generation of players (particularly <i>Pokémon Go</i> players) to the <i>Pokémon</i> series in addition to catering old players. As such, the games feature similar capture mechanics to <i>Go</i> where the player throws Poké Balls to catch wild Pokémon rather than battling them like traditional <i>Pokémon</i> games. In addition, the games feature the same setting and characters as the first generation of games and the original animated series, and include exclusively the original 151 Pokémon to further appeal to their targeted audience.<sup id=\"cite_ref-ReferenceA_446-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-ReferenceA-446\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>426<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-447\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-447\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>427<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The only new Pokémon featured are Meltan and Melmetal.<sup id=\"cite_ref-448\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-448\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>428<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading3\"><h3 id=\"2019–present:_Generation_VIII–IX,_open-world_gameplay\"><span id=\"2019.E2.80.93present:_Generation_VIII.E2.80.93IX.2C_open-world_gameplay\"></span>2019–present: Generation VIII–IX, open-world gameplay</h3></div>\n<p>Generation VIII<sup id=\"cite_ref-449\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-449\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>429<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> debuted with the release of <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Sword_and_Shield\" title=\"Pokémon Sword and Shield\"><i>Pokémon Sword</i> and <i>Shield</i></a> on 15 November 2019, for the Switch.<sup id=\"cite_ref-450\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-450\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>430<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Director Shigeru Ohmori stated that they designed the games based on what they believed of the biggest <i>Pokémon</i> theme of becoming/being \"the greatest or strongest\", which was expressed in the games' <a href=\"/wiki/Gameplay_of_Pok%C3%A9mon#Dynamax\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Gameplay of Pokémon\">Dynamax / Gigantamax</a> Pokémon core mechanic and the games' increasingly powerful software and hardware capabilities. Ohmori further revealed that through developing the <i>Let's Go</i> games as research projects for the Switch, they were able to gain valuable experiences and knowledge to develop <i>Sword</i> and <i>Shield</i>. He noted that they took advantage of the Switch's high resolution and TV connectivity to implement the games' gigantic-size core Pokémon mechanic. They envisioned the games' setting to be a \"wide-open space\" that is different from the traditional route systems and is constantly changing where the player can meet and explore with other players.<sup id=\"cite_ref-451\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-451\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>431<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Many pre-existing Pokémon are not available in <i>Sword</i> and <i>Shield</i>. This \"Dexit\", as it was called, led to fan backlash.<sup id=\"cite_ref-452\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-452\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>432<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <i>Sword</i> and <i>Shield</i> were the first <i>Pokémon</i> games to receive <a href=\"/wiki/Downloadable_content\" title=\"Downloadable content\">DLC</a> expansions: Part 1—<a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Sword_and_Shield:_The_Isle_of_Armor\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Pokémon Sword and Shield: The Isle of Armor\"><i>The Isle of Armor</i></a>, and Part 2—<a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Sword_and_Shield:_The_Crown_Tundra\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Pokémon Sword and Shield: The Crown Tundra\"><i>The Crown Tundra</i></a>; they were released on 17 June 2020, and 22 October 2020, respectively.<sup id=\"cite_ref-453\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-453\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>433<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> They include additional storylines, places, Pokémon, characters, and other features.<sup id=\"cite_ref-454\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-454\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>434<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>In 2020, the <a href=\"/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic\" title=\"COVID-19 pandemic\">COVID-19 pandemic</a> broke out. The resulting widespread ennui and excessive leisure time inspired a resurgence in popularity and interest of <i>Pokémon</i> cards,<sup id=\"cite_ref-455\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-455\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>435<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> which was further popularized by various <a href=\"/wiki/YouTuber\" title=\"YouTuber\">YouTubers</a> and other <a href=\"/wiki/Influencer\" title=\"Influencer\">influencers</a>, such as <a href=\"/wiki/Logan_Paul\" title=\"Logan Paul\">Logan Paul</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-456\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-456\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>436<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-457\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-457\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>437<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The craze resulted in severe supply shortages, and customers' inappropriate and obsessive behavior raised safety concerns in many retail outlets. <i>Pokémon</i> <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_most_expensive_CCG_cards\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"List of most expensive CCG cards\">cards' values skyrocketed</a>, prompting collectors to submit cards and overwhelm <a href=\"/wiki/Trading_card#Condition\" title=\"Trading card\">card grading agencies</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-458\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-458\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>438<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-459\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-459\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>439<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The Pokémon Company responded by reprinting impacted products at maximum capacity to ensure price stabilization and general accessibility.<sup id=\"cite_ref-460\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-460\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>440<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Remakes of <i>Diamond</i> and <i>Pearl</i>, <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Brilliant_Diamond_and_Shining_Pearl\" title=\"Pokémon Brilliant Diamond and Shining Pearl\"><i>Pokémon Brilliant Diamond</i> and <i>Shining Pearl</i></a> were released on 19 November 2021, for the Switch as part of Generation VIII.<sup id=\"cite_ref-461\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-461\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>441<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> They are the first <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_Pok%C3%A9mon_video_games#Main_series_games/remakes\" title=\"List of Pokémon video games\">core series</a> games to be developed by a third-party developer, ILCA, rather than Game Freak.<sup id=\"cite_ref-462\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-462\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>442<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The developers revealed that the games would not assume the anticipated style of the <i>Let's Go</i> Games and feature traditional game mechanics.<sup id=\"cite_ref-463\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-463\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>443<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <i>Pokémon</i> intends to celebrate their 25th anniversary with the release of the remakes by revisiting old games and mechanics, which they faithfully reproduced with enhanced 3D graphics.<sup id=\"cite_ref-464\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-464\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>444<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-465\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-465\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>445<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p><i><a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Legends:_Arceus\" title=\"Pokémon Legends: Arceus\">Pokémon Legends: Arceus</a></i> was released on 28 January 2022, for the Switch as a prequel to <i>Diamond</i> and <i>Pearl</i>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-466\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-466\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>446<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> It is part of Generation VIII.<sup id=\"cite_ref-467\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-467\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>447<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The game \"represents a new approach for the <i>Pokémon</i> video game series\" as it transitions from traditional RPG mechanics to add real-time elements in their games. Unlike traditional <i>Pokémon</i> games, the player can catch Pokémon by throwing a Poké Ball in real-time rather than triggering a battle; however, they can still choose the latter to weaken it for capture. Many in-game aspects, particularly its landscape, heavily resemble those of <i><a href=\"/wiki/The_Legend_of_Zelda:_Breath_of_the_Wild\" title=\"The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild\">The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild</a></i>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-468\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-468\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>448<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-469\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-469\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>449<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-470\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-470\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>450<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Generation IX<sup id=\"cite_ref-471\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-471\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>451<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> was introduced with the release of <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Scarlet_and_Violet\" title=\"Pokémon Scarlet and Violet\"><i>Pokémon Scarlet</i> and <i>Violet</i></a> for the Switch on 18 November 2022. The games are the first <i>Pokémon</i> games to feature an entirely open-world experience as opposed to the partially open-world experience in previous <i>Pokémon</i> games such as <i>Sword and Shield,</i> and it also departed from the traditional gym mechanics and the elite four battles to opt for unique road quests. The games' improved multiplayer experience allowed for up to four players to travel together.<sup id=\"cite_ref-472\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-472\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>452<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-473\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-473\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>453<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Their DLC, <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Scarlet_and_Violet:_The_Hidden_Treasure_of_Area_Zero\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Pokémon Scarlet and Violet: The Hidden Treasure of Area Zero\"><i>The Hidden Treasure of Area Zero</i></a>, consists of two parts, <i>The Teal Mask</i> and <i>The Indigo Disk</i>; <i>The Teal Mask</i> was released on 12–13 September 2023<sup id=\"cite_ref-474\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-474\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>454<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> and <i>The Indigo Disk</i> was released on 14 December 2023.<sup id=\"cite_ref-475\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-475\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>455<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> An epilogue to <i>The Hidden Treasure of Area Zero</i> was released on 11 January 2024.<sup id=\"cite_ref-476\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-476\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>456<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p><i><a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Legends:_Z-A\" title=\"Pokémon Legends: Z-A\">Pokémon Legends: Z-A</a></i> was released on 16 October 2025 for the <a href=\"/wiki/Nintendo_Switch\" title=\"Nintendo Switch\">Nintendo Switch</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Nintendo_Switch_2\" title=\"Nintendo Switch 2\">Nintendo Switch 2</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-477\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-477\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>457<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-478\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-478\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>458<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> It is part of Generation IX. A successor to <i>Legends: Arceus</i>, this game returns to the Kalos region seen in <i>X</i> and <i>Y</i>. A DLC, <i>Mega Dimension</i>, is planned for release on 10 December 2025.<sup id=\"cite_ref-479\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-479\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>459<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>By 2024, the <i>Pokémon</i> franchise had earned a total of 100 billion US dollars, making it the highest-grossing media franchise ever.<sup id=\"cite_ref-TIME_19-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-TIME-19\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>16<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup class=\"reference nowrap\"><span title=\"Page / location: 53\">: 53 </span></sup>\n</p>\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading2\"><h2 id=\"Media\">Media</h2></div>\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading3\"><h3 id=\"Video_games\">Video games</h3></div>\n<link rel=\"mw-deduplicated-inline-style\" href=\"mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320\"><div role=\"note\" class=\"hatnote navigation-not-searchable\">Main articles: <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_(video_game_series)\" title=\"Pokémon (video game series)\">Pokémon (video game series)</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_Pok%C3%A9mon_video_games\" title=\"List of Pokémon video games\">List of Pokémon video games</a></div>\n<p><i>Pokémon</i> video games have been released in a wide variety of genres. The <a href=\"/wiki/Role-playing_game\" title=\"Role-playing game\">role-playing games</a> (RPGs) developed by <a href=\"/wiki/Game_Freak\" title=\"Game Freak\">Game Freak</a> are considered the core series of the franchise.<sup id=\"cite_ref-480\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-480\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>460<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-481\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-481\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>461<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-482\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-482\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>462<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Various spin-off games also exist, such as <i><a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Mystery_Dungeon\" title=\"Pokémon Mystery Dungeon\">Pokémon Mystery Dungeon</a></i>, a <a href=\"/wiki/Roguelike\" title=\"Roguelike\">roguelike RPG</a> series, <i><a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Ranger\" title=\"Pokémon Ranger\">Pokémon Ranger</a></i>, an <a href=\"/wiki/Action_RPG\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Action RPG\">action RPG</a> series, and <i><a href=\"/wiki/Detective_Pikachu_(video_game)\" title=\"Detective Pikachu (video game)\">Detective Pikachu</a></i> (2018), an <a href=\"/wiki/Adventure_game\" title=\"Adventure game\">adventure game</a>. <i>Pokémon</i> games, in particular the core RPGs, are commonly classified in generations. For example, <a href=\"/wiki/Junichi_Masuda\" title=\"Junichi Masuda\">Junichi Masuda</a> referred to <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Diamond_and_Pearl\" title=\"Pokémon Diamond and Pearl\"><i>Diamond</i> and <i>Pearl</i></a> (2006) as Gen 4,<sup id=\"cite_ref-483\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-483\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>463<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> and <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_X_and_Y\" title=\"Pokémon X and Y\"><i>X</i> and <i>Y</i></a> (2013) as the 6th generation.<sup id=\"cite_ref-484\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-484\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>464<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Until 2011, <i>Pokémon</i> games were released exclusively on <a href=\"/wiki/Nintendo_video_game_consoles\" title=\"Nintendo video game consoles\">Nintendo's consoles</a>. With the rise of the <a href=\"/wiki/Smartphone\" title=\"Smartphone\">smartphone</a> during the 2010s, <a href=\"/wiki/The_Pok%C3%A9mon_Company\" title=\"The Pokémon Company\">The Pokémon Company</a> also began developing, publishing, and licensing <i>Pokémon</i> titles for the mobile phone market, most notably <i><a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Go\" title=\"Pokémon Go\">Pokémon Go</a></i> (2016), an <a href=\"/wiki/Augmented_reality_game\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Augmented reality game\">augmented reality game</a> developed by <a href=\"/wiki/Niantic,_Inc.\" title=\"Niantic, Inc.\">Niantic</a> that spawned a worldwide craze in the summer of 2016.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Newzoo_report_443-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Newzoo_report-443\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>423<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Makuch_(2016)_444-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Makuch_(2016)-444\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>424<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>According to the official website of <a href=\"/wiki/The_Pok%C3%A9mon_Company\" title=\"The Pokémon Company\">The Pokémon Company</a>, as of March&nbsp;2025<sup class=\"plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update\" style=\"display:none;\"><a class=\"external text\" href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pok%C3%A9mon&amp;action=edit\">[update]</a></sup>, over 489 million <i>Pokémon</i> game units have been sold worldwide.<sup id=\"cite_ref-In_figures_485-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-In_figures-485\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>465<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading3\"><h3 id=\"Trading_card_game_2\">Trading card game</h3></div>\n<link rel=\"mw-deduplicated-inline-style\" href=\"mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320\"><div role=\"note\" class=\"hatnote navigation-not-searchable\">Main articles: <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Trading_Card_Game\" title=\"Pokémon Trading Card Game\">Pokémon Trading Card Game</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_Pok%C3%A9mon_Trading_Card_Game_sets\" title=\"List of Pokémon Trading Card Game sets\">List of Pokémon Trading Card Game sets</a></div>\n<figure class=\"mw-default-size\" typeof=\"mw:File/Thumb\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:DP01_011_Palkia.jpg\" class=\"mw-file-description\"><img src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/e/e8/DP01_011_Palkia.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"215\" height=\"300\" class=\"mw-file-element\" data-file-width=\"215\" data-file-height=\"300\"></a><figcaption><a href=\"/wiki/Palkia\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Palkia\">Palkia</a>, a card from the <i><a href=\"/wiki/List_of_Pok%C3%A9mon_Trading_Card_Game_sets#Diamond_and_Pearl_Base_Set\" title=\"List of Pokémon Trading Card Game sets\">Diamond and Pearl Base Set</a></i></figcaption></figure>\n<p>The <i><a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Trading_Card_Game\" title=\"Pokémon Trading Card Game\">Pokémon Trading Card Game</a></i> (PTCG) was one of the first <a href=\"/wiki/Collectable_card_game\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Collectable card game\">collectable card games</a> (CCGs) in Japan. It was inspired by <i><a href=\"/wiki/Magic:_The_Gathering\" title=\"Magic: The Gathering\">Magic: The Gathering</a></i>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p153_161-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p153-161\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>150<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Pokemon_Business_Study_Group_(1998)_p112-117_162-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Pokemon_Business_Study_Group_(1998)_p112-117-162\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>151<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Kimura_2006_163-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Kimura_2006-163\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>152<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> In the card game, the players use a 60-card deck featuring Basic and evolved Pokémon, Energy cards, and Trainer cards to help them knock out the opponent's Pokémon, drawing prize cards and winning the game.<sup id=\"cite_ref-486\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-486\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>466<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Cards are classified into various levels of rarity, ranging from Common to Rare Holofoil with a holographic illustration. Rare cards, including limited edition, exclusive cards, and older cards, are highly valued among collectors due to their scarcity.<sup id=\"cite_ref-487\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-487\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>467<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-488\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-488\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>468<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>According to the official website of <a href=\"/wiki/The_Pok%C3%A9mon_Company\" title=\"The Pokémon Company\">The Pokémon Company</a>, over 75&nbsp;billion cards have been printed as of March&nbsp;2025<sup class=\"plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update\" style=\"display:none;\"><a class=\"external text\" href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pok%C3%A9mon&amp;action=edit\">[update]</a></sup>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-In_figures_485-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-In_figures-485\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>465<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading3\"><h3 id=\"Anime\">Anime</h3></div>\n<link rel=\"mw-deduplicated-inline-style\" href=\"mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320\"><div role=\"note\" class=\"hatnote navigation-not-searchable\">Main articles: <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_(TV_series)\" title=\"Pokémon (TV series)\">Pokémon (TV series)</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_Pok%C3%A9mon_films\" title=\"List of Pokémon films\">List of Pokémon films</a></div>\n<p>As of 2025<sup class=\"plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update\" style=\"display:none;\"><a class=\"external text\" href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pok%C3%A9mon&amp;action=edit\">[update]</a></sup>, the <i>Pokémon</i> anime consists of <a href=\"/wiki/Lists_of_Pok%C3%A9mon_episodes\" title=\"Lists of Pokémon episodes\">over 1,300 episodes across 28 seasons</a>. Its current season, <i><a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Horizons_%E2%80%93_Rising_Hope\" title=\"Pokémon Horizons – Rising Hope\">Pokémon Horizons – Rising Hope</a></i>, started airing on 11 April 2025. The anime originally focused on <a href=\"/wiki/Ash_Ketchum\" title=\"Ash Ketchum\">Ash Ketchum</a> and his travels across the Pokémon world with his partner, <a href=\"/wiki/Pikachu\" title=\"Pikachu\">Pikachu</a>. They were retired as protagonists at the end of season 25.<sup id=\"cite_ref-489\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-489\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>469<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The 26th season, <i><a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Horizons:_The_Series\" title=\"Pokémon Horizons: The Series\">Pokémon Horizons</a></i>, introduced two new protagonists, <a href=\"/wiki/Liko_(Pok%C3%A9mon)\" title=\"Liko (Pokémon)\">Liko</a> and Roy.<sup id=\"cite_ref-490\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-490\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>470<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> A total of <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_Pok%C3%A9mon_films\" title=\"List of Pokémon films\">23 anime films</a> have been released, the most recent being <i><a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_the_Movie:_Secrets_of_the_Jungle\" title=\"Pokémon the Movie: Secrets of the Jungle\">Pokémon the Movie: Secrets of the Jungle</a></i> (2020).<sup id=\"cite_ref-491\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-491\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>471<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Spin-off series from the anime have also been produced, including a variety show titled <i>Weekly Pokémon Broadcasting Station</i><span style=\"font-weight: normal\"> (<span title=\"Japanese-language text\"><span lang=\"ja\">週刊ポケモン放送局</span></span>, <span title=\"Hepburn transliteration\"><i lang=\"ja-Latn\">Shūkan Pokemon Hōsōkyoku</i></span>)</span>, which aired on <a href=\"/wiki/TV_Tokyo\" title=\"TV Tokyo\">TV Tokyo</a> from 2002 to 2004 and aired in English as part of <i><a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Chronicles\" title=\"Pokémon Chronicles\">Pokémon Chronicles</a></i>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-492\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-492\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>472<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-493\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-493\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>473<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_Pok%C3%A9mon_films#Television_specials\" title=\"List of Pokémon films\">Several television specials</a> have been released. <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_Pok%C3%A9mon_films#Pikachu_shorts\" title=\"List of Pokémon films\">27 short films starring Pikachu</a> were produced, primarily preceding the films.<sup id=\"cite_ref-494\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-494\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>474<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Various animated mini-series also exist.\n</p>\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading3\"><h3 id=\"Live-action\">Live-action</h3></div>\n<p><i><a href=\"/wiki/Detective_Pikachu_(film)\" title=\"Detective Pikachu (film)\">Detective Pikachu</a></i>, a <a href=\"/wiki/Live-action/animated_film\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Live-action/animated film\">live-action/animated film</a> based on <a href=\"/wiki/Detective_Pikachu_(video_game)\" title=\"Detective Pikachu (video game)\">the video game of the same name</a>, was released in 2019.<sup id=\"cite_ref-495\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-495\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>475<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/Detective_Pikachu_(film)#Sequel\" title=\"Detective Pikachu (film)\">A sequel</a> was announced even before the original premiered.<sup id=\"cite_ref-496\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-496\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>476<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> However, despite a number of updates over the next few years, the film did not materialize. As of 2025<sup class=\"plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update\" style=\"display:none;\"><a class=\"external text\" href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pok%C3%A9mon&amp;action=edit\">[update]</a></sup>, the status of the sequel is not known.\n</p><p>A live-action television drama produced by The Pokémon Company and <a href=\"/wiki/TV_Tokyo\" title=\"TV Tokyo\">TV Tokyo</a>, titled <i><a href=\"https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E3%83%9D%E3%82%B1%E3%83%83%E3%83%88%E3%81%AB%E5%86%92%E9%99%BA%E3%82%92%E3%81%A4%E3%82%81%E3%81%93%E3%82%93%E3%81%A7\" class=\"extiw\" title=\"jp:ポケットに冒険をつめこんで\">Poketto ni Bōken o Tsumekonde</a></i> (\"A Pocketful of Adventures\"), premiered on TV Tokyo on 20 October 2023.<sup id=\"cite_ref-497\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-497\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>477<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading2\"><h2 id=\"Reaction_to_Pokémania_(1999–2000)\"><span id=\"Reaction_to_Pok.C3.A9mania_.281999.E2.80.932000.29\"></span>Reaction to Pokémania (1999–2000)</h2></div>\n<figure class=\"mw-halign-right\" typeof=\"mw:File/Thumb\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Pikachu_on_New_Yorker_cover,_Nov_1_1999.jpg\" class=\"mw-file-description\"><img src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/1/18/Pikachu_on_New_Yorker_cover%2C_Nov_1_1999.jpg/250px-Pikachu_on_New_Yorker_cover%2C_Nov_1_1999.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"235\" height=\"326\" class=\"mw-file-element\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/1/18/Pikachu_on_New_Yorker_cover%2C_Nov_1_1999.jpg 1.5x\" data-file-width=\"268\" data-file-height=\"372\"></a><figcaption>1 November 1999 cover of <i><a href=\"/wiki/The_New_Yorker\" title=\"The New Yorker\">The New Yorker</a></i>, which depicts a <a href=\"/wiki/Pikachu\" title=\"Pikachu\">Pikachu</a> carrying away a bag overflowing with money while <a href=\"/wiki/Trick-or-treating\" title=\"Trick-or-treating\">trick-or-treating</a>. Artwork by <a href=\"/wiki/Harry_Bliss\" title=\"Harry Bliss\">Harry Bliss</a>.</figcaption></figure>\n<p>In 1999 and 2000, <i>Pokémon</i> was an unprecedented, ubiquitous <a href=\"/wiki/Fad\" title=\"Fad\">fad</a> in the Western world. <i><a href=\"/wiki/Time_(magazine)\" title=\"Time (magazine)\">Time</a></i> magazine described it as \"a multimedia and interactive barrage like no other before it\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-Chua-Eoan_Larimer_(1999)_32-6\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Chua-Eoan_Larimer_(1999)-32\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>27<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The franchise, primarily aimed at children, elicited mixed responses from parents and teachers, some of them critical. In a 2004 essay, anthropologist Christine R. Yano even claimed that the reactions at one point constituted a <a href=\"/wiki/Moral_panic\" title=\"Moral panic\">moral panic</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-498\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-498\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>478<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>The bulk of the criticism on <i>Pokémon</i> was directed at <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Trading_Card_Game\" title=\"Pokémon Trading Card Game\">the trading cards</a>,<sup id=\"cite_ref-Brougère_(2004)_p187-188_499-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Brougère_(2004)_p187-188-499\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>479<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> in particular the <a href=\"/wiki/Booster_pack\" title=\"Booster pack\">booster packs</a>, sealed packages of 11<sup id=\"cite_ref-boosters_177-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-boosters-177\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>g<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> randomly inserted cards that were sold separately from the main sets. The cards are of varying scarcity, the most valuable being the \"holofoil cards\" (also called \"holographic\" or \"foil cards\"), in which the illustrations of the Pokémon have a shiny overlay effect. The rare cards can only be found in booster packs, and the rarest ones are very infrequently included. <a href=\"/wiki/Joseph_Tobin\" title=\"Joseph Tobin\">Joseph Tobin</a> noted that rarity in this case is \"artificially created\", and \"effectively a form of gambling\" in which children need to repeatedly purchase booster packs to get more rare cards.<sup id=\"cite_ref-500\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-500\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>480<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Gilles_Broug%C3%A8re&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1\" class=\"new\" title=\"Gilles Brougère (page does not exist)\">Gilles Brougère</a><span class=\"noprint\" style=\"font-size:85%; font-style: normal;\">&nbsp;[<a href=\"https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gilles_Broug%C3%A8re\" class=\"extiw\" title=\"fr:Gilles Brougère\">fr</a>]</span> described a cynicism among adults that corporations could apparently, \"out of thin air\", ascribe value to cards which they saw as valueless, thereby \"deceiving vulnerable young consumers and garnering excessive profits\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-Brougère_(2004)_p187-188_499-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Brougère_(2004)_p187-188-499\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>479<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>As the franchise's popularity grew, children began taking their <i>Pokémon</i> cards to school for trading and playing. Soon, the cards were alleged to be \"disrupting learning, poisoning playground friendships and causing such distraction that some children forget their homework, tune out in class and even miss school buses as they scramble to acquire one more card\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-501\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-501\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>481<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The cards were \"turning the playground into a black market\",<sup id=\"cite_ref-502\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-502\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>482<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> with card swaps sometimes inciting conflicts. Certain children engaged in \"aggressive trading\",<sup id=\"cite_ref-Schools_ban_Pokémon_cards_503-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Schools_ban_Pokémon_cards-503\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>483<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> tricking other (often younger) kids into unfair deals, forcing teachers to arbitrate.<sup id=\"cite_ref-508\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-508\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>XI<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Some parents expressed their concerns about the craze, but feared that their children would be ostracized if they were to deny them <i>Pokémon</i> products.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Schools_ban_Pokémon_cards_503-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Schools_ban_Pokémon_cards-503\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>483<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-509\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-509\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>488<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-510\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-510\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>489<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> In the US, the <i>Pokémon</i> cards ended up \"almost universally banned\" from school grounds.<sup id=\"cite_ref-511\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-511\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>490<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Similar bans occurred in Canada,<sup id=\"cite_ref-512\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-512\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>491<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-513\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-513\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>492<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Australia,<sup id=\"cite_ref-schoolyard_bad_behaviour_514-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-schoolyard_bad_behaviour-514\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>493<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> New Zealand,<sup id=\"cite_ref-515\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-515\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>494<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> and European countries.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Schools_ban_Pokémon_cards_503-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Schools_ban_Pokémon_cards-503\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>483<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Montgomery_(2000)_516-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Montgomery_(2000)-516\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>495<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-517\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-517\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>496<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> In September 1999, US-based law firm <a href=\"/wiki/Milberg\" title=\"Milberg\">Milberg</a> filed a <a href=\"/wiki/Class-action_lawsuit\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Class-action lawsuit\">class-action lawsuit</a> against Nintendo of America, Wizards of the Coast, and 4Kids. The suit claimed that the booster packs constitute a form of lottery and promote gambling in kids.<sup id=\"cite_ref-518\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-518\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>497<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-519\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-519\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>498<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/Susan_Estrich\" title=\"Susan Estrich\">Susan Estrich</a> noted that similar lawsuits had been filed against trading-card makers in the US, without success.<sup id=\"cite_ref-520\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-520\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>499<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The <i>Pokémon</i> card suit is not known to have gone to court, and is believed to have been settled.<sup id=\"cite_ref-522\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-522\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>k<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_(TV_series)\" title=\"Pokémon (TV series)\"><i>Pokémon</i> anime series</a> was criticized by some as \"cheap Japanese animation\"<sup id=\"cite_ref-Allison_(2006)_p261_523-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Allison_(2006)_p261-523\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>501<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> that is \"violent\"<sup id=\"cite_ref-Plotz_(1999)_33-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Plotz_(1999)-33\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>28<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-524\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-524\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>502<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-525\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-525\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>503<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> and has \"little educational value\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-526\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-526\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>504<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Michelle Orecklin of <i>Time</i> dismissed the TV series as \"less a cartoon than a half-hour exercise in Pokémon product placement\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-527\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-527\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>505<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/Anne_Allison\" title=\"Anne Allison\">Anne Allison</a> wrote that even those within Pokémon's US marketing team agreed that the anime's visuals were \"not especially sophisticated\" compared to <a href=\"/wiki/Disney\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Disney\">Disney</a> cartoons.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Allison_(2006)_p261_523-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Allison_(2006)_p261-523\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>501<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <i><a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon:_The_First_Movie\" title=\"Pokémon: The First Movie\">Pokémon: The First Movie</a></i> premiered in the United States on 12 November 1999, and in European countries in February 2000. While a huge box-office success, the film was received negatively by several Western film critics.<sup id=\"cite_ref-528\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-528\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>506<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-529\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-529\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>507<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <i><a href=\"/wiki/The_Guardian\" title=\"The Guardian\">The Guardian</a></i> decried it as a \"contemptuously cheap animated cash-in on the monster kids' craze\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-530\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-530\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>508<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The American adult animated series <i><a href=\"/wiki/South_Park\" title=\"South Park\">South Park</a></i> satirized <i>Pokémon</i> in the episode \"<a href=\"/wiki/Chinpokomon\" title=\"Chinpokomon\">Chinpokomon</a>\", aired on 3 November 1999. In the episode, the titular media franchise is portrayed as a low-quality line of products that is part of an evil plan by the Japanese government to invade the US. <i>South Park</i> co-creator <a href=\"/wiki/Matt_Stone\" title=\"Matt Stone\">Matt Stone</a> commented that, at the time, <i>Pokémon</i> was \"scary huge\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-531\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-531\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>509<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Author Chris Kohler wrote that <i>Pokémon</i> was considered \"ruthlessly commercial\", and that it \"program[med] children to be consumers of anything and everything Pokémon\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-532\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-532\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>510<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/CNN\" title=\"CNN\">CNN</a> quoted child psychiatrist John Lochridge as worrying that \"Pokémon's creators and marketers deliberately set out to create a fantasy world so compelling that children would quickly become obsessed\". He believed that kids were being \"brainwashed\", and said: \"I have had parents tell me that they cannot get their kids to do anything except Pokémon, so this stuff seems to really capture their minds, in a way\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-Lockridge_(1999)_8-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Lockridge_(1999)-8\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>6<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> These concerns were countered by psychologist <a href=\"/wiki/William_Damon\" title=\"William Damon\">William Damon</a>, who told <i><a href=\"/wiki/Newsweek\" title=\"Newsweek\">Newsweek</a></i> that obsessing is in fact a normal part of a child's neurological development. It should concern parents only when the obsession gets dangerous or excessive.<sup id=\"cite_ref-533\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-533\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>511<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> An <a href=\"/wiki/Op-ed\" title=\"Op-ed\">op-ed</a> in the New Zealander newspaper <i><a href=\"/wiki/The_Dominion_Post_(Wellington)\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"The Dominion Post (Wellington)\">The Dominion Post</a></i> claimed that the anti-Pokémon sentiment was particularly American: \"The backlash, which seems largely confined to the United States, may be no more than the sound of the world's leading cultural imperialist gagging on a taste of its own medicine\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-534\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-534\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>512<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>As Pokémania built, Western media started reporting on several crimes associated with <i>Pokémon</i>. These included violence<sup id=\"cite_ref-schoolyard_bad_behaviour_514-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-schoolyard_bad_behaviour-514\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>493<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Cox_(1999)_535-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Cox_(1999)-535\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>513<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> (including two reported stabbings),<sup id=\"cite_ref-536\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-536\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>514<span
