class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-537\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-537\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>515<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> burglaries,<sup id=\"cite_ref-538\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-538\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>516<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Pokemon_card_crime_539-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Pokemon_card_crime-539\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>517<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> robberies<sup id=\"cite_ref-Montgomery_(2000)_516-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Montgomery_(2000)-516\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>495<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Cox_(1999)_535-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Cox_(1999)-535\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>513<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> (some at knifepoint),<sup id=\"cite_ref-Clothier_(2000)_540-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Clothier_(2000)-540\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>518<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-541\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-541\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>519<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> and shoplifting.<sup id=\"cite_ref-542\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-542\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>520<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-543\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-543\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>521<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Almost all these incidents were connected to the <i>Pokémon</i> cards, and the individuals involved were almost always underage. In the US, the incidents peaked in November 1999.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Yano_(2004)_p121_345-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Yano_(2004)_p121-345\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>327<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> In England, <i>Pokémon</i>-related delinquency reached a head in April 2000.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Clothier_(2000)_540-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Clothier_(2000)-540\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>518<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-544\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-544\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>522<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> High prices on the <a href=\"/wiki/Grey_market\" title=\"Grey market\">grey market</a> were a motive behind some of the crimes, \"posing a great temptation for older kids and bullies to take advantage of weaker children\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-545\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-545\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>523<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> At specialty shops and online auctions, a rare <i>Pokémon</i> card could be bought and sold for $50 or more (c. $94 in 2024).<sup id=\"cite_ref-546\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-546\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>524<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-547\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-547\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>525<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Aside from the negative reactions, many media also cited alleged beneficial effects of <i>Pokémon</i>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-548\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-548\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>526<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-549\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-549\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>527<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-550\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-550\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>528<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> It was noted that the video games and the cards require children to read, memorize, calculate, and plan out a strategy.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Mcfarland_Parvaz_(1999)_7-3\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Mcfarland_Parvaz_(1999)-7\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>5<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p246-247_179-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p246-247-179\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>167<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-551\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-551\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>529<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Both encourage socialization, and trading Pokémon requires negotiating skills.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Lockridge_(1999)_8-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Lockridge_(1999)-8\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>6<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Baylis_(1999)_20-4\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Baylis_(1999)-20\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>17<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Liu_(1999)_27-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Liu_(1999)-27\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>23<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/Stephanie_Strom\" title=\"Stephanie Strom\">Stephanie Strom</a> wrote in <i><a href=\"/wiki/The_New_York_Times\" title=\"The New York Times\">The New York Times</a></i> that the <i>Pokémon</i> anime taught children \"traditional Japanese values – responsibility, empathy, cooperation, obedience, respect for elders, humility\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-552\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-552\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>530<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/Anne_Allison\" title=\"Anne Allison\">Anne Allison</a> interviewed various American parents during Pokémania. She found that while most of them were \"utterly mystified\" about <i>Pokémon</i>, few were overly worried about it, instead meeting the craze with \"befuddled acceptance\". Allison also notes that the <a href=\"/wiki/Columbine_High_School_massacre\" title=\"Columbine High School massacre\">Columbine High School massacre</a> occurred during Pokémania (on 20 April 1999), causing violent television, music, and games to be scrutinized. Compared to these media, she notes, <i>Pokémon</i> is in fact rather tame.<sup id=\"cite_ref-553\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-553\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>531<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>In contrast, <i>Pokémon</i> received far less criticism in its native country of Japan. Anthropologist Christine R. Yano attributes this to <a href=\"/wiki/Cultural_differences\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Cultural differences\">cultural differences</a>, which includes: 1) greater acceptance of exuberant <a href=\"/wiki/Consumerism\" title=\"Consumerism\">consumerism</a> – to buy is to be a good citizen; 2) less focus on <a href=\"/wiki/Media_influence\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Media influence\">media influence</a> – instead, <a href=\"/wiki/Education_in_Japan\" title=\"Education in Japan\">Japan's educational system</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Education_in_Japan#Bullying\" title=\"Education in Japan\">bullying</a>, and dysfunctional families are more often the target of attention; 3) less separation between child- and adulthood – what is suitable for adults is not necessarily considered unsuitable for kids; 4) Pokémon being permeated with <i><a href=\"/wiki/Kawaisa\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Kawaisa\">kawaisa</a></i> (<a href=\"/wiki/Cuteness\" title=\"Cuteness\">cuteness</a>), a hallmark of Japanese culture; 5) Japan's core religions, <a href=\"/wiki/Buddhism\" title=\"Buddhism\">Buddhism</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Shinto\" title=\"Shinto\">Shinto</a>, are less moralizing in nature.<sup id=\"cite_ref-554\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-554\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>532<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> However, <a href=\"/wiki/Oliver_Burkeman\" title=\"Oliver Burkeman\">Oliver Burkeman</a> wrote in <i><a href=\"/wiki/The_Guardian\" title=\"The Guardian\">The Guardian</a></i> that the <i>Pokémon</i> cards were also banned from some Japanese schools.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Burkeman_(2000)_35-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Burkeman_(2000)-35\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>30<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading2\"><h2 id=\"Legacy_and_influences\">Legacy and influences</h2></div>\n<link rel=\"mw-deduplicated-inline-style\" href=\"mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320\"><div role=\"note\" class=\"hatnote navigation-not-searchable\">See also: <a href=\"/wiki/Cool_Japan\" title=\"Cool Japan\">Cool Japan</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Anime_and_manga_fandom\" title=\"Anime and manga fandom\">Anime and manga fandom</a></div>\n<p>After <a href=\"/wiki/World_War_II\" title=\"World War II\">World War II</a>, Japan experienced <a href=\"/wiki/Japanese_economic_miracle\" title=\"Japanese economic miracle\">a period of unprecedented growth</a> and became well-known in the Western world for its consumer products, such as <a href=\"/wiki/Transistor_radio#Japanese_transistor_radios\" title=\"Transistor radio\">radios</a> (e.g. <a href=\"/wiki/Panasonic\" title=\"Panasonic\">Panasonic</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Toshiba\" title=\"Toshiba\">Toshiba</a>), <a href=\"/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_Japan\" title=\"Automotive industry in Japan\">cars</a> (e.g. <a href=\"/wiki/Toyota\" title=\"Toyota\">Toyota</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Mitsubishi\" title=\"Mitsubishi\">Mitsubishi</a>), and <a href=\"/wiki/Sony\" title=\"Sony\">Sony</a>'s <a href=\"/wiki/Walkman\" title=\"Walkman\">Walkman</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-555\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-555\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>533<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> From 1991 onwards, <a href=\"/wiki/Lost_Decades\" title=\"Lost Decades\">its economy stagnated</a>, causing the country to lose its status as an economic superpower. However, during the 1990s and 2000s, Japan re-emerged as a source of 'cool' cultural goods, embraced by a growing international audience interested in <a href=\"/wiki/Japanese_culture\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Japanese culture\">Japanese culture</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-560\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-560\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>XII<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/Nintendo\" title=\"Nintendo\">Nintendo</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Sega\" title=\"Sega\">Sega</a>, and Sony launched several popular video game consoles and franchises.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Eisenberg_(1998)_261-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Eisenberg_(1998)-261\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>248<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-561\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-561\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>538<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-562\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-562\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>539<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> In terms of children's properties, the success of <i><a href=\"/wiki/Mighty_Morphin_Power_Rangers\" title=\"Mighty Morphin Power Rangers\">Mighty Morphin Power Rangers</a></i> changed perceptions on the viability of such Japanese imports in the West.<sup id=\"cite_ref-563\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-563\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>540<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-564\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-564\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>541<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-565\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-565\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>542<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The <a href=\"/wiki/Tamagotchi\" title=\"Tamagotchi\">Tamagotchi</a> fad (1997–98),<sup id=\"cite_ref-566\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-566\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>543<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> centered around a portable <a href=\"/wiki/Digital_pet\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Digital pet\">digital pet</a> device, was said to have \"paved the way for Pokémon\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-Gellene_(1998)_260-4\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Gellene_(1998)-260\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>247<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/Anne_Allison\" title=\"Anne Allison\">Anne Allison</a> wrote that, before the 1990s, Japan figured little in the face of the worldwide hegemony of Euro-American cultural industries, in particular that of the US. \"Hollywood has been hostile to imports\", she wrote, \"and foreignness has largely been, and been seen as, an impediment to mass popularization in the United States\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-567\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-567\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>544<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The surprise success of <i>Pokémon</i> was \"an undeniable breakthrough in the homeland of <a href=\"/wiki/Disney\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Disney\">Disney</a>\" that \"changed preexisting assumptions about the US marketplace at the same time that it was constantly resisted for deviating from them\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-568\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-568\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>545<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <i>Pokémon</i> was a welcomed boon to Japan's faltering economy,<sup id=\"cite_ref-Allison_p._194,_236_229-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Allison_p._194,_236-229\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>217<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> and positively influenced the country's <a href=\"/wiki/Soft_power\" title=\"Soft power\">soft power</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-569\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-569\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>546<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-570\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-570\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>547<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Sociologist Yoshinori Kamo interviewed various American children and found that kids who thought <i>Pokémon</i> was cool, were more likely to believe that Japan was a cool nation.<sup id=\"cite_ref-571\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-571\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>548<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Anne Allison gave a similar finding: all the children she interviewed knew where <i>Pokémon</i> originated, and \"many said that, as a result of <i>Pokémon</i> and other 'cool' Japanese goods, they had developed an interest in Japan. A number said that they now wanted to study Japanese and travel there one day\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-572\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-572\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>549<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Author Chris Kohler wrote: \"Japanese are proud of <i>Pokémon</i>, the most successful export of Japanese popular culture ever\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-573\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-573\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>550<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Although, sociologist Koichi Iwabuchi questioned to what extent <i>Pokémon</i> really is 'Japanese', and to what extent it is simply a good property with universal appeal. He noted that <a href=\"/wiki/Japanese_nationalist\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Japanese nationalist\">Japanese nationalist</a> commentators celebrated <i>Pokémon</i><span class=\"nowrap\" style=\"padding-left:0.1em;\">'</span>s global success and retrospectively attributed this to its \"Japanese cultural power\",<sup id=\"cite_ref-574\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-574\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>551<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> while ignoring the localization of <i>Pokémon</i> overseas,<sup id=\"cite_ref-575\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-575\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>552<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> as well as decades of increasing cooperation and cultural exchange between countries (<a href=\"/wiki/Globalization\" title=\"Globalization\">globalization</a>).<sup id=\"cite_ref-576\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-576\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>553<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>In the 20th century, <a href=\"/wiki/Anime\" title=\"Anime\">anime</a> found niche popularity in North America and Europe in series (<i><a href=\"/wiki/Astro_Boy\" title=\"Astro Boy\">Astro Boy</a></i>, <i><a href=\"/wiki/Kimba_the_White_Lion\" title=\"Kimba the White Lion\">Kimba the White Lion</a></i>, <i><a href=\"/wiki/Speed_Racer\" title=\"Speed Racer\">Speed Racer</a></i>) and films (<i><a href=\"/wiki/Akira_(1988_film)\" title=\"Akira (1988 film)\">Akira</a></i>, <i><a href=\"/wiki/Ghost_in_the_Shell_(1995_film)\" title=\"Ghost in the Shell (1995 film)\">Ghost in the Shell</a></i>).<sup id=\"cite_ref-579\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-579\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>XIII<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_(TV_series)\" title=\"Pokémon (TV series)\"><i>Pokémon</i> TV series</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_Pok%C3%A9mon_films\" title=\"List of Pokémon films\">films</a> marked a breakthrough for anime, contributing to its growing worldwide success at the turn of the 21st century.<sup id=\"cite_ref-582\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-582\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>XIV<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> For some children, <i>Pokémon</i> was their introduction to 'Japanimation',<sup id=\"cite_ref-583\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-583\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>558<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-584\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-584\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>559<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> serving as a \"gateway\" to other anime, manga, and Japanese culture in general.<sup id=\"cite_ref-585\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-585\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>560<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-586\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-586\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>561<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <i><a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon:_The_First_Movie\" title=\"Pokémon: The First Movie\">Pokémon: The First Movie</a></i> became one of the most successful Japanese animated films in history.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Sammut_(2023)_344-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Sammut_(2023)-344\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>326<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> After <i><a href=\"/wiki/Princess_Mononoke\" title=\"Princess Mononoke\">Princess Mononoke</a></i>, <i>Pokémon: The First Movie</i> became the second anime film to open at mainstream cinemas in the West, as opposed to the usual art house venues.<sup id=\"cite_ref-587\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-587\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>562<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Pioneering anime importer <a href=\"/wiki/John_Ledford\" title=\"John Ledford\">John Ledford</a> noted that <i>Pokémon</i> underscored the commercial potential of anime, thus making it interesting from a business perspective.<sup id=\"cite_ref-588\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-588\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>563<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>In the field of video games, the <a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_(video_game_series)#Games\" title=\"Pokémon (video game series)\">main <i>Pokémon</i> series</a> became the paradigm of the <a href=\"/wiki/Monster-taming_game\" title=\"Monster-taming game\">monster-taming game</a>. While not the first to use this concept, the <i>Pokémon</i> games became so synonymous with it that later titles involving catching and training monsters, RPGs or not, were inevitably compared to <i>Pokémon</i>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-589\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-589\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>564<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-590\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-590\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>565<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-591\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-591\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>566<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> Examples of this include <i><a href=\"/wiki/Dragon_Warrior_Monsters\" title=\"Dragon Warrior Monsters\">Dragon Warrior Monsters</a></i> (1998),<sup id=\"cite_ref-597\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-597\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>XV<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/Robopon_Sun,_Star,_and_Moon_Versions\" title=\"Robopon Sun, Star, and Moon Versions\"><i>Robopon Sun</i> and <i>Star</i></a> (1998),<sup id=\"cite_ref-598\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-598\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>572<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-599\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-599\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>573<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <i><a href=\"/wiki/Spectrobes_(video_game)\" title=\"Spectrobes (video game)\">Spectrobes</a></i> (2007),<sup id=\"cite_ref-605\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-605\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>XVI<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <i><a href=\"/wiki/Invizimals_(video_game)\" title=\"Invizimals (video game)\">Invizimals</a></i> (2009),<sup id=\"cite_ref-611\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-611\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>XVII<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <i><a href=\"/wiki/Monster_Crown\" title=\"Monster Crown\">Monster Crown</a></i> (2021),<sup id=\"cite_ref-617\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-617\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>XVIII<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> and <i><a href=\"/wiki/Palworld\" title=\"Palworld\">Palworld</a></i> (2024).<sup id=\"cite_ref-623\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-623\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>XIX<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>The success of <i>Pokémon</i> encouraged companies to look for other popular Japanese properties that might be localized for Western markets.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Stewart_(2004)_268-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Stewart_(2004)-268\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>255<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-624\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-624\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>594<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-625\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-625\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>595<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The importing of at least three similar franchises were confirmed by business executives to have been (partly) inspired by <i>Pokémon</i>: <i><a href=\"/wiki/Yu-Gi-Oh!\" title=\"Yu-Gi-Oh!\">Yu-Gi-Oh!</a></i>,<sup id=\"cite_ref-626\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-626\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>596<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <i><a href=\"/wiki/Digimon\" title=\"Digimon\">Digimon</a></i>,<sup id=\"cite_ref-627\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-627\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>597<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> and <i><a href=\"/wiki/Monster_Rancher\" title=\"Monster Rancher\">Monster Rancher</a></i>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-628\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-628\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>598<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The import of <i><a href=\"/wiki/Cardcaptor_Sakura\" title=\"Cardcaptor Sakura\">Cardcaptor Sakura</a></i> (as <i>Cardcaptors</i>) might also have been prompted by <i>Pokémon</i>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-629\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-629\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>599<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-630\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-630\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>600<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading2\"><h2 id=\"Footnotes\">Footnotes</h2></div>\n<style data-mw-deduplicate=\"TemplateStyles:r1239543626\">.mw-parser-output .reflist{margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}@media screen{.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%}}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class=\"reflist reflist-columns references-column-width reflist-lower-alpha reflist-columns-3\">\n<ol class=\"references\" data-mw-group=\"lower-alpha\">\n<li id=\"cite_note-3\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-3\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\">Pronunciation: <span class=\"rt-commentedText nowrap\"><span class=\"IPA nopopups noexcerpt\" lang=\"en-fonipa\"><a href=\"/wiki/Help:IPA/English\" title=\"Help:IPA/English\">/<span style=\"border-bottom:1px dotted\"><span title=\"/ˈ/: primary stress follows\">ˈ</span><span title=\"'p' in 'pie'\">p</span><span title=\"/ə/: 'a' in 'about'\">ə</span><span title=\"/ʊ/: 'u' in 'push'\">ʊ</span><span title=\"'k' in 'kind'\">k</span><span title=\"/ə/: 'a' in 'about'\">ə</span><span title=\"'m' in 'my'\">m</span><span title=\"/ɒ/: 'o' in 'body'\">ɒ</span><span title=\"'n' in 'nigh'\">n</span></span>/</a></span></span> <a href=\"/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key\" title=\"Help:Pronunciation respelling key\"><i title=\"English pronunciation respelling\"><span style=\"font-size:90%\">POH</span>-kə-mon</i></a>, <span class=\"rt-commentedText nowrap\"><style data-mw-deduplicate=\"TemplateStyles:r1177148991\">.mw-parser-output .IPA-label-small{font-size:85%}.mw-parser-output .references .IPA-label-small,.mw-parser-output .infobox .IPA-label-small,.mw-parser-output .navbox .IPA-label-small{font-size:100%}</style><span class=\"IPA-label IPA-label-small\"><a href=\"/wiki/American_English\" title=\"American English\">US</a> also </span><span class=\"IPA nopopups noexcerpt\" lang=\"en-fonipa\"><a href=\"/wiki/Help:IPA/English\" title=\"Help:IPA/English\">/<span style=\"border-bottom:1px dotted\"><span title=\"/ˈ/: primary stress follows\">ˈ</span><span title=\"'p' in 'pie'\">p</span><span title=\"/oʊ/: 'o' in 'code'\">oʊ</span><span title=\"'k' in 'kind'\">k</span><span title=\"/i/: 'y' in 'happy'\">i</span><span title=\"'m' in 'my'\">m</span><span title=\"/ɒ/: 'o' in 'body'\">ɒ</span><span title=\"'n' in 'nigh'\">n</span></span>/</a></span></span> <a href=\"/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key\" title=\"Help:Pronunciation respelling key\"><i title=\"English pronunciation respelling\"><span style=\"font-size:90%\">POH</span>-kee-mon</i></a>.</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-4\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-4\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a href=\"/wiki/Japanese_language\" title=\"Japanese language\">Japanese</a>: <span lang=\"ja\">ポケモン</span>, <a href=\"/wiki/Hepburn_romanization\" title=\"Hepburn romanization\">Hepburn</a>: <span title=\"Hepburn transliteration\"><i lang=\"ja-Latn\">Pokemon</i></span></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-22\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-22\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\">This count excludes <a href=\"/wiki/Mega_Evolution\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Mega Evolution\">Mega Evolutions</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Dynamax\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Dynamax\">Dynamax</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Gigantamax\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Gigantamax\">Gigantamax</a>, regional variants, and other forms. These are not considered separate species of Pokémon, but variations of existing ones.</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-cardgames-72\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\">^ <a href=\"#cite_ref-cardgames_72-0\"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href=\"#cite_ref-cardgames_72-1\"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class=\"reference-text\">Four<sup id=\"cite_ref-66\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-66\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>60<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> original card games are known to have been designed by Itoi: <i>Slot Brothers</i>,<sup id=\"cite_ref-67\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-67\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>61<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <i>Edoka</i>,<sup id=\"cite_ref-68\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-68\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>62<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <i>Hanamaru</i>,<sup id=\"cite_ref-69\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-69\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>63<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> and <i>Rameka</i>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-70\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-70\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>64<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The 1998 book <i>The Secrets of Pokemon</i> states that the last three games were contributed to by Ishihara.<sup id=\"cite_ref-71\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-71\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>65<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-78\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-78\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\">In <i><a href=\"/wiki/Dragon_Quest_II\" title=\"Dragon Quest II\">Dragon Quest II</a></i>, the item is called ふしぎなぼうし, <i>Fushigina Bōshi</i>, i.e. Mysterious Hat. The Japanese <i>Pokemon</i> RPGs feature an item called ふしぎなアメ, <i>Fushigina Ame</i>, i.e. Mysterious Candy. This item raises the level of a Pokemon by one. In the English games, it is called Rare Candy.</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-bugfixing-155\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-bugfixing_155-0\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\">Shortly after the original release of <i>Red/Green</i>, and before the release of <i>Blue</i>, Game Freak also made a slightly tweaked, new revision of <i>Red/Green</i>, which included bug fixes. Newly pressed cartridges shipped to stores subsequently had the updated <i>Red/Green</i> version installed on them.<sup id=\"cite_ref-154\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-154\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>144<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-boosters-177\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\">^ <a href=\"#cite_ref-boosters_177-0\"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href=\"#cite_ref-boosters_177-1\"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class=\"reference-text\">From the original <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_Pok%C3%A9mon_Trading_Card_Game_sets#Pokémon_Base_Set\" title=\"List of Pokémon Trading Card Game sets\">Base Set</a> to the <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_Pok%C3%A9mon_Trading_Card_Game_sets#Neo_Destiny\" title=\"List of Pokémon Trading Card Game sets\">Neo Destiny sets</a>, the booster packs contained 11 cards. After that and throughout the <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_Pok%C3%A9mon_Trading_Card_Game_sets#Third_Generation_Sets\" title=\"List of Pokémon Trading Card Game sets\">third generation 'EX' sets</a>, the booster packs contained 9 cards. From the <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_Pok%C3%A9mon_Trading_Card_Game_sets#Fourth_Generation_Sets\" title=\"List of Pokémon Trading Card Game sets\">fourth generation <i>Diamond and Pearl</i> sets</a> onwards, the packs contained 10 cards. Since the <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_Pok%C3%A9mon_Trading_Card_Game_sets#Seventh_Generation_Sets\" title=\"List of Pokémon Trading Card Game sets\">seventh generation <i>Sun and Moon</i> sets</a>, the packs have again contained 11 cards.</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-245\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-245\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\">A definitive number could not be established. The <a href=\"/wiki/Fire_and_Disaster_Management_Agency\" title=\"Fire and Disaster Management Agency\">Fire and Disaster Management Agency</a> announced that, as of 17:00, 17 December, a total of 685 people had been taken to hospitals in direct relationship to the <i>Pokemon</i> episode. Of these, 208 people were actually hospitalized.<sup id=\"cite_ref-240\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-240\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>228<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> However, different figures have been stated by different sources.<sup id=\"cite_ref-241\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-241\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>229<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-242\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-242\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>230<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> <i>Pokemon Story</i> (2000), a 500+ page book on <i>Pokemon</i>, states that \"approximately 750 children\" were taken to hospitals, of which 135 were hospitalized.<sup id=\"cite_ref-243\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-243\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>231<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> It has been reported that, due to the incident catching the country off-guard, different methods of surveying were used throughout Japan, and these methods were not always accurate.<sup id=\"cite_ref-244\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-244\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>232<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-285\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-285\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\">However, <i><a href=\"/wiki/Sailor_Moon\" title=\"Sailor Moon\">Sailor Moon</a></i> did gain a cult following at the time.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Allison_(2006)_p154_282-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Allison_(2006)_p154-282\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>268<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> After being pulled from syndication in spring 1996 due to low ratings,<sup id=\"cite_ref-283\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-283\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>269<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> it was broadcast again on <a href=\"/wiki/USA_Network\" title=\"USA Network\">USA Network</a> from June 1997 to March 1998.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Lenburg_(2009)_p613_284-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Lenburg_(2009)_p613-284\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>270<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> The anime subsequently had a successful run on <a href=\"/wiki/Cartoon_Network\" title=\"Cartoon Network\">Cartoon Network</a>'s <a href=\"/wiki/Toonami\" title=\"Toonami\">Toonami</a> <a href=\"/wiki/Block_programming\" title=\"Block programming\">block</a> from 1 June 1998, to 5 July 2002, a timeframe that overlapped Pokémania.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Allison_(2006)_p154_282-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Allison_(2006)_p154-282\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>268<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Lenburg_(2009)_p613_284-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Lenburg_(2009)_p613-284\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>270<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-369\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-369\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\">Shogakukan kept this condition until 2021. As of 2025<sup class=\"plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update\" style=\"display:none;\"><a class=\"external text\" href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pok%C3%A9mon&amp;action=edit\">[update]</a></sup>, the last animated <i>Pokémon</i> feature is <span title=\"Hepburn transliteration\"><i lang=\"ja-Latn\">Pokemon: Coco</i></span><span style=\"font-weight: normal\"> (<span title=\"Japanese-language text\"><span lang=\"ja\">ポケモン ココ</span></span>)</span>, released in Japan on 25 December 2020. It was released worldwide (excluding Japan, Korea, and China) as <i><a href=\"/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_the_Movie:_Secrets_of_the_Jungle\" title=\"Pokémon the Movie: Secrets of the Jungle\">Pokémon the Movie: Secrets of the Jungle</a></i> on 8 October 2021. Between 1998 and 2021, <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_Pok%C3%A9mon_films\" title=\"List of Pokémon films\">a total of 23 anime films</a> were released.</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-522\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-522\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\">In her 2006 book <i>Millennial Monsters</i>, <a href=\"/wiki/Anne_Allison\" title=\"Anne Allison\">Anne Allison</a> mentions the card suit and writes, within parentheses, that it \"was eventually settled out of court\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-521\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-521\"><span class=\"cite-bracket\">[</span>500<span class=\"cite-bracket\">]</span></a></sup> However, she does not cite a source for this. The full sentence does contain an inline citation to a <i><a href=\"/wiki/New_York_Times\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"New York Times\">New York Times</a></i> piece, but this article doesn't state that the case was settled.</span>\n</li>\n</ol></div>\n<div class=\"mw-heading mw-heading2\"><h2 id=\"References\">References</h2></div>\n<link rel=\"mw-deduplicated-inline-style\" [Such a council-like system is actually not that common among well-known properties. (...) Pokémon is probably the only character in the world today whose original rights are not consolidated in the hands of a single major copyright holder or a single company.]</cite><span title=\"ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=%E3%83%9D%E3%82%B1%E3%83%A2%E3%83%B3%E3%83%BB%E3%82%B9%E3%83%88%E3%83%BC%E3%83%AA%E3%83%BC&amp;rft.pages=474-475&amp;rft.pub=Nikkei+BP&amp;rft.date=2000-12-10&amp;rft.isbn=978-4822241995&amp;rft.aulast=Hatakeyama&amp;rft.aufirst=Kenji&amp;rft.au=Kubo%2C+Masakazu&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APok%C3%A9mon\" class=\"Z3988\"></span></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-Daswani_(2009)-16\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\">^ <a href=\"#cite_ref-Daswani_(2009)_16-0\"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href=\"#cite_ref-Daswani_(2009)_16-1\"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><link rel=\"mw-deduplicated-inline-style\" href=\"mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222\"><cite id=\"CITEREFDaswani2009\" class=\"citation web cs1\">Daswani, Mansha (9 April 2009). <a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"https://web.archive.org/web/20090413121437/http://worldscreen.com/articles/display/20547\">\"Pokémon Merges North American, European Operations\"</a>. <i>WorldScreen.com</i>. <q>But on the other hand, I don't worry about it as much as, say, 'Beast Wars', 'Batman' or 'X-Men'\", all animated series that she said emphasized violence.</q></cite><span title=\"ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+New+York+Times&amp;rft.atitle=Masters+of+the+Universe%2C+Youth+Division&amp;rft.pages=4&amp;rft.date=1999-08-29&amp;rft.aulast=Graeber&amp;rft.aufirst=Laurel&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F1999%2F08%2F29%2Ftv%2Fcover-story-masters-of-the-universe-youth-division.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APok%C3%A9mon\" from the original on 27 February 2023. <q>Parents find them less violent than some other recent toy phenomena, such as the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles.</q></cite><span rel=\"mw-deduplicated-inline-style\" href=\"mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222\"><cite id=\"CITEREFMallory2001\" class=\"citation news cs1\">Mallory, Michael (12 October 2001). <a rel=\"nofollow\" crack a perennial kids' TV nut: how to present action without violence. It's the stylized, whimsical little monsters that do all the fighting, not the humans.</q></cite><span title=\"ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Los+Angeles+Times&amp;rft.atitle=Kids%27+Anime+Hits+Critical+Mass&amp;rft.pages=F18&amp;rft.date=2001-10-12&amp;rft.aulast=Mallory&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.latimes.com%2Farchives%2Fla-xpm-2001-oct-12-ca-56238-story.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APok%C3%A9mon\" class=\"Z3988\"></span></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-Chua-Eoan_Larimer_(1999)-32\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\">^ <a href=\"#cite_ref-Chua-Eoan_Larimer_(1999)_32-0\"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href=\"#cite_ref-Chua-Eoan_Larimer_(1999)_32-1\"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href=\"#cite_ref-Chua-Eoan_Larimer_(1999)_32-2\"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href=\"#cite_ref-Chua-Eoan_Larimer_(1999)_32-3\"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href=\"#cite_ref-Chua-Eoan_Larimer_(1999)_32-4\"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a> <a href=\"#cite_ref-Chua-Eoan_Larimer_(1999)_32-5\"><sup><i><b>f</b></i></sup></a> <a href=\"#cite_ref-Chua-Eoan_Larimer_(1999)_32-6\"><sup><i><b>g</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><link rel=\"mw-deduplicated-inline-style\" href=\"mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222\"><cite id=\"CITEREFChua-EoanLarimer1999\" class=\"citation magazine cs1\">Chua-Eoan, Howard; Larimer, Tim (22 November 1999). <a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"https://content.time.com/time/subscriber/printout/0,8816,992625,00.html\">\"Beware of the Poke Mania\"</a>. <i><a href=\"/wiki/Time_(magazine)\" title=\"Time (magazine)\">Time</a></i>. When they lose battles, they faint. And if that happens to your Pokemon, you can take it to the local Pokemon Center, a high-tech spa where it can be restored to \"fighting fit\".</q></cite><span title=\"ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Time&amp;rft.atitle=Beware+of+the+Poke+Mania&amp;rft.volume=154&amp;rft.issue=21&amp;rft.pages=80-86&amp;rft.date=1999-11-22&amp;rft.aulast=Chua-Eoan&amp;rft.aufirst=Howard&amp;rft.au=Larimer%2C+Tim&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fcontent.time.com%2Ftime%2Fsubscriber%2Fprintout%2F0%2C8816%2C992625%2C00.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APok%C3%A9mon\" class=\"Z3988\"></span></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-Plotz_(1999)-33\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\">^ <a href=\"#cite_ref-Plotz_(1999)_33-0\"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href=\"#cite_ref-Plotz_(1999)_33-1\"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><link rel=\"mw-deduplicated-inline-style\" href=\"mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222\"><cite id=\"CITEREFPlotz1999\" class=\"citation web cs1\"><a href=\"/wiki/David_Plotz\" title=\"David Plotz\">Plotz, David</a> (12 November 1999). <a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"https://slate.com/news-and-politics/1999/11/pokemon.html\">\"Pokémon. Little. Yellow. Different. Better\"</a>. <i><a href=\"/wiki/Slate_(magazine)\" title=\"Slate (magazine)\">Slate</a></i>. <a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"https://web.archive.org/web/20030316022254/http://slate.msn.com/id/55696/\">Archived</a> from the original on 16 March 2003. <q>Pokémon softens its violence with sweetness. Like Ninja Turtles and Power Rangers, Pokémon is packed with battle scenes. But it is far gentler. Pokémon never die, they only \"faint\".</q></cite><span title=\"ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Slate&amp;rft.atitle=Pok%C3%A9mon.+Little.+Yellow.+Different.+Better.&amp;rft.date=1999-11-12&amp;rft.aulast=Plotz&amp;rft.aufirst=David&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fslate.com%2Fnews-and-politics%2F1999%2F11%2Fpokemon.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APok%C3%A9mon\" class=\"Z3988\"></span></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-Howe_(2000)-34\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\">^ <a href=\"#cite_ref-Howe_(2000)_34-0\"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href=\"#cite_ref-Howe_(2000)_34-1\"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><link rel=\"mw-deduplicated-inline-style\" href=\"mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222\"><cite id=\"CITEREFHowe2000\" class=\"citation news cs1\">Howe, Rupert (5 March 2000). <span class=\"id-lock-subscription\" title=\"Paid subscription required\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"https://www.proquest.com/docview/311603385\">\"Made in Japan: Chasing the Dragon. But a New Wave of Japanese Monsters Threatens to Be Even More Addictive\"</a></span>. <i><a href=\"/wiki/The_Independent\" title=\"The Independent\">The Independent</a></i>. pp.&nbsp;<span class=\"nowrap\">20–</span>23. <link rel=\"mw-deduplicated-inline-style\" href=\"mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222\"><a href=\"/wiki/ProQuest\" title=\"ProQuest\">ProQuest</a>&nbsp;<a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"https://www.proquest.com/docview/311603385\">311603385</a>. <q>But Pokemon was different. Pokemon monsters, famously, do not die; they simply suffer a cute fainting fit. And it's this emphasis on non-violent problem-solving and group action which also informs the new shows.</q></cite><span title=\"ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Independent&amp;rft.atitle=Made+in+Japan%3A+Chasing+the+Dragon.+Pokemon+Was+Nicknamed+%27Kiddie+Crack%27.+But+a+New+Wave+of+Japanese+Monsters+Threatens+to+Be+Even+More+Addictive.&amp;rft.pages=20-23&amp;rft.date=2000-03-05&amp;rft.aulast=Howe&amp;rft.aufirst=Rupert&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.proquest.com%2Fdocview%2F311603385&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APok%C3%A9mon\" Archived from <a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lwSSWGxgCwM\">the original</a> on 9 September 2023.</cite><span title=\"ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=GameCenter+CX&amp;rft.place=Japan&amp;rft.series=Season+1.+Episode+SP&amp;rft.pub=Fuji+TV&amp;rft.date=2004-05-30&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.youtube.com%2Fwatch%3Fv%3DlwSSWGxgCwM&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APok%C3%A9mon\" class=\"Z3988\"></span></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-51\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-51\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a href=\"#CITEREFTomisawa2000\">Tomisawa (2000)</a>, p.&nbsp;168: \"当時は、現在のようなゲー厶情報が掲載された専門の雑誌はまだ存在していなかった。だからこそ、それを豆本なり小冊子なりにまとめてやれば、ゲー厶プレイヤーたちからの大きな需要があるだろう、と考えたのだ。\" [\"At that time, magazines specializing in gaming did not yet exist as they do today. Therefore, he figured there would be a great demand among gamers for a kind of pamphlet or small book with gaming information.\"]</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-52\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-52\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><link rel=\"mw-deduplicated-inline-style\" href=\"mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222\"><span id=\"CITEREFSato1998\" class=\"citation\">Sato, Tetsurō. \"The Birth of Pokemon\". In <a href=\"#CITEREFOhtsuki1998\">Ohtsuki (1998)</a>, p.&nbsp;133.</span> \"当時はTVゲームの攻略法を解説した雑誌など皆無だった。『ゲームフリーク』は全国のTVゲームファンに口コミで拡がり、定期購読者を増やしていった。読者からの攻略法のリクエストも殺到した。\" [\"At that time, there were no magazines that explained video game strategies. \"Game Freak\" spread by word of mouth among video game fans nationwide, and the number of subscribers grew. Requests for game strategies from readers also started pouring in.\"]</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-53\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-53\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a href=\"#CITEREFMiyaTajiri2004\">Miya &amp; Archived from <a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"http://www.nintendo.co.jp/nom/0007/kawaguti/page01.html\">the original</a> on 16 December 2002.</cite><span title=\"ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Nintendo+Online+Magazine&amp;rft.atitle=%E3%83%9D%E3%82%B1%E3%83%A2%E3%83%B3%E8%AA%95%E7%94%9F%E7%A7%98%E8%A9%B1%E5%A4%A7%E5%85%AC%E9%96%8B%21%21+%E5%B7%9D%E5%8F%A3%E5%AD%9D%E5%8F%B8%E3%81%95%E3%82%93%EF%BC%88%E4%BB%BB%E5%A4%A9%E5%A0%82%EF%BC%89%E3%82%A4%E3%83%B3%E3%82%BF%E3%83%93%E3%83%A5%E3%83%BC&amp;rft.date=2000-07&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nintendo.co.jp%2Fnom%2F0007%2Fkawaguti%2Fpage01.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APok%C3%A9mon\" class=\"Z3988\"></span></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-Masuda_2019_interview-65\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\">^ <a href=\"#cite_ref-Masuda_2019_interview_65-0\"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href=\"#cite_ref-Masuda_2019_interview_65-1\"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href=\"#cite_ref-Masuda_2019_interview_65-2\"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href=\"#cite_ref-Masuda_2019_interview_65-3\"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><link rel=\"mw-deduplicated-inline-style\" href=\"mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222\"><cite class=\"citation magazine cs1\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"https://lavacutcontent.com/masuda-game-freak-history/\">\"増田氏が語る、ゲームフリークが世界で通じる会社になるまで\"</a> [Game Freak's Path to Worldwide Fame, As Told By Masuda]. <i><a href=\"/wiki/Sh%C5%ABkan_Famits%C5%AB\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Shūkan Famitsū\">Shūkan Famitsū</a></i>. 23 May 2019. pp.&nbsp;<span class=\"nowrap\">82–</span>86. <a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"https://archive.today/20250207170813/https://lavacutcontent.com/masuda-game-freak-history/\">Archived</a> from the original on 7 February 2025. <q>Ishihara in particular was fond of card games and used that insight to advise on how to add more depth to the battle system. To be honest, things like the Pokemon types, the link cable battles, and the Pokedex were all added later in development based on his suggestions. (...) Ishihara also gave us some pointers on the story and setting.</q></cite><span title=\"ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Sh%C5%ABkan+Famits%C5%AB&amp;rft.atitle=%E5%A2%97%E7%94%B0%E6%B0%8F%E3%81%8C%E8%AA%9E%E3%82%8B%E3%80%81%E3%82%B2%E3%83%BC%E3%83%A0%E3%83%95%E3%83%AA%E3%83%BC%E3%82%AF%E3%81%8C%E4%B8%96%E7%95%8C%E3%81%A7%E9%80%9A%E3%81%98%E3%82%8B%E4%BC%9A%E7%A4%BE%E3%81%AB%E3%81%AA%E3%82%8B%E3%81%BE%E3%81%A7&amp;rft.pages=82-86&amp;rft.date=2019-05-23&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Flavacutcontent.com%2Fmasuda-game-freak-history%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APok%C3%A9mon\" But after that, Tajiri tried to regain the world that he had lost by creating Pokemon.\"]</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-87\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-87\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a href=\"#CITEREFHatakeyamaKubo2000\">Hatakeyama &amp; Kubo (2000)</a>, p.&nbsp;75-76.</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-92\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-92\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a href=\"#CITEREFTajiri1995\">Tajiri (1995)</a>, p.&nbsp;154 + 155.</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-93\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-93\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><link rel=\"mw-deduplicated-inline-style\" href=\"mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222\"><cite class=\"citation web cs1\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"https://web.archive.org/web/20021215234444/https://www.nintendo.co.jp/nom/0007/gfreak/page01.html\">\"開発スタッフインタビュー/ゲーム内容が決まるまで\"</a> [Interview with development staff / Making the Game]. <i>Nintendo Online Magazine</i>. nintendo.co.jp. You're working on a Game Boy game? That's not going to sell very well, don't you think?\" That's kind of what the atmosphere was like in Japan at the time.</q></cite><span title=\"ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Polygon&amp;rft.atitle=Pok%C3%A9mon+veteran+Junichi+Masuda+reflects+on+the+series%27+early+days&amp;rft.date=2018-09-28&amp;rft.aulast=Frank&amp;rft.aufirst=Allegra&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.polygon.com%2Finterviews%2F2018%2F9%2F27%2F17909916%2Fpokemon-red-blue-junichi-masuda-interview&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APok%C3%A9mon\" class=\"Z3988\"></span></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-141\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-141\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a href=\"#CITEREFHatakeyamaKubo2000\">Hatakeyama &amp; Kubo (2000)</a>, p.&nbsp;169.</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-142\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-142\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a href=\"#CITEREFHatakeyamaKubo2000\">Hatakeyama &amp; Kubo (2000)</a>, p.&nbsp;178.</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-143\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-143\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a href=\"#CITEREFHatakeyamaKubo2000\">Hatakeyama &amp; Kubo (2000)</a>, p.&nbsp;170.</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-Sato_(1998)_p118-144\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\">^ <a href=\"#cite_ref-Sato_(1998)_p118_144-0\"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href=\"#cite_ref-Sato_(1998)_p118_144-1\"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href=\"#cite_ref-Sato_(1998)_p118_144-2\"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href=\"#cite_ref-Sato_(1998)_p118_144-3\"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><link rel=\"mw-deduplicated-inline-style\" href=\"mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222\"><span id=\"CITEREFSato1998\" class=\"citation\">Sato, Tetsurō. \"Pokemon course for fathers\". id=\"cite_note-150\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-150\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a href=\"#CITEREFHatakeyamaKubo2000\">Hatakeyama &amp; Kubo (2000)</a>, p.&nbsp;204.</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-CoroCoro_May_96-151\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\">^ <a href=\"#cite_ref-CoroCoro_May_96_151-0\"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href=\"#cite_ref-CoroCoro_May_96_151-1\"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><link rel=\"mw-deduplicated-inline-style\" href=\"mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222\"><cite class=\"citation magazine cs1\">\"ポケットモンスター「赤・緑」100 万本突破記念、青バージョン新発売！\" [To commemorate the sales of over 1 million copies of <i>Pokemon Red</i> and <i>Green</i>, a new <i>Blue</i> version has been released!]. <i><a href=\"/wiki/CoroCoro_Comic\" title=\"CoroCoro Comic\">CoroCoro Comic</a></i>. 15 April 1996. pp.&nbsp;<span class=\"nowrap\">59–</span>60.</cite><span title=\"ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=CoroCoro+Comic&amp;rft.atitle=%E3%83%9D%E3%82%B1%E3%83%83%E3%83%88%E3%83%A2%E3%83%B3%E3%82%B9%E3%82%BF%E3%83%BC%E3%80%8C%E8%B5%A4%E3%83%BB%E7%B7%91%E3%80%8D100+%E4%B8%87%E6%9C%AC%E7%AA%81%E7%A0%B4%E8%A8%98%E5%BF%B5%E3%80%81%E9%9D%92%E3%83%90%E3%83%BC%E3%82%B8%E3%83%A7%E3%83%B3%E6%96%B0%E7%99%BA%E5%A3%B2%EF%BC%81&amp;rft.pages=59-60&amp;rft.date=1996-04-15&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APok%C3%A9mon\" class=\"Z3988\"></span> (<a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"https://archive.today/20250207173209/https://lavacutcontent.com/corocoro-comic-pokemon-blue/\">Translation</a>)</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-Iwata_Asks_1-152\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\">^ <a href=\"#cite_ref-Iwata_Asks_1_152-0\"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href=\"#cite_ref-Iwata_Asks_1_152-1\"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><link rel=\"mw-deduplicated-inline-style\" href=\"mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222\"><cite class=\"citation interview cs1\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"https://iwataasks.nintendo.com/interviews/ds/pokemon/0/0/\">\"Just Making The Last Train\"</a> (Interview). <a href=\"/wiki/Iwata_Asks\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Iwata Asks\">Iwata Asks</a>. Interviewed by <a href=\"/wiki/Satoru_Iwata\" title=\"Satoru Iwata\">Iwata, Satoru</a>. <a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"https://web.archive.org/web/20230328012400/https://iwataasks.nintendo.com/interviews/ds/pokemon/0/0/\">Archived</a> from the original on 28 March 2023.</cite><span title=\"ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Just+Making+The+Last+Train&amp;rft.series=Iwata+Asks&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fiwataasks.nintendo.com%2Finterviews%2Fds%2Fpokemon%2F0%2F0%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APok%C3%A9mon\" class=\"Z3988\"></span></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-153\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-153\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a href=\"#CITEREFHatakeyamaKubo2000\">Hatakeyama &amp; Kubo (2000)</a>, p.&nbsp;532.</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-154\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-154\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a href=\"#CITEREFHatakeyamaKubo2000\">Hatakeyama &amp; Kubo (2000)</a>, p.&nbsp;200: \"ミュウが出現するという報告を受けると、すぐにデバッグプログラムを起こし、修正できるタイミングの出荷分から、ミュウの箱をさらに厳重に封印しました。その結果、市場にはミュウが出現するカートリッジと出現しないカートリッジが存在することになりました。\" [\"As soon as they [Nintendo] received reports of Mew appearing, they initiated a debugging program and sealed the Mew data even tighter, starting with the next batch of shipped cartridges. As a result, there were now cartridges on the market in which Mew could appear and cartridges in which Mew could not appear.\"].</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-156\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-156\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a href=\"#CITEREFTomisawa2000\">Tomisawa (2000)</a>, p.&nbsp;14: \"〈赤〉と〈緑〉が発売されたあとも、残されていたバグを取り除く作業や、新人の育成などの意味も含めて、制作を担当したゲー厶フリークの社内で試験的に作られていたものだったのだ。しかし、グラフィック担当者からの要望で、ポケモンたちの絵を新しく描き起こすなどしているうちに、〈青バージョン〉はかなり完成度の高いものになってきた。\" [\"Even after <i>Red</i> and <i>Green</i> had been released, the games were still being tested in-house at Game Freak, the company in charge of their development, in order to remove any remaining bugs and to train new employees. However, at the request of the graphic designers, the Pokemon characters were redrawn, and eventually, the <i>Blue Version</i> turned out a very polished product.\"].</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-157\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-157\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a href=\"#CITEREFHatakeyamaKubo2000\">Hatakeyama &amp; Kubo (2000)</a>, p.&nbsp;210.</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-158\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-158\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a href=\"#CITEREFHatakeyamaKubo2000\">Hatakeyama &amp; Kubo (2000)</a>, p.&nbsp;212-213.</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-159\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-159\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a href=\"#CITEREFTomisawa2000\">Tomisawa (2000)</a>, p.&nbsp;16.</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-160\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-160\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a href=\"#CITEREFPokemon_Business_Study_Group1998\">Pokemon Business Study Group (1998)</a>, p.&nbsp;88-89.</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p153-161\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\">^ <a href=\"#cite_ref-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p153_161-0\"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href=\"#cite_ref-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p153_161-1\"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href=\"#cite_ref-Hatakeyama_Kubo_(2000)_p153_161-2\"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a href=\"#CITEREFHatakeyamaKubo2000\">Hatakeyama &amp; Kubo (2000)</a>, p.&nbsp;153.</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-Pokemon_Business_Study_Group_(1998)_p112-117-162\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\">^ <a href=\"#cite_ref-Pokemon_Business_Study_Group_(1998)_p112-117_162-0\"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href=\"#cite_ref-Pokemon_Business_Study_Group_(1998)_p112-117_162-1\"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a href=\"#CITEREFPokemon_Business_Study_Group1998\">Pokemon Business Study Group (1998)</a>, p.&nbsp;112-117.</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-Kimura_2006-163\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\">^ <a href=\"#cite_ref-Kimura_2006_163-0\"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href=\"#cite_ref-Kimura_2006_163-1\"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a href=\"#CITEREFKimura2006\">Kimura (2006)</a>: \"香山は続けて岩崎に、米国 WOC 社製「マジック・ザ・ギャザリング」というトレーディングカードゲームが米国で大人気であること、石原たちが開発した「ポケットモンスター カードゲーム」は「マジック・ザ・ギャザリング」をヒントにしているが、純国産のオリジナルトレーディングカードゲームであることを教えた。そして今の所、声をかけた、幾つかの大手卸問屋から取り組みを拒否されていることも岩崎に伝えた。\" (\"Kayama went on to tell Iwasaki that a trading card game called \"Magic the Gathering\" made by WOC [Wizards of the Coast] was very popular in the United States, and that the \"Pokemon Card Game\" developed by Ishihara and his colleagues was inspired by \"Magic the Gathering\". However, it was a completely original trading card game made in Japan. He also told Iwasaki that, so far, several major wholesalers he had approached had rejected the project.\")</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-164\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-164\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><link rel=\"mw-deduplicated-inline-style\" href=\"mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222\"><cite id=\"CITEREFTobin2004\" class=\"citation book cs1\">Brougère, Gilles (5 February 2004). \"Pokémon in France\". In <a href=\"/wiki/Joseph_Tobin\" title=\"Joseph Tobin\">Tobin, Joseph</a> (ed.). <i>Pikachu's Global Adventure: The Rise and Fall of Pokémon</i>. <a href=\"/wiki/Duke_University_Press\" title=\"Duke University Press\">Duke University Press</a>. p.&nbsp;197. <a href=\"/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"ISBN (identifier)\">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href=\"/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0822332879\" title=\"Special:BookSources/978-0822332879\"><bdi>978-0822332879</bdi></a>.</cite><span title=\"ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Pok%C3%A9mon+in+France&amp;rft.btitle=Pikachu%27s+Global+Adventure%3A+The+Rise+and+Fall+of+Pok%C3%A9mon&amp;rft.pages=197&amp;rft.pub=Duke+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2004-02-05&amp;rft.isbn=978-0822332879&amp;rft.aulast=Broug%C3%A8re&amp;rft.aufirst=Gilles&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APok%C3%A9mon\" class=\"Z3988\"></span></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-165\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-165\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><link rel=\"mw-deduplicated-inline-style\" href=\"mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222\"><cite class=\"citation web cs1\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"http://www.sjgames.com/pyramid/sample.html?id=571\">\"Pyramid Review: Pokemon Trading Card Game\"</a>. <i><a href=\"/wiki/Pyramid_(magazine)\" title=\"Pyramid (magazine)\">Pyramid</a></i>. Kubo (2000)</a>, p.&nbsp;309 + 332.</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-200\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-200\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a href=\"#CITEREFPokemon_Business_Study_Group1998\">Pokemon Business Study Group (1998)</a>, p.&nbsp;164-165.</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-201\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-201\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><link rel=\"mw-deduplicated-inline-style\" href=\"mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222\"><cite id=\"CITEREFYoshidaFlanagan1999\" class=\"citation magazine cs1\">Yoshida, Toshifumi; Flanagan, Bill (July 1999). <a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"https://www.animenostalgiabomb.com/1st-pokemon-cover-pikachu-and-ash-ketchum-animerica-july-1999/\">\"Animerica interview: Takemoto Mori\"</a>. <i><a href=\"/wiki/Animerica\" title=\"Animerica\">Animerica</a></i>. Vol.&nbsp;7. pp.&nbsp;28 + 30. <a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"https://web.archive.org/web/20231201224853/https://www.animenostalgiabomb.com/1st-pokemon-cover-pikachu-and-ash-ketchum-animerica-july-1999/\">Archived</a> from the original on 1 December 2023. <q>The main point is not to alienate any of the kids. For example, if we had the main character choose Zenigame (Squirtle), then some of the kids would say, \"Hey, I chose Hitokage (Charmander),\" and that would lead to the kid saying, \"Who needs this show!\"<span class=\"cs1-kern-right\"></span></q></cite><span title=\"ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Animerica&amp;rft.atitle=Animerica+interview%3A+Takemoto+Mori&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.pages=28+%2B+30&amp;rft.date=1999-07&amp;rft.aulast=Yoshida&amp;rft.aufirst=Toshifumi&amp;rft.au=Flanagan%2C+Bill&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.animenostalgiabomb.com%2F1st-pokemon-cover-pikachu-and-ash-ketchum-animerica-july-1999%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APok%C3%A9mon\" In <a href=\"#CITEREFTobin2004\">Tobin (2004)</a>, pp.&nbsp;59–61.</span> \"While feared and envied in the West, Japan's success in exporting cultural products led to the emergence in the 1990s of a chauvinistic, self-praising discourse in Japan. Flush with nationalistic pride, Japanese social commentators suddenly found a specifically Japanese \"fragrance\" in these previously culturally odorless products\".</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-575\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-575\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><link rel=\"mw-deduplicated-inline-style\" href=\"mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222\"><span id=\"CITEREFIwabuchi2004\" class=\"citation\">Iwabuchi, Koichi. \"How \"Japanese\" Is Pokémon?\". In <a href=\"#CITEREFTobin2004\">Tobin (2004)</a>, pp.&nbsp;66–69.</span> \"However, American involvement in Pokémon is not just limited to distribution; it includes as well involvement in production, in the form of alterations in the substance of Pokémon\"</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-576\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-576\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><link rel=\"mw-deduplicated-inline-style\" href=\"mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222\"><span id=\"CITEREFIwabuchi2004\" class=\"citation\">Iwabuchi, Koichi. \"How \"Japanese\" Is Pokémon?\". In <a href=\"#CITEREFTobin2004\">Tobin (2004)</a>, p.&nbsp;64.</span> \"It is important to locate the global popularity of Pokémon, and of Japanese animation and computer games in general, within a wider picture of the increasing interconnectedness of transnational media industries and markets, an interconnectedness that in turn reflects larger processes of globalization.\"</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-577\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-577\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><link rel=\"mw-deduplicated-inline-style\" href=\"mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222\"><cite id=\"CITEREFFrutkin1999\" class=\"citation news cs1\">Frutkin, Alan (12 April 1999). <span class=\"id-lock-subscription\" title=\"Paid subscription required\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"https://www.proquest.com/docview/213654957\">\"Land of the rising shows: Japanese imports are catching on at broadcast and cable nets\"</a></span>. <i><a href=\"/wiki/Mediaweek_(American_magazine)\" title=\"Mediaweek (American magazine)\">Mediaweek</a></i>. This launched a global phenomenon known as *Pokémania*, characterized by intense media coverage, merchandise sales, and passionate fan communities. The creation of The Pokémon Company and Pokémon USA further solidified the franchise's international presence, streamlining operations and managing its explosive growth.\"\n"
